description:
3.75ish: Pretty tasty! 

The authentic and delightful Turkish smells wafting out of this place are incredible! 

My bff and I showed up at 5:30pm on a Friday night. Made a reservation but they couldn't find it. It was practically empty when we arrived so it wasn't a problem. 

We were seated in a cute wooden booth. Not the most comfy but nice. My fried started with a Turkish beer and we ordered a few small plates. 

Decided on the spiced fries ($6.50), dolmas ($12) and grilled cauliflower ($10). The fries were perfectly seasoned without being salty and came with a lemony garlic mayo. Fries were crispy and hot just like I like it! 

The dolmas were my favorite dish of the entire meal. Four baby cabbage rolls stuffed with delicious beef and topped with a bright tomato sauce and a sexy tzatziki type white sauce. OMG I could eat those everyday! The grilled cauliflower was smokey and tender without being mushy. Served with the sexy tzatziki on the bottom of the dish. Overall, they supply several fantastic vegetable offerings here. 

For our mains we split the vegetable moussaka and the salmon kebab platter. Moussaka was just ok in my opinion. Didn't taste the béchamel sauce at all. It was kinda dry without it and the lentils were hard. It wasn't completely hot all the way through, either. It came with a deliciously moist, well seasoned rice with slivered almonds on top. The two sauces served with the meal were excellent as well but I would not order the moussaka again. I've had better. 

Salmon kebab was meaty and juicy. Perfectly cubed and served with kebab veggies that were grilled properly. It came with a simple, yet well dressed salad and yummy spiced rice with a creamy-spicy sauce on top. Super yummy dish that didn't leave me feeling heavy. Would definitely order again. 

We ran out of beverages a few times. Wish the servers would have checked up on us more.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
Came here with a friend at about 6:45pm on a Sunday. We had a reservation, but probably didn't need one. There are high top tables and regular seating. The service was really nice and attentive. 

We decided to get two things to share: the Vegetable Moussaka with lentils, eggplant, zucchini, potatoes, and bechamel sauce ($17.50) and a Organic Chickpea Falafel Bowl ($12) with hummus, pita, greens, avocado, feta, and herb yogurt. 

The Vegetable Moussaka in its appearance, looked like a Shepard's pie, but was amazing. It was savory, filling, and had a nearly perfect balance of flavors. The only thing I would say is that there was a tad too much bechamel sauce on top for me that caused it to be a bit heavy. The Falafel Bowl was a perfect, lighter dish that paired nicely with the heavier Vegetable Moussaka dish. The falafels were well done, not over cooked and the pita was good. I would have liked more tomatoes, as we got about 2 in the salad. 

I would definitely return...Maybe for lunch to try the wraps that they don't have at dinner or for brunch to try the Shakshuka!
author: April L.

description:
I love this spot for a quick and filling meal. The lamb shoulder pita is to die for! I am continuously craving it!

The chicken wrap is also a great lunch. Portions are also pretty good for the price!
author: Hanna S.

description:
That was my lunch . 30$ . The lamb was chooi with mellow taste , I was disappointed from the food , service was nice but other than that the food very mediocare - price way too high for the product.
The design is nice , the atmosphere is nice but food was not good .
author: Zohar I.

description:
On 4/22/2018 after the Cherry Blossom Festival was ended, me and my friends, Logan T & Grace were visited to this local Mediterranean Turkish restaurant located at Fillmore Street strip. It's called, "Troya." Troya serves the customers to taste their authentic and dazzling Mediterranean cuisines especially traditional Turkish dishes every 365 days a year! The atmosphere is very laid back and elegant as I welcomed there. The concept is much like visiting to your local Mediterranean restaurants, yet it's pretty modern and home-living feel filled with contemporary designs and furnitures across the whole interior room.

The employees here from servers and cookers here are doing an excellent job for making the customers like me a remarkable, friendly service! No cons!

Now onto the food! Since it was dinner time already, I ordered right directly from the menu. It's called, "Harissa Spiced Meatballs." It contains 4 meatballs with a side of seasoned basmati rice, mixed greens with dippables: Harissa and plain yogurt. As I ate it, that dish tasted wonderfully spectacular! I did felt the authentic flavors of both rice and the meatballs because of the natural spices and seasonings after cooked! The meatball weren't that dried which I did bite it for the first time. I wish the meatballs should cooked a little soft, but for me, it doesn't matter after all. I really loved the idea that you can dip the meatballs into any 2 dips, and it worked very well! The side of mixed green salad also tasted very good too thanks to the arrays of rinsed vegetables from lettuce (both red and green) to cherry tomatoes. What a way to complete my day during the night!

Parking at Troya can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

To conclude, Troya is the most incredible and outstanding local Mediterranean Turkish restaurant that I've ever discovered and visited for the very first time! Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gathering! A well received! My rating: 5 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: I was eager to try Troya because of all the veggie options their menu had. I love the neighborhood it's in, but was disappointed by the restaurant itself. I started with the spiced brussels sprouts ($9), as that's what brought me to the restaurant to begin with. They were way too fried and almost completely tasteless. I found myself salting them, and you know when you're salting restaurant food you have a problem. I also ordered the roasted cauliflower ($14) as well, which was phenomenal. The portion size was huge and I loved the flavors. I wish I had skipped the brussels and ordered something else instead!
author: Kirsten H.

description:
Really nice people, really hit or miss food/drink

Coffee was thin and burnt
Brussel sprouts covered in oil and powder. Disappointing.
Lamb meatballs super tasty but burnt
Tasty rice, but tiny portion for an entree 

Hope they dial it in because it's a really cute place with nice staff.
author: J L.

description:
This is a great neighborhood restaurant with fantastic service, nice decor and good food. 

I liked the decor a lot. Nice open look and very warm and inviting. They have beer on tap and wine as well. I sat at the bar since I was there by myself...hey, I see your judging face. How can you expect others to like your company if you yourself don't? Try it once in a while.

I ordered the manti based on the recommendation from the waiter. Very nice presentation and it tasted yummy. Very flavorful and light. Not sure which came first but it reminded me of an Afghan dish called mantoo which is very similar.  

The waiters were all super cool. They all seemed very relaxed and friendly as I observed them talking to the patrons. I ended up having a conversation with a couple of them about restaurants in the area. It was like talking to friends and it was genuine interest and conversation since I had already paid the bill by that time. I am a fan!
author: Sunil R.

description:
3.25/5
Wanted to come here after seeing a photo of Lahmajun on Yelp so came with a friend for a weekday lunch. Place was pretty empty. Love how open the restaurant space feels. Parking in the area wasn't too bad though we had to pay the meter. While the photos looked really interesting their weekday lunch menu had very few items I found unique. We ended up getting the following:

1) Crispy Brussel Sprouts: Highly recommended by the server and they were good (though a bit pricey at $8 for a small bowl). Light and crispy. Slightly burnt bits complimented the soft full pieces. Nice slightly spicy aioli but also nothing I haven't gotten at a semi nice American place. (3.5/5)

2) Turkish Spiced Fries: Mainly got these for my friend who has a fry addiction. Good spices on an average thin cut fry with some solid aioli. Once again fine, just nothing special (3.25/5)

3) Lamb Shoulder: Well seasoned lamb meat w/ some flavorful rice and a side of salad. Not a ton of food for $16 since most of the plate is salad. Besides the presentation it's basically good street car food at a higher pricepoint (3.5/5)

Overall Troya is a decent restaurant. Nothing is super unique in terms of menu options or flavors but they do what they do well. However, a lot of the price seems to just come down to presentation and atmosphere.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Had dinner here this past week with some coworkers who had never been to Troya before and were excited to eat Turkish/Mediterranean food. I was surprised to see the place so packed on a Tuesday night, which means they must be doing just fine...props to them! 

I'm sure it was because they were slammed but, the service was exceptionally slow and we had to get menus for ourselves and flag down the server to get attention. No matter because the kabobs were all delicious and the trio of apps were also a nice touch. I wasn't a huge fan of the brussel sprouts but, everything else was yummy. 

I think they realized how slow things were going because they brought out a complimentary dessert at the end of the meal which is always a classy move. 

Great spot for some casual kabobs and a great option for take away.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
If you're in Pac Heights looking for a delicious lunch or dinner spot, I would definitely check out this Turkish delight.

Troya serves up creative, reasonably priced Mediterranean food in a comfortable, biz-caz setting. My co-workers and I came here recently for a team dinner and took over their communal table.

Here's what I really liked and would recommend:
- an eclectic selection of Starters (you can easily make a meal out of sharing three or four of them). My favorites included: the Trio of Dips (Hummus, Tzatziki & Muhamara) served with the freshest pita bread this side of the Adriatic; the Turkish Spiced Fries; and the Red Lentil Soup.
- If you're crazy about kebabs like me, be sure to order the salmon and lamb kebabs. They come with basmati rice (topped with a tangy/garlic sauce), greens, herb yogurt, and harissa. If you're dining with friends, I'd recommend sharing ordering one of each kebab (lamb, salmon, and chicken).
- Make sure to order extra hummus and pita bread (trust me, this stuff is addictive).
- Plenty of veggie options if you have vegetarian friends in your dinner party.

Here's what what wasn't so great:
- the service (while friendly) was super SLOW on the night we dined. It took us 10-15 minutes to even get menus or put in our drink order. And after we received our starters, there was like a 30 minute gap between us getting our main course. It felt like they were disorganized or short-staffed.
- the Crispy Brussels Sprouts were dry and lacking in flavor. Not even the aleppo aioli which they came with could save this dish.
- this place is beer/wine only... so if you want a cocktail, I'd recommend stopping by Elite Cafe or Palmer's beforehand.

All in all, I really enjoyed my meal here. It's certainly a reasonably priced lunch/dinner option for groups. Plus, it's fun to walk around Fillmore Street before and/or after your meal. The neighborhood is looking really good these days.
author: Kevin B.

description: All I have to say is this is one of the best restaurants I've been to in SF. Beautiful interior, fantastic food, and great service.
author: Cecilia C.

description: Came here with a friend around lunch time on a Wednesday. We both decided to get the Chicken Kebab. The chicken was well cooked and tasted good. Only downside was the wait was very long even though there were empty tables. Would definitely come here again!
author: Sonali G.

description: Been here for lunch and dinner. For lunch, we ordered and paid at the counter and they brought our food out to us. We had the falafel bowl and the lamb wrap. Both were great. The falafel bowl comes with some falafel balls over hummus and is served with the flatbread and a salad with avocado. The lamb wrap was good and is filled with fresh cucumber. Also the tzatziki sauce is yummy.  This most recent time, we came for dinner. It was sit-down and there was waiter service. We had the hummus with spiced lamb. And split the free range roasted chicken leg. The chicken dish comes with two quarter legs of a chicken, a small salad and your choice of rice or fries. It's enough food for two people. Good Mediterranean flavors. Service was average.
author: Alison W.

description: Came here for my 2nd time and it was awesome again! Got the olives for an app and the chicken kebab which was super flavorful. Highly recommend trying an appetizer of theirs and you can't really go wrong with any main dish.
author: Drew F.

description:
Despite decent reviews our meal here today was a fail. 

The atmosphere was nice if quite chilly. It was low 50s out and they had the door wide open. Brr. 

My wife ordered the red lentil soup. It was puréed and had chili oil and some herbs on top. It was the only good part of the meal. 

My wife ordered the falafel wrap. The wrap choice was pita or tortilla (no lovash?). She selected tortilla. What arrived was a bowl not a wrap and with pita not tortilla. I ordered veg and halumi cheese skewers. I asked if they could leave the cheese out but apparently the skewers are premade. It was supposed to come with salad and rice. It came with salad and some sad looking quinoa. When I inquired about rice the waitress said the vegetables are served with quinoa. The menu says nothing about this but she offered to bring rice while correcting my spouse's order. 

The rice was ok. The quinoa was awful and I generally like quinoa. The vegetables were pretty sad - not much flavor, not very evenly cooked and the big shame was lousy eggplant. 

The falafel wrap was really bad and my wife barely ate it. The falafel was cold as if it just came out of the frig. 

All in all this was a big waste of $38.
author: Marco M.

description:
My new favorite place in all of San Francisco. 

The way to get served is exactly what I'd wanted in this neighborhood. Far too often I am confronted with the decision of going to a hole-in-the-wall Mediterranean place where I'd prefer ordering takeout or have to go to one of those overly fancy establishments that cost a lot more $$$ than I'd prefer dishing out. Troya is a godsend in this regard - using the classic 'order at counter, take your table sign number' method after paying at the register. Quick, easy way to get your food.

The food couldn't have been any better. The braised lamb was so soft and tender, as if they've been braising the meat for years. The hummus is punchy, fresh, flavorful. The falafel tastes wholesomely homemade. And last but not least, the kunefe was a masterpiece. Ever since visiting Turkey, I have yet to find a restaurant that executed this dessert authentically, and I may just have found hope in Troya.
author: David Y.

description:
I have only been to Troya for lunch and it's one of my favorite places to go on Fillmore! They have an awesome lunch menu with many healthy option. Everything is in the $10-17 range for large portions of food. 

You can get kebab plates with rice as well as lamb shoulder and chicken plates that come with salad, rice, and pita. 

I got the lamb shoulder plate and it was delicious. The lamb was perfectly-cooked, shredded and very very tender. Not to mention they put some kind of creamy, spicy sauce on the rice that blew my mind! 

If you're in Pac Heights or Marina for lunch and craving Greek food, consider this your new go-to.
author: Liz S.

description: Was around the neighborhood with my boufriend and saw very good reviews on yelp! I decided to make a reservation through yelp and go try it. It is located in a very nice neighborhood and theres  plenty meeter parking spaces. The inside is very open and welcoming environment.  Service was great! Very attentive, consistent check inns and refills. Food flavor was delicious! The portion sizes where fair, both my boyfriend and I think it could be a bit more. But the quality was excellent! Will definitely recommend.
author: Natalia F.

description: Came here on a beautiful Saturday. I ordered the Hummus combination and lamb wrap. My girlfriend ordered the Greek omelet. All around good good and relaxed vibe. Definitely would recommend for a bite!
author: Scott R.

description: Very nice restaurant. The service was excellent. It is Turkish food and very flavorful with some unique spices and herbs. The pita bread it is very fresh. They have a unique dish of meat-filled dumplings and yogurt sauce which is very tasty. The atmosphere is informal but very pleasant.
author: Mickey C.

description:
This restaurant has the best chicken salad in the city, their staff are super nice and I love their decor.
For some reason is not so crowded but I really appreciate that since I'm not up for waiting in line.
author: Gabriela B.

description: Wonder if it could actually be possible to spend less money on decor?  Filled with 20- and 30-somethings who are perfectly happy to pay $80 per person for 10 bites of food, while they stand in a room that looks like it's half garage and damaged items that came from the back of Pier One -- after having been stored there (and moved around a lot) for 10 years  What passes for a restaurant here (I was born and raised here, btw) is appalling. No ambience. No joy.  Food is passable, highly "indifferent" sevice -- because the clientele is more focused on the phones then what they're putting in their mouths or interacting with those they are eating with.
author: L M.

description:
Loved the delicious entrees here
Would recommend getting a reservation here ahead of time though!
author: Herb Q.

description: Great food! Nice ambience and the service was fantastic!! For sure I'll be back!
author: Peter Paul L.

description:
Have come here for lunch and dinner. For lunch, you have to order at the cashier area and for dinner, they have table service.

Both times I have had amazing experience here. First time I had the vegetarian tangine and second time I had their vegetarian salad for lunch. 

Also, I have tried their red pepper dip with pita bread. Everything was super delicious making the experience memorable!

I really like that they Mediterranean food which is unique like tangine, moussaka, others which gives this restaurant an edge over others.

We were debating between a grilled chicken dish and moussaka and really liked how the person who took our order he said that you would get grilled chicken anywhere but moussaka and other dishes are unique to a Mediterranean restaurant. Amazing customer service!
author: Surbhi K.

description:
We had the lamb kebab and the chicken kebab, both were pretty good! Quite flavorful, served with rice and reasonable portion sizes. I really loved the ambiance of the restaurant. My husband and I went here for date night and I really liked this restaurant for such an occasion. Casual and trendy, I would say. 

I do have to say that the service was mediocre, the waitress wasn't in a very good mood. Also the bathroom was a mess and the toilet was broken.
author: Neha S.

description: Loved this quaint restaurant in the Filmore! The crispy brussel sprouts were so delicious! Perfectly seasoned & crunchy and paired with a yummy aioli. If you love lamb, get the honey & cinnamon lamb shoulder. It tastes like a Greek version of Mexican birria. Will definitely come again!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Great Mediterranean place in Pac. Heights. Quiet and casual - great place for a date or a nice night out. We ordered the fried cauliflower as an appetizer and it was delicious - it came with a mayonnaise sauce and spring onions that really enhanced the taste of the vegetable. For the entree, I got the chicken kebab - it comes two skewer sticks with 8 pieces of chicken mixed with veggies. It also has a side of basmati rice that was delicious. 
 
Another fantastic thing about this place was the service -- the host actually helped us shift tables because I was uncomfortable in the high chair halfway through our meal. Really nice touch.

Overall, I love this place. The food was delicious, the service was excellent, and the ambience was great. Highly recommended.
author: Aditya V.

description: Had the chicken salad for lunch.  Fresh, great dressing and perfectly seasoned chicken.  The only downside was the music was too loud.
author: L J.

description: This place is a gem in the heart of the Pacific Heights neighborhood. Not only is the food fantastic, the staff delightful and the ambiance perfect for a date night or a group setting, the owner is incredibly passionate about what he does and a pleasure to speak to. Would highly recommend Troya - it's our new favorite place in the neighborhood!
author: Mohamed E.

description:
We have ordered from Troya a number of times in the past- usually a chicken wrap and/or falafel wrap. Today we opted for two chicken wraps, recalling how delicious, heavy, and filling they are. Because we often run out of the yogurt sauce that comes with the order, I ordered extra sauce with each wrap. 
Our order arrived as scheduled, but the wraps we received were barely filled with fatty chicken (I even found bone in one bite) and minimal veggies. Very very different from our past orders. To top it all off, we were charged for extra sauce that never arrived. Worst delivery from this restaurant to date.
author: Roma R.

description: Very good food and wine, nice service too. Good thing we made a reservation, because the place was packed (it's so popular). All the 5 of us enjoyed the meal very much!
author: Sofya N.

description: I was expecting good but basic. The chicken kebabs were anything but boring. Moist, tender and delicious. The best part are the sauces. I'll be back for sure!
author: S T.

description: We brought a party of 14 on a week night. Since the place was not busy we were able to be served without problems. I like the accessible location. The prices are reasonable for SFO at about $18 per dish. The wine selections are adequate. We started with the pita bread and dips: red pepper walnut and yogurt hummus. Everyone seemed to like all 3. For entrees it was a mixed bag. Many of us had the chicken kabab -greek yogurt marinated free range chicken breast with cherry tomatoes, onions and the lamb kebab - marinated lamb leg with cherry tomatoes, onions and bell pepper. Mine was very tasty. The lamb chops came up short as they were very thin and bony. The harissa spiced meatballs have an distinctive taste, so if you're looking for traditional meatballs, these are them.
author: Scott B.

description: I had the unexpected pleasure of trying Troya for the first time when they accidentally delivered a catering order two weeks early. The food was delicious, especially the falafel wraps and the lamb. Very fresh, authentic, and flavorful cuisine. If their catering is this good, I can't wait to try their restaurant in person!
author: Gem L.

description:
Wonderful and delectable. Warm, hearty food, pleasant and airy space bordering casual, conversation friendly, music jives, choice beers on tap and selective wines, spacious tables, feels neighborhoody, and not a scene. 

Lovely for longer lunches in the afternoons.
author: Juls C.

description: My favorite place in san francisco. İf you want to eat Mediterranean food , Troya is perfect
author: Kasım I.

description: Very friendly & attentive staff for dinner.  Very good chicken kabab & fried brussel sprouts.  Loved the Harissa, spicy & flavorful.  Lots of other items I would like to try in the future.  Good solid Mediterranean food here.  Nice setting.  Definitely worth a visit.
author: Steven B.

description: Food was decent, too expensive for the portions and there were a lot of flies flying around. Chicken plate was good but not the best.
author: Kristle I.

description:
SO. GOOD. 
I came in a group of 4 and we ordered a bunch of different appetizers and desserts to share. Favorites were the Turkish dips, cabbage stuffed with lamb (it was a special), and watermelon salad. Everything was seriously amazing. Each item I tried was fresh and delicious, plus our server was awesome. I will come back here every time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Liz Z.

description:
I was a regular customer (2nd visit in 3 days) but not after tonight.  Very disappointed.  GF and I walked out tonight due to bad service.   After we sat down, a large party(10) arrived.  We had been waiting for an extended period of time for our waitress to take our order. She decided to take the larger group order first instead of ours. I asked her why she wasn't taking our order first and she said would get to us after taking their order and we should just wait.  We decided to walk out.  As we were leaving, She also told me she didn't care if we didn't want to come back.  Well I will not be coming back. 
This is my first review on yelp because I feel I needed to share my experience.
author: Matt A.

description:
My spouse and I had lunch here today and except for the lentil soup, the food was horrible.   

My spouse ordered the vegetable kabobs and asked if it could be made vegan (sans cheese). They said no because the skewers were already made up.  Really.  How hard can it be to cut up or re-skewer some veggies.  There was only 1 other diner in the whole place so they were not busy.  And it made no sense on their part money-wise because cheese is more expensive than peppers.  

For $17, we expected those veggies to be beautifully seasoned and grilled.  They weren't.  The eggplant was raw and rubbery.  Any Middle Eastern restaurant that cannot cook eggplant should immediately close its doors in great shame. 

Said kabobs were supposed to be served with rice.  They arrived with a tasteless glob of quinoa. When my spouse asked about it, the waitress said the veggie kabobs were served with quinoa. Funny, we both heard her saying it came with rice when she took our order and the menu also said it came with rice. 

I ordered a falafel wrap but got a bowl.   It was hard to understand how they screwed up both our orders.  They corrected it but the falafel was cold and they put a shit-load of hot sauce in there without asking me for my preference.

When the waitress came to clear the table, she noticed that I left 90% of my falafel.  She asked if everything was OK but did not wait for my answer before asking if I wanted to take my leftovers home.  I said no, thank you.  She asked again if I wanted to take my leftovers. I again said no thank you. You'd think that would trigger a why.  The apparent manager also noted my uneaten falafel and also didn't ask if it was satisfactory.  

I wouldn't go back to this place they offered me free lunch for a month.
author: Hadas R.

description: Decent food. Dunya is more flavorful and affordable but Troya was okay as well. We ordered 2 types of dips and a veg kebab. The kebab was good
author: Vidushi S.

description: I had the baby lamb chops. When it arrived, I was disappointed just by looking at it. It literally was three lamb chops sitting a top a small bed of hummus and potatoes. That's it. No rice, no vegetables, nothing else that a plate of lamb chops would usually come with at a turkish restaurant. So, it definitely wasn't filling, but it was tasty. So, deducting stars/points for value. A meal should always at a bare minimum at least fill you. The place was family-friendly, not super cute or anything. A little pricey for what I got.
author: Marie D.

description:
Yum! Came here with two friends yesterday. We got the red pepper dip and the hummus for appetizers. While the hummus was good, the red pepper dip was amazing -- would definitely recommend!

I asked the server for a vegan recommendation and unfortunately none of the "large plate" entrees are vegan! That was surprising to me, because Turkish cuisine really lends itself to vegan dishes. The options for me were:

Large plate menu:
* veggie kabobs no cheese

Small plate menu:
* roasted brussels 
* roasted cauliflower
* lentil soup

The vegetable tagine sounds perfectly vegan but is cooked in butter. Thank you, waitress, for pointing this out!

I ended up getting the roasted cauliflower and the lentil soup and it was a filling meal, especially on top of the appetizer dips.

My friends both got the vegetarian moussaka (they are vegetarians).

Would go here again but would love more vegan friendly entrees :-)
author: L F.

description:
Troya is one of our favorite restaurants in the city. My boyfriend and I lived a few blocks from this local spot for about a year and had to restrain ourselves from coming in every night! Eventually, we got to know the staff and owners, who are extremely kind and welcoming. They helped us celebrate birthdays, anniversaries, accomplishments, and even our recent move away from the city. We were so sad to leave this place that we saved it for our last dinner! That night they surprised us with a gift of a few of our favorite recipes and handwritten notes. It was magical. 

Tips:
- Get the brussel sprouts. Trust me. They're some of the best I've had.
- Ask for extra harissa sauce with whatever you get. They make it in-house and no other harissa I've had even compares.
- The Greek red wine blend is lovely
- The cinnamon braised lamb is probably one of my boyfriend's top 5 dishes of all time. It's tender and flavorful, but not too game-y or rich
- The red pepper muhamara (I know I butchered the spelling...) is the best appetizer dip by far.
- The chicken sqwers are always tenderly cooked and juicy
author: Morgan W.

description:
Loved this place, one of the best meals I've had in a LONGGGG time! 

The owner (?) was so accommodating and kind (guy with the manbun) 

Deff  go here  the kebabs were out of this world! The chicken one was stupidly good. 

Thanks guys!
author: Neil G.

description: We had bunch of stuff from the menu. The wines we're double the price and vegetarian dishes were not that good. I ordered one of the popular dishes baked dishes and it was average. I ordered vegetarian Moussaka and it was below average. Lentils were good but bechamel was too thick and potatoes were not completely cooked. Although my friends enjoyed the meat dishes. So I give it 3 stars.
author: Ankita J.

description: The food was pretty good. We got the appetizer dip sampler. We needed 2 small pieces of pita to finish it. The owner was nice enough to come by and brought over a couple pieces. He charged us $1 for this. I think in terms of customer service, it was the wrong decision to charge for this when we're already spending $70 here.
author: Ben W.

description: Wanted to try this place going by the stellar yelp reviews, but was let down. We ordered the hummus, walnut and red pepper dip, tzatziki, crispy Brussels sprouts and the vegetable tagine . Every single item was disappointing
author: Meenakshi K.

description:
Ended up here on a Sunday afternoon when all the prime brunch spots were rammed. The restaurant was pretty much completely empty when we got here which was a little concerning but the food was solid. 

I only ordered the crispy brussel sprouts appetizer. It came with an aioli for dipping which had a nice freshness to it. The dish itself was a decent size which could be shareable for 2. 

A bit slow for being the only table but the staff were lovely. Good place.
author: Emily L.

description: Nice Mediterranean place located in Pac Heights. The venue is quaint inside. Some of the plates are simple and balanced -- meat, rice and salad. Whereas some of the the dishes are elaborate -- meat dumplings with yogurt sauce. We got the lamb, salmon, meatballs and dumplings. The lamb was slightly dry, the salmon was good, meatballs were great, and we wished that the dumplings didn't have so much yogurt sauce.
author: Young Y.

description: I've lived in the neighborhood for nearly a year and finally got around to trying this place. I typically think Mediterranean food is a bit bland, but the dishes at Troya are amazing and in the 3 times I've been I don't think I've had one I didn't love. The cinnamon lamb, fried cauliflower and spiced fries are my favorites. The brussel sprouts and meat balls are a close second. They also have a great selection of local wine and beers on tap, and the price point for both drink and food portions is pretty good...you could easily make 2 meals out of some of the dishes.  Staff and manager are all very friendly and really bring joy to the experience. Will definitely be a regular here!
author: Kathryn P.

description: Food is delicious here! I had Turkish food from so many different  places and even in Istanbul. But this place is literally  one of the best turkish food I have ever had before. We had turkish scrambled eggs with pita bread, chicken and lamb kebab. We eat out almost every day and struggle of finding a good tasty food is a thing. But  I also want to try their chicken bowl and manti next time. We also got desert- kunefe and some turkish tea
author: Gunay S.

description: Love lamb. They have wrap w/ pita optional, bowl and kebab w/ rice. Taste awesome & staffs friendly :) just the seating can be more comfortable tho
author: Emerson H.

description: It was really good. I had the halloumi kebab and we had the pita & dips for a starter. Everything was really delicious and the service was great. On top of that I had the Turkish Cabernet Sauvignon that they had on glasses and it was surprisingly delicious - given I know nothing about Turkish wine.
author: Clovis S.

description: I lived in Turkey and Greece for a while and was excited to try this supposedly "Mediterranean" place with my wife. The service was very friendly. However I can't say the same about the food. The isn't anything close to Turkish or Greek food.
author: Sam B.

description:
Completely marginal. Really unremarkable to plain bad. Meatball things were completely dried-out little pucks and lamb was over cooked and bland. 

Pass pass pass.
author: Steven G.

description: we had a table of four and ordered 1 bottle of turkish wine, 3 entrees and 4 appetizers and they were plenty! wine was smooth and tasted much like a pinot noir. food was on par and everything tasted great.  service was exceptional, our waitress kept on checking on us.  overall great experience! we were there on a Sat. night and got there at 6, no wait.  right around 730 a short line started to queue up.
author: Lian F.

description:
Came here for the first time for an event.  I live about 10 min away but usually avoid restaurants on Fillmore Street due to the commercialization and mediocre reviews.

The food was so yummy! The falafels were warm and oh so good.  The owner said the bread crumbs are made from scratch -- they were the best falafels I've ever had (and I've had Mamoun's in Manhattan).

The staff and owners were so kind and in a good mood even though the event was big and probably overwhelming. The owners are originally from Turkey.  I chatted with the wife a bit and she originally came to the US 2 years ago to learn English -- her English is great! Her husband was so nice and hospitable too.  

Would definitely come back and recommend to all my friends who are looking for delicious Mediterranean food.
author: Siv L.

description: Surprised I haven't found this place sooner, beautiful place and definitely hit the spot! Left feeling pretty satisfied! Meals are all light too. Definitely recommend
author: Lauren K.

description:
I wouldn't bother coming back it was so average at best. 

The Brussels sprouts were admittedly tasty. But the rest was kind of meh. Falafel was competent but should have been exceptional for the price paid. They kept bringing us other people's food which just made a weird impression on top of a mediocre one.
author: Tim P.

description: Been coming here a lot lately, mostly for lunch. The halloumi kebabs are fabulous and the manti are extremely tasty. Nice location, usually zero to minimal wait which is a big plus. Also handy that there's usually a sporting event up on the TV!
author: Bo M.

description:
3.5 stars

I walked into Troya thinking that this place is overpriced for Mediterranean food. 

I'm right about the prices and while La Mediterranee is only a half block away, the food here tastes fresher. (La Med def microwaves their pita!) 

We chose Troya mainly for the space: my niece's stroller fits nicely in the corner on one of their communal tables. (YAY for SF restaurants with space!)

Troya's new concept of a fast, casual lunch service suits the Fillmore weekend crowd better. You can order at the counter, utensils are at the table already and food is delivered to you. We shared several apps which were all outstanding: Turkish red lentil soup, crispy brussel sprouts with aleppo aioli, roasted cauliflower and Turkish fries. I had a falafel bowl and the others had a wrap or grilled kebabs. Overall, the lunch was very satisfactory, the only drawback is the cost.
author: Janice C.

description:
This place is one of the best Mediterranean kitchen in San Francisco .
All Kebabs are amazing which comes with right size of salad and rice , not too oily and perfectly cooked. 
There is a lot of vegetarian options. My favorite was vegetable tagine and roasted cauliflower which so flavorful. 
All staff were nice and hospitable .
Definitely come back to Troya again
author: Begaiym S.

description: This place is overpriced and overrated. Been here for dinner and brunch now, and each time they manage to disappoint. The description of the food on the menu sounds very appetizing, but when the food comes out (which at dinner took over 30 minutes at a not crowded restaurant, with no apology or acknowledgement), the potions are on the small side and the food is extremely underwhelming. During brunch, I ordered the turkish scramble which sounded so flavorful and unique, when in actuality it was a bowl of average scrambled egg and very few vegetables, and no taste other than egg. It was served with 4 tiny triangular pieces of pita, and nothing on the side. Bland and boring. Will not return.
author: Adi F.

description: This is our favorite neighborhood resturaunt. It's consistently excellent food in a great location with the most thoughtful and friendly staff. Would give it 10 stars if I could!
author: Bahar M.

description: Went here with Jimbo. Amazing food. Wayyy too expensive and simply for that reason would not go back.
author: Cherry J.

description: Great restaurant. We enjoyed the food and the felt very welcomed. I highly recommend when you are vising San Francisco.
author: Adam E.

description: Consistently great food, and friendly people who work here. The atmosphere is relaxing too, nice music, lighting, seating.
author: Sheri Z.

description:
We were looking for some restaurant in San Francisco to get our lunch on Saturday. I've found Troya over the Yelp, so decided to try it out.
We came in, one of the staff member stoped by and let us know, that we can choose any table and we need to order from cash register. Prices are reasonable, variety is pretty good - wraps, salads, soups, kebabs, bowls, desserts and drinks. Spot is good for both - meat lovers and vegetarians. We ordered food from cashier and in few minutes our order was ready and brought to our table.
My husband ordered lamb kebab, I don't eat meat, so went with red lentils soup. I am also coffee lover, so ordered Turkish coffee, which was really delicious. Kebab comes with rice, small salad and sauce on a side. My husband said that lamb was really good - juicy, soft, perfectly cooked. My soup also tasted delicious. 
We also tried baklava - it was one of the best I've ever tried! Soft and filled in with honey very well.
Interior is nice - cozy, clean, looking good place, I want to come back next time! 
Staff is friendly and helpful! 
Thank you Troya! We will come back!
author: Mariia N.

description: Great food, service and location. We make a reservation an hour before arriving at 7pm on a Friday. Comfortably crowded! We did shared appetizers and mains. Will be back again
author: Lisa K.

description: Food was tasty. The cauliflower, Brussels sprouts and watermelon salad was on point. Good sized portions too! The lamb shoulder was good and the mixing of the whole bowl was delish!
author: Melinda L.

description: This was the best meal I have had in San Francisco in 27 years I have lived here.  It was simple, flavorful, healthy, and it was ample.  I have food allergies, and none of them were in this dish.  It was the lamb shoulder, shredded meat, done in a very nice flavorful but not too intense, just right, sauce.  The rices was again just the right flavor, not too intense, in another well done sauce on top and cooked in some way to make the rice itself just right.  Wow!  And I loved the greens, no heavy oil on it, with tomatoes.  Just right!  The best meal done just right that I have had in San Francisco ever, even when I came here as a tourist in the decade before I moved here!  I prefer a service that is not hurried, and the tables are big enough to work at and with others while you eat.  The huge low-rise bowls they use are perfect, too.  I will be back!!! and with friends!!!!
author: Janet C.

description: What it lacks in ambience it makes up for in service and food. The hummus with shredded lamb is delicious as are the Brussel sprouts.  My favorite item to order is the tiny manti (dumplings).
author: Ally G.

description:
I was walking through the neighborhood a few Sundays ago getting my coffee from the Peet's at the corner, when this place caught my interest. The place is in the heart of one of my favorite neighborhoods in the city, and on a beautiful sunny day? Fresh Greek food felt appropriate for the occasion. I tried their avocado toast, which consists of a sesame type of sliced bread, Greek yogurt, slices of avocado, sliced hard boiled egg, sliced cucumbers and radish. I can't tell you enough how delicious this was!!! Having said that, I returned again this past Sunday. This time I tried their  
honey and cinnamon braised lamb bowl. The combination of flavors was so delicious, I wanted more even after I was already full!! Their service is very welcoming and it feels like you are a guest in their home!! Absolutely love this little gem! Fresh and flavorful food, and hospitable service!!!
author: Celia V.

description: Nice space.  The waitstaff were pleasant and earnest.  We started off with a crisp bottle of assyrtiko.    The Brussel sprouts and falafel salads were very good.   The main courses of chicken and lamb kebabs were very good.  We had two issues with the service.   My wife and daughter both ordered the chicken kebabs.  When my daughter said "I'll have the same thing," it was somehow heard as "I'll have the salmon."   So she got the wrong entree. That was fixed gracefully.  More annoyingly, the main courses were served before we were done with our appetizers.  This is a pet peeve of mine and cost Troya a star.  We still had a good meal and would give them another shot.
author: Joel S.

description:
I love Turkish food and Troya does NOT disappoint!  We started with the watermelon salad; watermelon, mint, fennel, feta and arugula.  Absolutely refreshing salad!  Then we had the Turkish dips with pita bread.  We couldn't get enough!  Finally, I had the honey and cinnamon infused lamb shoulder.  Delicious!

For dessert, we had Kunefe which is one of my favorite Turkish desserts!  Fantastic!  I doubt you'll find better Turkish food in SF!
author: Steve H.

description: I was pleasantly surprised when coming here for a late dinner. The food was very tasty, size was just right and the price was very fair.
author: Ilya K.

description:
The food at Troya is 5 stars, the ambiance maybe 4. A friend and I split the pita bread and two dips: red pepper walnut and yogurt. I couldn't get enough of both of them and the bread was amazing as well. I had the braised lamb shoulder as a main course and it was a generous amount of food for 16 dollars. The rice was fluffy and flavorful, salad was good too. The lamb was the star. Braised and slightly shredded, incredibly tender and well flavored. It paired really well both with the sauce that came with the meal and the leftover yogurt and walnuts dips from our appetizers. 

The only reason I'd say the space was 4 stars was that it was kind of warm and stuffy. At 7 on a weekday, it was mostly empty but definitely filled up as we were leaving later in the evening. A great spot for amazing Mediterranean food.
author: Annie M.

description:
Wow, what a wonderful surprise in both food & service.  Every person in my party of six loved the exquisite, unique taste of the roasted cauliflower.   Also the Brussels Sprouts starter and puréed lentil soup were excellent as well.   Our entrees included moussaka, chicken kabobs, and Turkish beef dumplings which were all very good.  The surprising standout entree was the Vegetable Tangine, a complex mix of flavors with numerous perfectly cooked vegetables in an amazing sauce.  As a recent vegetarian convert, it was one of the most exciting dishes I've had in a long time.  And the non-vegetarian who ordered it, also raved about the flavors.   
Middle Eastern & Mediterranean food is becoming too associated with cheap wraps and bowls of hummus.   Troya shows how wonderful the true breadth of Turkish cuisine can be.   Hope it achieves the customer base it deserves so we can come back.
author: James W.

description: Great restaurant with a jazzy ambiance, proper food (they brought sumac upon request) and great service! I wanted a half dish and they accommodated and it came at a treasonable price. A really nice place to catch up with friends, have a date, or just enjoy a tasty plate of food. Try the cauliflower--it's delicious.
author: Brian B.

description:
This review is for their food truck.  Their lamb is amazing and is good enough to carry a 4-star review, even though their falafel bowl was quite a letdown (maybe 2.5 stars).  So be careful what you order.  Kinda makes me want to check out their restaurant and pig out on lamb.  So tasty.

Braised Lamb Wrap: One of the best wraps I've had in San Francisco.  It appears that the lamb is slow braised to make it tender, but then grilled/griddled to give it a bit of crunch.  Seriously better than that mass produced gyro meat others tend to sling.  The wrap bread was fresh and tender (albeit a bit too bready by the ends).  Loved the spicy/creamy sauce.  Just the right amount of veggies without being overwhelming.  But wow, I still keep thinking about that lamb meat though, so good!

Falafel Bowl: A bit disappointing.  The outer edges of the falafel were a bit soft instead of that just out of the fryer crunch.  Also, the inner texture/taste wasn't that memorable.  And it was a bit annoying that there was no rice in the falafel bowl (unlike the chicken or lamb bowls), so it felt like a really unsatisfying salad.
author: Adam B.

description:
Restaurant is casual, simple place...I'd say lunch worthy.

 The meats tasty . ..sauce/dip is spot on...ordered the lamb rice bowl and a salmon skewer side. Good piece of fish, but would have preferred not cooked so much. Overall good, but pricey meal.

 Perfect for lunch.
author: Sharine d.

description:
I travel to Turkey every 1-2 years and love the cuisine there. Have to say, Troya has very authentic turkish food while still providing a lot of Mediterranean-inspired options for those are less adventurous with their taste.

Loved the lentil soup to start. The falafel dish is perfectly prepared. The kebab dishes are also very authentic and remind me of what they serve in Istanbul. 

Also - my girlfriend left her sunglasses here. The staff here found it and locked it up in a safe and we were able to get them back the following week when we decided to look for the glasses there. Felt like I had to credit the ownership/staff for their act of kindness in addition to great food!
author: J. K.

description: Unfriendly service and TWO hairs found in my takeout food.  Wasn't going to write this until a woman just rudely asked me to leave their outside table, where I was just sitting for a few mins, unless I bought something. STAY AWAY!
author: Brooks W.

description:
I have not bought a Groupon in a while. I have been to the Troya up on Clement, and Meh...(now closed) But I had heard this one was better.

We had 3 small plates and a lamb flatbread. Small plates were scallops, the platter of lamb bacon, figs, hummus and pita and the Hallumi cheese and peach salad. There was plenty of food. The Lamb bacon was great, loved the scallops and the peach salad was a nice light touch.  

Our server Veronica was a doll and the food was well paced. There are plenty of other things I would like to try - the cauliflower, the brussels sprouts, the kebob.  It was a great deal on a Groupon, and glad I finally hit this spot.
author: Amy W.

description: Food has really gone downhill. Falafel wrap was weird and gross. It also took forever and was expensive. Hard pass.
author: Lily L.

description: Exceptional service. This is my first time here and the food is great. I ordered the chicken leg bowl and Turkish fries and I loved both. The girl who took my order was absolute sweetheart. She asked me if I was from the area and I told her, I work close by and she said you get a discount. How nice of her. I will definitely be back here more often
author: Shanzay H.

description:
My husband and I made a reservation at Troya for a casual 'rehearsal dinner' with our families the evening before got married at City Hall. We made a reservation pretty far in advance, and chose Troya because it was close to our hotel, and because we'd eaten here before and the food is delicious. They very graciously prepared a set menu for our large group, and the food was all very good. Troya has a fantastic beer menu too, so that was also fun.

A couple things were a bit off, so we're docking one star for the following issues: 

- Our reservation was for 13 people + one two year old, meaning we needed 13 chairs and one high chair. When we arrived, we had a table set up for 12 people and no high chair. They brought over a high chair, but we were sitting at a high top table, and the high chair was not tall enough for it. One member of our party was not able to make it, and the two year old was able to sit in his stroller, so it all worked out. Not sure what we would have done if we'd had 13 adults though. 
- Once everyone arrived, the waiters brought out our delicious appetizers but didn't stop to take drink orders. We had to aggressively flag someone down in the middle of appetizers to get our drink order taken. 

Overall though, the service and food were great. We didn't feel rushed at all, and all the food was super delicious.
author: Anne W.

description: All of the food I've tried here has been really good and fairly healthy. A great stop on Fillmore for some reasonably priced, good mediterranean food.
author: Lauren A.

description: Great lentil soup, a manti that is as homemade as you can get in a restaurant and a kunefe that could launch a thousand ships. This was very high quality and very authentic.  This is the way it should be. Troya SF gets it right!!
author: Emin S.

description: They've done a great job remodeling and revamping the vibe here. It's got a cozy ambiance that's date and family friendly. The food is consistently flavorful and meat is always juicy and tender!
author: Ami Y.

description:
Lovely lunch. Modern decor. At lunch you order at counter and it's brought to your table. Looked like all locals. Ordered bowl of shredded lamb with salad, yogurt dip and rice. Delicious spices. My date ordered the meatballs with yogurt, also good. 
Will definitely return.
author: kathleen m.

description: Really great place for a meal before the movies. Place can get loud when full. Food is full of flavor and comes out fast. Service is great and everyone seems to pitch in when needed. Only thing is dinner for two was $95.00 with tip. We ordered two appetizers, one soda, one hot tea and two entries. Seems very pricy for dinner for two.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Lots of competition in the area and this place didn't really excite and it was pricey.

We stopped in for lunch on a Saturday during the Cherry Blossom Festival since we weren't in the mood for Japanese.

Ambiance was dark so it appeared closed even with the few patrons we saw at tables.  You order at the register and take a seat until your food is brought to you.

Decent kale salad with added grilled chicken.

Pretty good meatball (lamb?) over rice bowl with a small side salad and a thimble of yogurt.
author: Rick S.

description:
Amazing falafel bowl!definitely recommend
Friendly staff, everything is clean and modern
author: Helen M.

description:
The food was decent but the service is slooooooooow and inattentive. It's really only worth it if you have 3 hours with nothing to do and you'd like mid range Turkish food.
The waiters couldn't be bothered to find you or take your order. When you mentioned things were slow or served cold, they shrugged and said "so what". It's just too big of a city to put up with this.
author: Brian S.

description:
I went back to Troya for lunch with another Vegan friend knowing they could find something here.  As a non-vegan I ordered their lamb which the owner said was a house specialty.  We also had wine recommended to us by the owner.  

The lamb was amazing, it was so good I think I could eat it every day.  It was not a huge serving so I felt great after, it was so tender and flavorful, amazing!  My friend had a vegan wrap; the harrissa they use was so good and the falafel was so perfect my friend was convinced the dish had dairy and egg.  We also shared a dip platter which was perfect.  The wines were great and reasonably priced.  

LOVE this place!!!
author: Cari N.

description:
Mundane would describe the food well. The nice decor and overall cleanliness keep this out of 2 star territory. The steak was good but then again it's steak, just add salt and don't fk it up.

 Nothing stood out here or on any other table, except maybe the actual bar counter and wood backsplash on the wall. Not sure why we were asked if we wanted the bread before or at the same time as the meal...it was literally olive oil and bread...

Salmon kebab was supposed to be popular, tried a bit... this was also unspectacular.

Tldr; very boring place to spend $40-50 a head at
author: Garrett N.

description: Will never go here again. Ordered two wraps and it took 30 minutes to come out. Asked where our food was, no apology ... nothing. Food was fine but not great. Felt like it was something that could have been made at home.
author: Kristin K.

description: "Service" is terrible. One of those restaurants where from the moment you arrive they make you feel like even seating you was an inconvenience to them. And what makes it worse is the dynamic between the female servers and the male manager where anytime they ask him if they can do something which isn't standard he just dismissively shakes his head without answering in front of you with an attitude of how dare you ask?
author: James F.

description:
Lunch is over priced you have so pre tip for terrible service. Payed $47 for a single person at lunch. Asked for no rice, got regardless. Watched 10 people come in 4 left when they saw the prices. 

The "Kabab" is slow roast lamb shoulder which under seasoned but nice is not worth $18. I'm pretty sure they just put the lamb bowl on a bigger plate with rice. $10 Kunefe is share size. I've paid less in the city for better. Coffee is good but on chipped plates. 

Overall the take away is PAN-meditation = meh Turkish at double the price. A great introduction to Turkey with out any of those great flavours getting in the way of someone who is fearful of new flavours. If you don't know what it actually tastes like and can afford cost this is the place for you!

Also it you are too polite to complain please bring your best poker face. You won't be the only head shaking person walking away from the square machine in disbelief.
author: Alex C.

description: I live close by and as a result pop into Troya fairly frequently for fairly healthy dinner. Everything is super tasty, but the value for money is terrible. The portions are pretty small and the prices don't match . I wouldn't say the atmosphere is worth the price point either.
author: Shannon H.

description: Troya is a fast causal Mediterranean restaurant on Fillmore St. The space is very spacious, clean, and had a modern but rustic look. The staff was also very nice and friendly. I wish I could have better things to say about the food but unfortunately, I've experienced better. I ordered their Falafel bowl which came with 3 pieces of falafel, a side salad, hummus, and pita bread. The pita bread wasn't pita bread - it was like a very thin tortilla. The falafel was also dry. The food was average in my opinion. Didn't think the quality of the food was worth the price unfortunately.
author: Chisholm T.

description:
very disappointing. we used to enjoy this place for the odd special occasion dinner. when we recently returned, they'd made big changes. nice new tables, BUT: dinner has gone down the tubes and we won't be back: low quality food at high prices = lose, lose. 

more specifically, we tried a vegetable tagine - something we've enjoyed many times both out at restaurants and home cooked. it's a reliable, simple, lovely dish (hard to screw up), but we got a bowl of expensive potatoes with a pitiful few vegetables not worth half what we paid.
author: BayArea L.

description:
Food used to be much better here.

I had a lamb shoulder wrap and the quality of the meat was horrendous. It had huge chunks of fat and even pieces of bone.

The lentil soup was decent so that's the only reason I'm giving it 2 stars.
author: Paolo F.

description:
Meh meh. It was good, it was satisfying, but it wasn't memorable by any means.

We had a party of 3 on a Sunday. Started with the 3 dips - Hummus, Haydari, Muhammara. Pretty sure I've had better hummus from the grocery store. The 
Crispy Spiced Brussel Sprouts were only kinda crispy and not all that spiced - but hey, gotta eat your greens. The chicken kabobs were juicy but would I order it again? Nah. The hanger steak was cooked perfectly and this was probably my favorite dish. The lamb meatballs were a bit dry, but the flavor was there.
author: Stephany T.

description:
I went to Troya when it used to serve tapas a few years back. Was disappointed by the small portions and high prices.

So when they started advertising their 'new concept', I was skeptical, but decided to give them a try. 

OH BOY IS THEIR NEW MENU A SLAM DUNK!!! 

It's like Souvla meets Turkey. They offer bowls and wrap options with chicken, lamb, meatballs, or veggies. They also offer various kebabs!

The lamb shoulder just melts in your mouth, and the flavors are fantastic. The harissa sauce should be a national treasure, it's so delicious. The kebabs were so well cooked and yummy. 

We're SO happy that we gave Troya another chance!!
author: Ami Y.

description:
QMF: Quality Mediterranean Food. Spiced by the best spices the world can offer. Meat cuisines are well recommended for delightful lunch.
BTW - GREAT BAKLAVA !!
author: Or S.

description:
The inside of this restaurant is kinda gorgeous. It's next to the Marc Jacobs in the Fillmore so it's bouge-town.

Hummus/dip platter was to die for. Wine selection was okay. Lamb was a bit chewy and not the best. I would rate this 2.5 $$ as it was between moderate and expensive.
author: Chris L.

description: This place is a waste of time. The portions are tiny and the servers have an attitude. They keep it really warm in there, I had to step outside twice during the meal
author: Moe S.

description: The pita bread and the dips were one of the best I have had. We couldn't just stop having them.I would surely go back again.
author: Sriram S.

description:
A great neighborhood gem! 

The server was lovely and recommended the best wine I've had in ages (maybe ever!)

Ooooo that cauliflower dish is to die for!!! Simply the best dish we had by far! 

Calamari was excellent as well. 

Lamb bacon was an interesting try, although the plating was super weird/ ugly and the hummus was average. They need to rework this dish and it could be great. 

Lamb kebabs were excellently cooked. 

All in all a beautiful food experience!
author: Jen B.

description: Friendly service and excellent food. Try the beef dumplings...we get them each time without fail.
author: John W.

description:
Went to troya last night and it was quite the disappointment.

Firstly they have changed from table service to counter service and the prices have remained the same. So you are paying the same price for lesser service. 

We had: 

Dips combo - dips were great but Pita was dry. I remember the Pita at troya being the best in the city which added to my disappointment 

Lamb kebab: good portion average taste 

Falafel bowl: falafel was really dry and I had trouble swallowing it and it comes with Pita and salad which were both dry too, salad was too sour with the dressing. 

Troya please go back to being what you were. I don't like the new you.
author: Priyanka P.

description:
This was my first time at Troya and I had a great experience!

Our server was extremely friendly and helpful. She gave us great recommendations, was patient, and attentive. 

DRINKS:
We started off with a bottle of the Educated Guess Cab which was so so good. 

FOOD:
Roasted Cauliflower - yum 
Crispy Brussels Sprouts - a little too crispy for my taste
Lamb Meatballs - a bit on the dry side
Pita with 3 dips - necessary!
Lamb kebab - my favorite :)

Everything was so delicious and our server even gave us more pita once we finished our first round 

A little on the pricey side - everything is so good and semi small portions so the prices add up REAL quick.

so worth it though.
author: Ilana B.

description: Big fan of this redesign, from awkward to chill, and now good food on the quick. Lower price points, nice range of veggie options and their halloumi kebabs, oh my.  More of a gastropub med feel than a restaurant and that works for me. Good for healthy ish lunches, chill dates and lazy sundays.
author: Zara S.

description:
I feel like the connoisseur or the falafel- only because I ate them every day for lunch for a year from a takeaway stand in the section of Anaheim California where rent was cheap.

Troya has the best falafel in town! Light and crisp, so flavorful and fresh, the pita was thin and delicate. 
We also ordered a lamb wrap. The lamb was tender with a deep flavor that only slow cooking for hours could produce. This is a wonderful 'find' in a city where good food is greatly admired and sought after. 
Our hostess/waitperson was very helpful and the menu is small, she explained the menu and was helpful all the way around.
This is a casual place, order at the counter and they will bring the dish as prepared.
author: Kris I.

description:
Great restaurant with consistent delicious dishes. I've been here a couple times and was a little bummed the most recent time that there wasn't moussaka on the menu but everything else we had was still great. 

Most recently had the roasted cauliflower, dip trio and dumplings.  The cauliflower was roasted perfectly and had the most amazing sauce. 

For dessert we tried the Turkish pot de creme. Slightly thicker than I was expecting but good flavor, next time I definitely want to try the other desserts.
author: Daniela J.

description: Please note: this review is only for the last time I was there and for the worst owner/manager I've ever seen in my life. I've been to Troya many times and had wonderful meals in a lovely environment. However, I brought 3 out of town friends there this weekend and the experience sucked. First off, we had to order and pay at the counter in the late afternoon even though there were 3 people literally standing around. The meal itself was decent, though not up to par. But the piece de resistance was getting a last-minute bill on the table for $1.12 for 5 small extra pieces of pita. I am not making this up. My perplexed friend handed me the piece of paper. When I went to pay upfront I told the manager I was disappointed in this petty pita charge. Instead of employing good customer service tactics like making the customer feel better, he proceeded to tell me how he can't afford to give pita away and became extremely defensive. Then he had the nerve to ask me if I had a $1 instead of a $20 and he would not charge me the 12 cents -- I'm not making this up. He then proceeded to give me $19 in...wait for it...singles. I will not be spending one more $1 at this place. It's a loss but I don't want to support a place that forgoes good common customer service in favor of making a buck--literally.
author: Janice C.

description: I've been coming to this place almost once a week for the past 6 months and it is easily my favorite restaurant on Filmore in the area. The food is outstanding. I especially like the lamb shoulder, which is incredibly rich and flavorful. The restaurant is run by a a husband and wife duo who are awesome and very friendly.
author: N B.

description:
honestly if i could give troya 10 stars i would.  troya=perfection.

the food is absolutely incredible.  everything is super fresh, flavors excite the palate and there is a great variety of different large and small plates to choose from.

we had the cauliflower which was perfectly balanced with a bit of heat, yogurt and the nutty flavor of roasted cauliflower.  we had the hallumi appetizer and it was cooked perfectly and served with a light salad.  our main courses were the beef dumplings and the falafel.  the beef dumpllings were delicate, flavorful and not like "dough" bombs.  the falafel are the ABSOLUTE BEST IN THE CITY.  we could not get enough.  we kept ordering more and more.  they were super crisp on the outside yet moist and flavorful on the inside.  my son had the chocolate gelato which was so good he ordered another order!!!  complete perfection

if the food is not enough to draw you in, the service should be.  everyone there is the real deal and they not only know their food but they are sweet, professional and delightful.  

troya is a san francisco gem and i cannot wait to go back!
author: Samantha B.

description:
The food was delicious.  I had the meatballs and cauliflower, and appreciate Troya's spicing and generous portion size.

Apparently the restaurant no longer offers waitress service at lunch. This is absurd for the prices. ($10 for kuneyefeh ?). Also, when you pay they request a 15%- or higher- tip. I don't tip that much when there's no service except for bringing the food to my table. I even had to pour my own water. I'd appreciate a return to full-service.
author: Daphne X.

description: Amazing food! I'm coming back for sure! I ordered lamb kebab, lamb shoulder and kale salad. Everything was amazing! Service was great. People are nice. Perfect for a casual lunch and dinner.
author: Pau Y Monica C.

description: Had a great dinner at a Turkish restaurant, Toya on Fillmore St. in San Francisco, celebrating my sister's 70th birthday. The food was wonderful, and the staff was really helpful and attentive. Check this place out!  The starters were incredible - check the red pepper and walnut dip, and the "Turkish Fries". My sister had the braised lamb shoulder; the meat was meltingly tender. My brother in-law had the meat balls with balsamic rice, and was effusive in praise of the spicing.  I had the manti as my entree - centimeter square  beef ravioli in a yoghurt sauce - beautifully spiced, with the yougurt creaminess offsetting the heat of the spicing, perfectly balanced. My order took a while to come out - the staff apologized for the delay; but it was clear that it took awhile because the dish had been made fresh, from scratch! (I always order manti as the test dish for a Turkihs or Afghan restaurant; if the manti is good, everything will be good. Toya passed the test with high marks!) (For a Desi restaurant, the test is the Palak Paneer; for a Chinese restaurant, wok fried green beans with brown sauce.) Our whole party was extremely pleased, and the service was great. Highly recommend Toya!
author: Rashid P.

description: Relatively tasty, with lean meat, organized / compartmentalized sections for their vegetables, rice, sauce and protein, and medium sized portions. Could give more portions for the money ($12 for a bowl for lunch), but in line for SF prices especially on Fillmore (good location by the way).
author: Arvindh K.

description:
Things I love: dining solo and getting the chance to sit at the bar. Things I love more: the fig, hummus and lamb bacon dish I ate while at Troya. There's something incredibly satisfying in this dish's simplicity and paired with the brussel sprouts, and olive oil poached salmon my little  ginger soul was content. Weeks later I am still contemplating the fig, lamb bacon and hummus dish and have even gone so far as to try and recreate it at home. Alas, the joy of it will be something I hold dear until I can wander up Fillmore to Troya once again. 

Cliffnotes you'll want to know:

- This is just as easily a venue for you to dine with a few friends. Solo dining isn't all Troya is good for.
- They do offer take-away (or at least did while I was in town in July)
- 3 dishes were more than ample for one. I dare say they would have been equally suited portions if I had a dining companion to share with. 
- Take the suggestions from the waiters. They know their stuff!
author: Lani P.

description: A little pricey for what you get but good ambience, good food and good service. Love the music and location. Lentil soup is incredible.
author: Saf A.

description: I ate at Troya not long after it first opened and didn't go back again. Recently when I read about their "new concept" and decided to give it a try. We had a couple things that were good and agreed we'd make it a regular. Tonight we had delivery via Caviar and were very disappointed. While the lentil soup and two of the dips were very good, better hummus can be found in most grocery stores. The pita, also the thin grocery store variety has been heated and when we opened the foil, it began to cool...and harden. Really awful. The "kale" salad was puny given the $12+ price, not to mention it was mainly iceberg lettuce with a few pieces of kale (see photo). The lamb entree was dry did not live up to the flavors in its description. Overall, a highly unsatisfactory meal. And oh - because it was delivered, the total cost was almost $70.
author: R. P.

description:
I'm salivating just thinking of it now, three days later. Every bite was amazingly flavorful and delicious and unique. We will definitely be going back.

Interestingly enough, the dish I was looking forward to the least was my favorite--definitely get the Roasted Cauliflower. I can also recommend the Lahmajun Flatbread, the House Made Manti, and the salmon (which doesn't appear to be on the Yelp menu at the moment).

Just be aware that you're going to spend quite a bit (I think that Troya should be listed as $$$ instead of $$) and you probably won't have leftovers.
author: Michelle G.

description:
"What's it called again?  You know...that Turkish place."

The fact I've always had problems remembering Troya's name must have been a sign.  Even when I could think of something, I'd mix them up with "Chaya" half of the time anyways (whoops).  Still, after passing by their Clement and FIllmore locations countless times over the years, I had been really curious about checking them out.  

I'm not sure if reservations are necessary on a weekend, but my friend and I were able to snag a table with relative ease on a Wednesday night.  The menu seemed reasonably priced and had a good variety of dishes (mezes, flatbreads, and entrees), but most of what we had wasn't very exciting.

-- CRISPY SPICED BRUSSELS SPROUTS with Aleppo Aioli...$9
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/troya-fillmore-san-francisco?select=N1w4Th8kXy3RcW_mvdDlXw#Kb2EeFvpPVfP1V2KwiR-0g)
I liked the concept of the dish and the aioli, but the sprouts were really overseasoned.  Though it has an entirely different flavor profile, Marlowe's sprouts dish is much better.

-- ROASTED CAULIFLOWER with Green Onion, Lemon, and Urfa Pepper...$9
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/troya-fillmore-san-francisco?select=N1w4Th8kXy3RcW_mvdDlXw#K4awyhBJ38d-xHPrbxHGOw)
More successful than the sprouts, but defintely not as unique.  The cauliflower was roasted well and it tasted fine, but the price is a little steep for what it is.

-- GOLDEN CHANTERELLE AND LEEK FLATBREAD with Farmers Cheese...$12
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/troya-fillmore-san-francisco?select=N1w4Th8kXy3RcW_mvdDlXw#mRY6hQoubcGdYmpAUKQv2Q)
For me, this was one of our better dishes (our dessert was the other).  I thought the leeks and chantrelle mushrooms went well together, but less of the former might have been better (it made the crust soggy).

-- TURKISH STYLE MARINATED CHICKEN KEBAB with Eggplant, Zucchini, and Paprika Sauce...$17
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/troya-fillmore-san-francisco?select=N1w4Th8kXy3RcW_mvdDlXw#22zGM1IOl_9FnvOnoTJBSg)
The taste didn't seem that different from any other Mediterranean chicken kebab I've had and I could barely taste the marinade.  However, the bigger qualm I had was that a couple of pieces on my kebab had a peculiar, semi-undercooked texture.

-- PISTACHIO BAKLAVA with Housemade Vanilla Ice Cream...$8
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/troya-fillmore-san-francisco?select=N1w4Th8kXy3RcW_mvdDlXw#3vOwWJBvwIGvWH7sUmtysA)
My friend and I agreed this was one of the two "plus" dishes on the night (her second was the cauliflower).  The baklava was a little too sweet, but both the pistachios and the vanilla ice cream were great.

If it weren't for our last minute decision to get dessert, this would have been a two star review.  Even though I'm giving three stars, there was nothing remarkable enough about the experience that would make me want to come back again.  For a restaurant with a name I always seem to forget, I'll probably remember our meal for being unmemorable.
author: Mike L.

description: Food was decent, but service was slow. My chicken kebab was juicy, yet the portion size for $16 was too small. The lamb shoulder was well cooked and tender, yet it also had meager portions. The lentil soup was mediocre and lacked the right chunky consistency. I would not recommend this overpriced restaurant.
author: Byron H.

description: I have been here before and came expecting it was going to be the same but they obviously change the concept of the restaurant to a fast food type of style, lower the quality! And it's overprice
author: Faby M.

description: My sister and I were visiting from out of town and took a self-guided walking tour to Salt and Straw. Found Troya along the way and thought it looked like an awesome Mediterranean place. I so wanted to love this place! The decor was very trendy and cute. We had the falafel and Brussels sprouts. The texture and flavor were so bland I'm still having nightmares. I tried my best to flavor with the sauces provided but we ran out...please do not get the falafel salad. It does not come with enough hummus. It comes with a smear of hummus for plating purposes only. So disappointing.  There are plenty of other options in this cute area.
author: Melissa M.

description: I've eaten many Mediterranean dishes in the past, and Troya applies the Turkish version to most of their items.  We ordered the Brussels Sprouts, Scallops, Lahmajun flatbread and the Manti.  The waiter was very friendly and provided great service.  All of the food tasted good, yet I would say the cuisine is an acquired taste.  The one dish that I missed and will try when I come back is the Cauliflower.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Instead of saving room for kebabs, we should have grazed through the top part of the menu because the small plates at Troya really shine. If I could rewind dinner, I'd order a smorgasbord of roasted brussel sprouts & cauliflower in addition to the seared scallops & trio of dips we picked (with the best undoubtedly being the walnut, which we killed.) We abandoned the Turkish bread, which was too doughy & not fresh tasting, in favor of the complimentary spiced crackers. 

The roasted sauces that accompanied our chicken & lamb kebabs were spectacular (red pepper & eggplant, respectively), but I thought the chicken was tough & not properly seasoned. Really enjoyed the fresh flavors in the arugula salad & in the chickpea salad, but the protein was a bust. What I would order in its place next time -- a flatbread (pear, lemon, goat cheese one sounded amazing.) Lastly, side of basmati rice with slivered almonds was fluffy & nicely flavored. 

Stick with sides & small plates & you'll be feeling fine in the modern Pac Heights eatery.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Delicious! Great options for veggies! We had the mousaka and the tagine, both excellent.
author: Ah T.

description: We just walked in to this place for lunch as we were passing by . Oh my! What a pleasant surprise! The food was superb! Very fresh,very well seasoned! Many vegan options as well as chicken and lamb. The place is VERY clean! Customer service is outstanding! The interior design is very nice and contributes to relaxing atmosphere​. If you like Mediterranean food you must try this place! On top of everything the prices are very reasonable. Next time I'm in SF ,I will definitely go there again.
author: A F.

description: Went to Troya for dinner tonight as the Thai restaurant I wanted to try was closed. I ordered the chicken kabobs that came with rice and a salad. The food was well spiced ad cooked well and I have to agree with everyone else that said it is pricey for what you get. I don't think I would come back again but not because the food or service was bad.
author: Linda M.

description: Troya is our absolute favorite neighborhood spot! We enjoy dinner there just about once a week and can always count on delicious food and friendly service. Highly recommend!
author: Kelly K.

description:
Between two, we split 4 small plates: calamari, cauliflower, scallops, and halloumi cheese. And the lahmajun flatbread. The amount was perfect for us, taking home a few slices of the flatbread to-go.

We weren't really impressed by any of it though. The calamari came out smelling amazing, and the seafood was all fresh, but they were also very small portions for the price. Same with the halloumi cheese, which tasted great, but only had like 3 tiny slices of fruit and a tiny slab of the cheese. On the other hand, the cauliflower plate was huge.

I think you're supposed to get complimentary chips, which we didn't get, but received after asking.
