We agreed that we may have just ordered the wrong things, considering that I usually come into a Mediterranean restaurant craving lamb and hummus. This time was a bit more adventurous.
author: Stella A.

description: I find that this city has mediocre Mediterranean food, so stumbling into Troya two years ago was such a pleasant surprise!!! Every dish we ordered was phenomenal! The lamb is next level, the dumplings are so well spiced and texturally off the chain. The service is great I literally have no complaints. I've been here 4 times since then and have never had a bad meal because they are consistent, which is extremely important quality in a restaurant. Go to a movie at Kabuki and walk up a couple blocks to enjoy some amazing Turkish food, it's a perfect date night restaurant you will not be disappointed!
author: Romy V.

description:
I don't think I would ever come back. My friend and I were rudely greeted when we walked in. We had reservations, and one of the workers just looked at us and walked to the back.

Food was okay. It was our first time trying Turkish food, and the portions were small.. Not recommended for hungry people. Watermelon salad was just mediocre. Pistachio cigars were interesting, and the beef kabob, (overpriced). 

Ambiance is casual, laid back vibe.

Wouldn't have come here if it wasn't for LS.
author: Jamila W.

description: This place is SO SO yummy. We got the pita with dipping sauce, brussels sprouts, and veggie dish. I was honestly shocked the place wasn't busier for how delicious all the food was! I'm already craving the veggie plate again, and I'm planning to go back asap!
author: Shannon L.

description:
Our reservation was at 11.30 and we were the first people there when they opened.  I bought a Groupon because my sister came for a visit and I really wanted to take her to a nice place to eat.

Ordered $40 of food BUT did not read the fine print.  The groupon was only for dinner and because of that, the groupon was only worth $30 for lunch, so I ordered all that food in vain and had to spend more money than saving money..ahhh.... Parking was also horrible that day.  We must have put in $8 worth of coins into the meter. And because they took so long getting the bill we almost got ticketed, but luckily we didn't .

Overall the food was so, so. Service was good but slow.  And the sardines were way over priced.  About $12 for two tiny fish. Most likely try other places to eat than to go back there.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Solid place for lunch. Clean and tasty. Good ingredients. Didn't really leave a lasting impression. Wish it had more of a real Turkish vibe, a la Tuba. They should have a real Turkish brunch (LIKE IN TURKEY), which is lacking in SF/The States...
author: Andrew K.

description:
Troya is another great entry in the Fillmore St. mid-priced casual category, one that has been growing a lot lately. The food is fresh and flavorful, the prices are fair, and the service is good.

I've probably been three or four times now, for lunch, weekend brunch, and dinner. So far, I haven't had a bad meal, and have always left satisfied (i.e., the portions are good).

Most of the dishes I've tried have been tasty, and the ones that stand out in my mind include the moussaka (huge portion, very rich), the lamb kebab, the Turkish eggs benedict, and the heirloom tomato lahmacun. I had the eggs just yesterday, and they were perfectly poached and served over a deep-fried eggplant and feta sandwich. Pretty amazing. The desserts, including the baklava and the semolina cake are really excellent.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I have been told that they recently updated the menu, although I am not sure when.

My first time in.  We sat at the bar, service was great.  My date and I got the brussel sprouts, braised lamb shoulder and chicken kabobs, I thought they were all fantastic.

Will look forward to using this as a neighborhood go-to in the future.
author: T B.

description: It was ok, but the menu was quite small and it was more of an informal place than I had anticipated. The food was on the bland side, but they had lamb kabobs that were good.
author: Caro S.

description:
Came here for lunch on Saturday afternoon. We waited over 10 minutes before anyone even came to our table. If it was busy I would understand, but it was relatively slow. Ended up waiting over 45 minutes and our server didn't even come by to ask if we needed anything or to apologize about the delay. 

Don't waste your time or money here. If you want food Mediterranean food go across the street to La Med.
author: Jon F.

description:
I've been going to Troya since they opened and absolutely love the food. The kitchen does an exceptional job with the food and presentation. If only the wait staff were up to par with the kitchen. My experience last night had me dismayed and disappointed. Our server pretty much treated us with benign neglect all evening. I'm not sure what was going on, but it seemed as if she and the other employees were just going through the motions. 

What was very disconcerting was how they began stacking chairs on top of the tables before we finished dinner! Clearly, this sends the message that the staff is ready to go home, so finish up and move on. Overall, the experience was unfortunate but I can see where the staff was taking their cues... from the manager. Although he greeted us and led us to the table, the rest of the evening he was more concerned with 'closing the books' than ensuring the patrons were enjoying the evening. Starting with the manager, the entire staff need updated training on customer service. Sadly, Troya will not be one of my Top 5 choices on Fillmore.
author: Ted R.

description: The experience we had at Troya last night was amazing! The cauliflower appetizer was to die for, the yogurt sauce was delicious. The meatballs were delicious with yogurt sauce as well and salad on the side. The lab kabab was so flavorful and not too heavy. The server/ owner is so sweet and she made our dining experience one of a kind. I highly recommend this restaurant for anyone looking for a new kind of night out.
author: Genevieve D.

description: So happy I discovered this place! Had dinner with my friend here on a weeknight. Food, wine and service were great! I had the vegetable moussaka, which is like a Mediterranean lasagna, but so much better than lasagna. The flavors just come together beautifully. My friends lamb shoulder was fantastic. Loved our Turkish wines too.
author: Shannon L.

description: Really good food, everything we had was delicious from the cauliflower appetizer to the baklava dessert. Comfortable atmosphere too, we went there for dinner and it was nice, but seems like a great lunch spot.
author: Mac C.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city! Amazing hospitality from the owners, and delicious food at reasonable prices. Their Kunefe is the best dessert I've ever had!
author: Ceci L.

description: Came for dinner. Great food, staff were nice, and the environment is spacious and casual. The dinner menu is split between starters and entrees. For starters we ordered the kale salad, chicken salad, and hummus with lamb. I'd recommend all three and we could've stopped there but we ordered the chicken kabob entree too, which was okay. Overall I recommend this place and I'll be back. Enjoy!
author: Ken C.

description: It was an okay experience, the food was a little pricey. I got the meatballs and lentil soup. The lentil soup was tasty and so were the meatballs and the salad however the rice that came with the dish had a sweet taste to it which I wasn't fond of. The service customer starting lacking after we ordered our food and then once we tipped we did not even receive a thank you. Not the best out there.
author: Yasmine E.

description: If you walk up you might wonder because Jane next door is packed and Troya only has a few people in there but that's just because they've only been there 2 months. I walked in because I didn't have tons of time for lunch and was SO happy I did. The chicken salad was delicious with tons of flavor and a really good sized portion. I recommend it!
author: Andrea S.

description:
Taste:6/10
Ambience: 6/10
Service: 4/10
Price: 6/10 
Value for money: 3/10

Went for Lunch on a Saturday.  Waitress sat us immediately at a table but unfortunately it was dirty and un-bussed.  We had the honey braised lamb wrap with tomatoes, cucumbers, pickles, feta & yogurt.  It was ok but not as flavorful as lamb wraps I've experienced at other places nearby.  It was also very wet and dripped constantly in my plate.  It gave the the sense that it was pre-made because it was also not very warm either.
Our second selection was the superior farms lamb kebab with pistachio, tahini yogurt, basmati rice & greens,  Again it was decent but with all those ingredients it was also lacking flavor and tenderness I'm accustom to.  In fact, if the edges of the lamb weren't charred it wouldn't have had any flavor at all.  The char overstated the meat.
author: John W.

description: Delicious! My favorites were the roasted cauliflower and the chicken kabob. I'm not usually into chicken at restaurants but this dish was cooked perfectly and served well with a really delicious chickpea and harrisa side. We also tried the lamb meatballs, salmon and lamb kabob and lamb bacon. The lamb was seasoned well but was overlooked in all these dishes. I would definitely go back for the chicken though!
author: Asha S.

description:
TL;DR: Had a good dinner but the food wasn't mind-blowing. Service was great. Tagine was flavorful and interesting; beef dumplings were just ok. Maybe try multiple small plates.

AT and I came here with a LivingSocial voucher (which I sometimes purchase to force ourselves to try a different restaurant in town). Getting a reservation was no problem, and when we arrived there were plenty of open tables. The service was great, and the food came out quickly.

AT and I got two main dishes (tagine and beef dumplings), but the table next to us opted to get several small plates to share. AT's tagine was good--it's a vegetarian dish with plenty of flavor. My dumplings were good but got boring halfway through. It's basically mini beef dumplings covered in a yogurt sauce. I think it would have been better with a smaller serving and maybe something on the side. The baklava threw us for a loop: it looked like a cinnamon roll but tasted like baklava. Don't get me wrong--it was still good, but just strange.

Overall, things were good, and I want to try getting multiple small plates next time. But for the price point, I think I want to try a few other places first before coming back immediately.
author: Julia N.

description: The food is delicious! I especially loved the Brussels sprouts and the cauliflower. Highly recommended!
author: Alison R.

description: I think that this is one of the best places on Fillmore for dinner. It is a really cute place. The service was great...and super fast. I couldn't believe how quickly the food came out! Everything was very good. My parents loved the manti. The kebabs were also a hit. Really nice neighborhood spot!
author: Jen G.

description: Loved this place. Delicious Turkish coffee and dessert. Will definitely come back to have dinner here. Their staff is very sweet and welcoming. Highly recommend it.
author: Nina A.

description: High quality Turkish/mediterrenian food,good service in a very chic neighborhood Fillmore! All of us ordered lamb shoulder, it comes with salad and yogurt sauce. It was very delicious. The place is very spacy so you can sit comfortably. Another plus for me is tht the restaurant is kid friendly
author: Merve A.

description: Had dinner there tonight. Excellent ambiance, unique food menu &  delicious food. It's pretty price but worth every penny. Must try!
author: Mark Z.

description: I have seen their food truck all over the place so I was excited to try the brick and mortar location on Fillmore. Everything we had was super tasty and we loved the brussel sprouts, flat bread, and chicken kebab. The baklava was some of the best I have had - up there with Kokkari's. I will definitely be back as the food and experience was solid!
author: Derek S.

description:
I really loved this place. The décor is cute and the food is great. We got the halloumi starter and it was so great! It's so hard to find halloumi in restaurants in San Francisco and it is my favorite cheese. I also had one of the flatbreads and it was really good. I was going meatless on the day I went due to Lent, and there were plenty of options.

Halfway through the meal, the waiter asked if we could move over one table because a reservation for 4 people was arriving and they need to push two tables together. We gladly scooted over 3 feet, and they were SO apologetic even though it was no big deal. Next thing we knew, we had two free drinks coming our way and a free dessert! No necessary at all, but appreciated!
author: Alexandra W.

description: Noisy, expensive local spot that makes a nice pureed lentil soup. I'm not a fan of their grilled veggies or dry chicken kabob. Pleasant servers here.
author: Lynn S.

description: Very cozy and intimate place - a hidden gem. They start you off with homemade crackers while you wait. This is my second time here. Both visits I had the same dishes: chicken kabob with warm bean salad and spicy dip and olive oil poached salmon with turnip and potato purée.  I was equally happy with both visits - they are pretty consistent here. Both dishes were great both times. The chicken and salmon were cooked perfectly - moist and flavorful. I have to say the spicy dip/sauce that comes with the chicken dish is so good! Ask for extra sauce!!! It was so good that I enhanced my salmon dish with it - gave it a good kick.
author: Caroline K.

description:
What I love about ethnic cuisine is its authenticity. None of that dumbed down fusion sh*t for me puhlease. For Italian, I want hearty, stick-to-your-rubs rustic dishes. For Chinese, the dingier the restaurant, the better. Sticky tables? Flies? They just add to the authenticity. For Mexican, no head (cabeza) and no lengua (tongue) on the menu? Adios.

Being a fan of Troya's original location in Inner Richmond (my review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/troya-san-francisco#hrid:z2rd1mAYwRonuYfJdLRfHQ), their new Fillmore location (formerly Citizen Cake) was a complete disappointment. The Turkish dishes here are Californian-inspired (different menu than Inner Richmond) and the service lacks the warmth and charm of their original location.

I know it's Pac Heights and all but ballers should have non-bougie, authentic cuisine available to them too. 

Make sure to call in for reservations (not on OpenTable yet) because we ended up waiting for 2 hours on a Friday night. Totally NOT worth the wait (I was too gin happy at the time to care). Even with no wait, I wouldn't return to this location. 

F O O D
*HUMMUS w/ Turkish Bread ($5) - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o4x29HYKvEUf7Regrn-J9g?select=3L_wrcsl_o_q4fbknylRQQ#P6SpVcBbN3vDqscnBKr48Q
I like my hummus smooth and creamy. This hummus had an unappetizing chunky granular texture. It was also yearning for more lemon juice and salt as it was very bland. 

*FETA CHEESE CIGARS w/ Pistachio & Honey ($7) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o4x29HYKvEUf7Regrn-J9g?select=3L_wrcsl_o_q4fbknylRQQ#gN9S7jJYSU1tU7F42KNMow
You can never go wrong with anything fried right? This was the case with the feta cheese cigars. It was deliciously crunchy and the pungent saltiness of the feta along with the sweet honey tickled my taste buds.  

*ZUCCHINI FRITTERS w/ Mint & Yogurt ($7) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o4x29HYKvEUf7Regrn-J9g?select=3L_wrcsl_o_q4fbknylRQQ#m3jMgeQ2_fvJdHS2D9fltA
A signature appetizer from their original location, the zucchini fritters did not disappoint. It had a nice crispy exterior with a tender center. The tangy yogurt gave it oomph.

*BRAISED LAMB DOLMAS w/ Pomegranate Molasses & Tahini ($9) - 0 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o4x29HYKvEUf7Regrn-J9g?select=3L_wrcsl_o_q4fbknylRQQ#N1w4Th8kXy3RcW_mvdDlXw
The WORST dish of the night, the dolmas looked like shriveled up 8=D. Notice how I used just one "=". Micropenises. UGH. They were blistered and brunt on the outside (left lingering charcoal taste in my mouth) and the lamb filling was super dry.

*MOUSSAKA ($14) - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o4x29HYKvEUf7Regrn-J9g?select=3L_wrcsl_o_q4fbknylRQQ#xJtGQj3jCzDK0poKrmHCRA
Having loved this comfort dish (like eggplant parmesan) at their original location, I was surprised how this dish was a near fail. Though the moussaka was creamy and decadent, it was severely under seasoned and incredibly bland. It was like eating spoonfuls of semi-solidified unsalted cream. 

*GRILLED VEGGIES w/ Mushrooms ($11) - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o4x29HYKvEUf7Regrn-J9g?select=DSSwmMbcWi8KnlxfUXaUUA#3L_wrcsl_o_q4fbknylRQQ
Not sure how you can easily mess up a dish as simple as grilled veggies but they somehow managed to. The grilled veggies were dry and bland while the couscous was overly salty. Nearly $4 each for a veggie skewer? Ripoff. 

*CHICKEN KEBAB ($13) - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o4x29HYKvEUf7Regrn-J9g?select=3L_wrcsl_o_q4fbknylRQQ#Djel6xNzrdBxz-fZjeJM4g
Although the chicken was tender, it was yet again bland just like most of the other dishes. 

S E R V I C E
Though the staff was friendly, they were green and lacked refinement. We were never checked on and empty plates sat on our table and were not taken away when our other orders arrived. I know they've only been open for 2 months but simple things like this is plain commonsense. 

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Trendy and sophisticated, this Troya location is good date spot and for small groups with Edison lighting, a communal table, and exposed red brick walls. Seating for about 40 people and bar seating is available.  

P A R K I N G
Street parking only. 

Sadly, Troya Fillmore is an example of WHY you need to go to the "hood" to get solid ethnic eats specifically the TL. Walking through pee pee and poo poo infested streets with Tory Burch flats, stepping over passed out crack heads and brushing arms with trannies while clutching onto your LV bag. Easy peezy...just act cray and NO one will bother you. Works like a charm every time...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
We've been intending to try Troya ever since we learned it was taking over the former Citizen Cake location. It took more than a year and we finally got around to un-bookmarking some weeks back.  

I was slightly disappointed to be honest. Not because our server was only one of two (perhaps the only) servers that night, we felt we were waiting on her instead of the other way around but rather the meal was an unmemorable one. My dish, although it sounded remarkable on the menu was dry and slightly bland and felt a bit heavy handed. Not to mention priced a bit steep for what it was (a non-meat dish that was priced almost as much as the ones inclusive of meat) The smaller plates seem to be priced right however. 

I wouldn't say this area of Fillmore is overflowing with superb dining options so perhaps this alone might be a contributing factor as to why I might return to Troya when I stumble into the area.
author: Esther A.

description: I gave this place another try, after a very disappointing take-out experience, and I had a great dinner.  The  food -cauliflower, brussel sprouts, lamb, and falafel- was excellent and the service was friendly and fast.  Thus, I highly recommend coming here for dinner, but I can't recommend getting take-out.
author: JJ M.

description:
This place was ok. Came in town for a wedding and went to dinner here as it's close to buchanan. 
Great food but service and execution can use an improvement. Dim lighting needs to be darker to create a intimate feel. I would give this another shot but was not impressed the first time :/
author: True R.

description: Umm, it's okay. Nothing special. Just got the Mediterranean salad. And the lettuce was not totally crisp, tomatoes and avocado were really cold which means they were in the fridge. You don't put tomatoes and avocados in the fridge bc they lose all their flavor. They don't give you enough dressing. THe last time I was here my wrap was just okay. This white girl can make better Mediterranean food.
author: WC Gal Z.

description:
Feta on lahmajun, really?! Never seen that in any Turkish restaurant ever, and my personal opinion, as a Turk, is those two things don't go together.

Other than that, the manti and the moussaka were great.

Also waiters were very helpful and polite, and I really appreciated the "Tesekkurler" ("thank you" in Turkish) in excellent accent after dinner. Photographs of Istanbul all around set the atmosphere nicely as well.
author: Ezgi A.

description: Great place. You order pay and then they bring plates to your table. Good service. Not as romantic as they were back on 5th and Clement. More of a cafe feel to it. Food is excellent. Lentil soup is amazing so were salmon kebabs. Turkish coffee is awesome.
author: A. P.

description:
I got a living social coupon for this place and went. They don't really need these living social coupons! The place was filled. But I guess it turned out to be a great deal for me so I can't complain :)

We ordered three small plates and one flatbread. Everything was great - fresh ingredients, great flavor. Service was just ok, but nothing wrong. Ambience was vibrant, a bit on the modern side.

- brussel sprouts - they are deep fried, on the greasy side, but tasty
- grilled calamari - wonderfully cooked, very flavorful, tender, and smokey
- red lentil soup - they split the soup for the two of us. The spices are wonderful, the olive oil and lemon added perfectly into the soup. 
- eggplant flatbread - very light, very fresh, and just enough flavor. 

It was a great meal! Will definitely go back again. But since I don't live in the neighborhood anymore, maybe next time they offer another coupon :)
author: Wendy K.

description:
Food was good, nothing mind blowing but so many great options. I'm giving it 4 star because the foods great and I think more people should patronize it. 

The service wasn't as great. We seemed to be rushed a little bit.  There were people ahead of us to get a table and they were asked to wait 10-15 minutes when the restaurant was practically empty. The wine and beer selection was weak. 

I think this place is suffering from Groupon fatigue. Everyone around us had a Groupon and if we knew this before we would have never bothered coming here. However, since so many people had one I decided to buy one on my phone to save $15. This place can totally stand on its own; just need better management.
author: LAIKA K.

description: The staff is sweet! Great food, music and atmosphere! Very relaxing!!! Highly recommended!!! Seriously
author: Bryan B.

description: Ate here on Saturday night and STILL thinking about the delicious food!  The lamb kebab did not disappoint!  It was cooked perfectly and the plate had this amazing garlic brown sauce, while my husband loved his Harissa meatball bowl.  The ambiance is awesome for a fast casual and I loved that they had Turkish wine options.  Will definitely be going back soon!
author: Jane H.

description: Not my favorite Turkish food in the city, but definitely good. The brussel sprouts appetizer and the blueberry pancakes for brunch are v yummy!
author: Elise M.

description: The brunch menu on Yelp is a lie, and the service was terribly slow on a Sunday. The food was just alright, but overall I was hoping for more.
author: Gigi B.

description:
I had a groupon to this place and finally set aside time to use it. We arrived and sat down right away- the service was great. 

We ordered a bottle of French wine (the cheapest on the menu $35) and the owner of the restaurant came over to our table, extremely apologetic and explained that he was out of most of their French wine but that he would give us a discount for the only French wine he had (the most expensive on the menu $90)... he was extremely sincere and accommodating. 

We ordered the Brussels sprouts and the cauliflower appetizers and both were full of flavor, I would have ordered them again. I need to come back and try all of the starters because I'm sure they are equally tasteful. For the main course we ordered 2 flat breads and they were decent in size and very creative in flavor. I would definitely return to this restaurant.
author: Micki D.

description: When we were recently visiting our son, we had the opportunity to try this restaurant.  We loved it!   The staff and the food was superb!
author: Kelli A.

description: It's an ok restaurant if you like this kind of food.   The service was good, and it's a nice environment. The food was ok, no more no less. Small dishes for the price. Also $1 per extra pita ?! I don't think we will be back, there are other better choices in SF!
author: Ahuva R.

description: Great food and fun atmosphere! Wanted to specifically call out the manager who overheard me mention I was allergic to salmon and proactively told me the chicken is prepared near it on the grill. He was able to cook my kebab in the oven to insure no overlap! The chicken was cooked perfect - I also recommend starting with the cauliflower!
author: Lisa C.

description:
Hit and miss experiences here. The halloumi omlette they sometimes have at brunch is really good if you like salty halloumi, and it's an item I haven't seen anywhere else. Same goes for the dinner salad with halloumi and persimmons, which is salty, lightly sweet, and complex. 

The lunches are overpriced and twice I've had my chicken kebabs come out undercooked (I will say they replaced them with fully cooked ones ASAP). The lentil soup is very creamy but needs a lot of salt and the squeeze of lemon it comes with to get the depth of flavor to shine. 

Troya is a good stop for the neighborhood, but not a destination for Mediterranean food.
author: Laura J.

description:
Love this place! The hanger steak and lamb bacon was delicious!! :) 
Our server Lisandro totally made our night he was so friendly and funny and answered any questions we had! Definitely recommending this place to all my friends!
author: Angie O.

description:
Had a best-friend-date here last night.  It was all so good I started writing my review in my head during dinner.

We ordered: 
Feta Cheese cigars with Pistachio& Honey = yum!
Zucchini Fritters with Mint & Yogurt = yum!
Turkish Beef Dumplings with Yogurt, Dried Spices & Paprika Butter  = OMGAmazingTrippleYUMYUMYUM!!!

Seriously, the little dumplings in tangy yogurt were divine.  I've never had anything like it.

The atmosphere is great.  It's warm and kind of masculine.  Very cool light fixtures, lots of warm wood.  This would be a great place for a first date.  It's not overly romantic yet the lighting makes everyone look really good.  Which means it's also a great place for a best-friend-date.

Price wise, it's a terrific bang for your buck.  I will be back!

The only reason it's not a five star review is because I don't like unisex restrooms.  I also don't like restrooms right next to the kitchen.
author: Chloe M.

description: I was very excited to try Troya's lunch, as I thought their lunch menu sounded delicious.  It is not.  I got a chicken wrap, and it was honestly awful.  The chunks of chicken were huge, way too large for a wrap.  They were also of questionable quality - definitely had more than one bite that had some kind of fat or gristle in it.  But, the worst part is that it had NO flavor.  I will not be returning to Troya.  Also - their online menu has lower prices than the actual menu in the restaurant, which is very strange
author: CateyLou C.

description:
Troya is located conveniently on Fillmore. I admit I am not a fan of their ambiance or their rather small and uncomfortable tables  but their food was reasonably good!

I decided to splurge on sugar and ordered a dessert wine (no selection there, they had only one) and it was pretty good, seemed mid-way between a Müller-Thurgau and an Auslese. Nothing fantastic, but good. 

We had a the Baked Halloumi Cheese for a starter, not much of cheese there really! 

I quite forget what I got for my main course, but it was a vegetarian dish with a tangy red wine sauce which was fantastic. 

Not too many vegetarian choices though, unlike other Mediterranean places. Pretty average place...
author: Rocking V.

description:
I went to Troya for breakfast on a Saturday morning. The place was half full so I was initially suspect because every other good breakfast place had a long line outside the restaurant. 

I sat down at the bar and ordered freshly squeezed Orange juice and a mushroom omelette. For someone who grew up in India always drinking juice freshly squeezed and rarely having drunk out of the bottle, I have high expectations of freshly squeezed OJ and this place met it. It was cold and freshly squeezed and  delicious.

The mushroom omelette was sumptuous and came with a salad and sliced avocado. The omelette came with an incredibly tasty sauce whose name I forgot to ask as I was worried about my parking meter running out. 

Overall, great place to take kids too. There is a lot of room in the restaurant so there is no jostling of elbows when you eat .
author: Sudarshan S.

description: Had the falafel salad and Chardonnay for lunch with teenage daughter - she had an omelette.  Atmosphere -5.  Food -4.5. Drink - 4.  Daughter said 3 out of 5 - she would come back.  We are both vegetarians.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
The food at Troya is rich with flavor, but light on the stomach. My favorite combination.

I was extremely impressed with all of the dishes that I sampled at the Troya Fillmore location last week. I've always been a big fan of their Richmond restaurant and it's nice to see Troya expanding - especially since they put a large emphasis on making sure that many of their dishes are organic, sustainable, and locally farmed.

The ambiance at this location is hip and chic. It's a remarkable addition to the Pacific Heights area and is perfect for catching up with friends and such. Though be sure to make a reservation at night - since Troya is definitely a happening spot.

We shared the roasted cauliflower with spring onion and urfa, the watermelon and braised fennel salad, as well as the Mahi-Mahi skewers.  Everything was perfectly cooked, and you could taste the freshness of each ingredient - from the crisp juicy watermelon, to the lightly roasted cauliflower. The Mahi-Mahi was superb and grilled with care.

If you're trying to eat healthy and don't want to sacrifice taste - come here. Troya's menu is innovative  - and they can accommodate nearly every kind of eater. 

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I've seen queues out of this place. Popped in for lunch and was greeted with friendly staff. 
The lunch menu is reasonably priced, great food particularly the fact the wraps can be made as salads too. The char grilled chicken has the perfect char grilled taste.
Good serving sizes for lunch too, not too much that there's food wastage. 
Would definitely come back.
Oh and their Turkish peppermint tea is delicious!
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
Bib Gourmand. 

Went for brunch and for dinner.
Some interesting choices. The flatbreads were nice, the spreads were tasty too (special mention to the yogurt one).
A bit disappointed by the hot cheese, but overall it was a pleasant experience. 

The atmosphere is nice and service was good.
A nice address, but not even closed to Michelin Star level. 

Edit: not really surprised by the fact they lost their Bib Gourmand.
author: Lionel F.

description:
Taste:7/10
Ambience: 7/10
Service: 9/10
Price: 4/10 (kind of expensive)
Value for money: 6/10

Note: I paid $65 for 2 ppl without drinks. So did not find it reasonable. Food was good but not great.
Not really a Turkish place. Just uses Turkish ingredients.
author: Abhijeet T.

description:
Simply - avoid the place.
I ended up there because the weekend lines at Jane's next door were way too long and I was hungry.
I ordered a chicken salad. The chicken seemed to be cooked a while ago, and then re-fried and served. I was promised that the chicken is grilled, but this was not the case. It was very greasy and had an aftertaste. Likewise, underneath the grease the chicken breast was so dry it jammed the  spaces between my teeth. Three hours later I threw it all up. I think the chicken breast was not fresh in addition to the fact that I'm not used to eat greasy fried food. 
I was told that if I want bread to go with the salad it's additional $3.50. 
Conclusion - better wait in the line for Jane than enter Troya.
The faucet water was tasty. I think SF's water originates in Yosemite.
author: Ayala K.

description:
Troya Fillmore fills the space left behind by Elizabeth Faulkner's Citizen Cake though thankfully not the stench of their horrible service and sad dinner food.  It's nice to see the space filled with happy diners and a high level of excellent service.  Not having a reservation on a Saturday evening, we were offered a seat at the bar where we led off with some fine New Zealand Pinot Noir by the glass ($9).  We graduated onto mezes and shared an entree.  Our waitress was right in saying this would be plenty of food.    

Of the mezes we ordered, my favorites were:  

*  Feta cheese cigars with pistachio, honey, and cinnamon ($7) - With their oozy, melty, salty filling I could eat these all night long.  I love these things.  I wish I could order a platterful.
 
* Zucchini fritters ($8) -  These were hot and spicy, crunchy and well flavored.  A perfect companion was the mint dipping sauce accompaniment.  A platter of this would be desirable as well.     

*  Roasted caluliflower with spring onion - I make roasted cauliflower all the time so it practically kills me to pay $9 for someone else to make it.  This was good though (as is mine) and it was a nice balance to the other flavors we sampled.

* Roast asparagus - This was on the specials menu.  Again, roasting asparagus at home is a snap but they added some artichokes and tomatoes and the whole thing tasted good, not grand.     

I really didn't care much for the cracker-like flatbread that they serve in a cup nor the turkish bread that accompanied the trio of Babaganoush, Haydari, and Muhammara ($14).   Both seemed more like supporting vehicles for delivering things that taste better.  In this case, that would be only the Haydari, a white Turkish yogurt dip.  The Babaganoush had an odd grey color and tasted burnt.  The orangy-red Muhammara tasted oddly of nothing.  In the future, I'd skip this meze altogether and substitute something else in its place.  Fried calamari, perhaps?

We shared the moussaka entree ($19) which proved a wise decision.  Though not bad it was a large serving and its one-dimensional mouth-feel (cinnamony and rich) meant that I would've quickly tired of the taste.  As it was, we brought 50% home for a future meal.  I'd get this again, but only if I were sharing it amongst 3 - 4 people.  

Though Troya was full with people the restaurant had a quiet energy.  It was easy to carry on a conversation, even at the bar.   I think the place is solid, but it might take some careful menu sampling to come up with a meal where everything is universally delicious.  I'd not be opposed to sampling more widely to really hone in on the things that taste great.
author: Tracey A.

description: The location is good, but foods are not good! If you order the steak, then it is a waste! Calamari order is very tiny but not cheap.  Waitress had no smile! It's not a good place to eat!
author: Vincent Y.

description:
Great food amazing service. 
We went for brunch on a Saturday morning. It was not my first time at the restaurant but first time for brunch. 
The food was so fresh and good. Our waitress Veronica was so accommodating and very cheerful. I love great service better than great food but this place has both.
author: Khaoula B.

description:
This is always my go to place when I am meeting a friend for dinner, and we want something on Fillmore. The food is great, and the service is always on point. They are always so attentive and friendly!

The haloumi cheese appetizer and roasted cauliflower are always a winner, and depending on my diet, I love the chicken kebab (when I'm on paleo) or the Turkey dumplings, or manti (when I am not on paleo). The meat is cooked perfectly (so flavorful and never dry!). 

Every time I have gone here, both the service and the food has remained consistent. Will definitely be going back!
author: Victoria B.

description:
Absolutely OUTSTANDING restaurant!

Anyone looking to try Turkish food should come here - it is the best Turkish food I have had in the city. My uncle is from Turkey and we come here all the time. The food is so fresh, the flavors are carefully crafted, and the menu changes frequently. Everything I have had is delicious. Mr. Kilicoglu (the owner) is an extremely talented and warm-hearted individual who is passionate about food and providing excellent customer service.
author: Nicky K.

description:
Visited with a group of 7 friends last night, sans reservation, our bad!  However, as we made it in for a later dinner this was not an issue and we were seated quickly. Having lived in Turkey for a couple years as a teenager, I was very excited to try this place, and overall I was not disappointed. 

As a group we ordered:
turkish bread- meh
lentil soup- delicious
feta cheese cigars- delicious
grilled halloumi cheese- delicious
calamari- delicious
fried zucchini- meh

I then had the lamb kebab and the hubbs had the chicken kabob, lamb wins, it was moist and delicious. I sampled the braised chicken and the moussaka from friends and i also like the moussaka, this is a dish you want some bread to dip with. 

All in all the service was great, the food was yummy although a lil pricey, but I would definitely go again!
author: Nicole Z.

description:
Came here on a Sunday for lunch but menu is actually for brunch. They were empty, while the other restaurants were packed. So yup got a table right away.

Service was pretty lousy. They were interested in cleaning instead of serving. And not very nice.

We ordered the Turkish spread appetizer (babaganoush, haydari & muhammara with house made turkish bread) and zuchini fritters. They were good but way overpriced. And they don't give you enough bread with the spread plate. For $14 that should come with as much bread as possible (they charged us for extra order). 

I had the lamb meatball wrap, and my partner had the falafel wrap. They were both very good, I really liked the taste. Strange though that they came in a pita wrap because I asked for extra pita (for the turkish spread) and they don't have those individually. Good restaurants will go out of their way to make customers happy. I don't think the staff here cares very much.
author: Vol T.

description: Average food and average service. They ran out of a key ingredient in a salad, but didn't inform us or offer a substitute until we asked. The lamb bacon was fatty. And the  calamari was flavorless. The only saving grace was the kenefe dessert. The baclava was burnt.
author: V S.

description: Delicious food, calm atmosphere, and very reasonably priced. Great neighborhood spot!
author: Dominic D.

description:
Food was okay. Portions were small for the price. Server was really nice. Went with a groupon. 
Will not come back.
author: Girl I.

description: Came here for lunch after an early movie as I've been wanting Turkish cuisine for awhile.  Unfortunately the mantis dumplings that I wanted, was available for dinner only so we went with a roasted eggplant and ricotta flatbread and the turkish meatball lavash wrap.  Both were wonderfully flavored that I ended up jumping back and forth between the two plates and still couldn't decide which I liked more.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
Let's talk about brunch...

There are so many vegetarian breakfast burritos, fruit and granola bowls and Mediterranean omelets I can eat.  Sometimes, the funk chain must be broken, but it is a rarity for a restaurant to venture past predictable breakfast/brunch options and excite the palate with a little something different.  

Enter Troya.  Not since State Bird Provisions (which ironically stopped serving brunch days after I had the pleasure of dining there) have I been so giddy about my morning meal.  I literally (and unashamedly) was clapping as I was eating.  And here is why:

- menemen eggs: plain, simple delicious.  Scrambled eggs with tomatoes, onions and bell peppers.  Comes with rather large sides of spiced potatoes (fantastic!) and green salad.  
- braised greens with 2 eggs: Oh my freaking lord. This was amazing! Simple, well-prepared ingredients + paprika (and other spices) makes me a happy bruncher. This dish also came with a healthy side order of potatoes and greens.
- their jams; it doesn't matter what kind it is, it will be amazing. Try it with a side order (only $2) of Turkish bread.

No fancy brunch drinks yet, but the glass of prosecco I had was perfect with the delectable options above!

I think for me personally though, the brunch atmosphere reminded me of when Troya first opened for dinner, before the word-of-mouth,  glowing SF Chronicle review, and resulting lines out the door.  

A special thank you to Berk, who should teach a course on ensuring customer satisfaction.  Thank you for always being gracious and generous, and for always going that extra step and making sure that your diners leave happy.  It is greatly appreciated!
author: Gev M.

description: The food is excellent. It is all extremely fresh and prepared perfectly. However my only issue is over the price. The price to portion ratio is way off in my opinion. It's probably just because of what neighborhood it's in. It is worth giving a try at least once! The customer service is awesome as well.
author: David M.

description: I'm very disappointed in this new iteration of Troya. This used to be a go-to place for fresh salads, delicious mezze, roasted vegetables and meats. The new counter service offers an extremely limited  (still expensive) menu with a few kebabs, new bowls/wraps, and one mezze combo. The meatballs were dry, over-cooked and bland. The hummus was watery and the lavash was cold--a far cry from the old platter. Service at the table is antagonistic at best. This place was always expensive; now it's distinctly not worth it.
author: Kim B.

description: Troya is a welcome spot of Mediterranean cuisine located around a plethora of "trendy" food options on the upper Fillmore. Lunch here was a delicious Chicken wrap. The chicken meat was well cooked and decently spiced while remaining juicy. It was accompanied by a tasty greens blend and tzakziki  sauce that really worked for me. It was spicy and tangy without any particular element overpowering the chicken. Salient point here is that I could actually taste the chicken.  A big plus was the wrap was nice and toasted that ended a very pleasing textural element to my meal. Ordering is in the walk up counter style and for lunch the menu is limited to four mains/wraps and a variety of salads, the service is prompt and courteous. Libations ranged from Mexican Coke , micro brew ales and the normally good range of wines Troya is known for. The decor is of a brick house minimalist style that is pleasing. I'll definitely come back here for dinner.
author: Hector A.

description: We stumbled upon this neighborhood gem a few years ago, and it remains one of my favorite restaurants on Fillmore! Everyone in our group, during every visit, loves their meal. The new design of ordering from the counter was new and different for a nice restaurant like this, but honestly, it made for a much more relaxed experience. We just chatted away until it was time to eat. Service was still amazing, servers were very attentive and accommodating. And once we were finished, we were on our way!
author: J K.

description: I cannot emphasize how much I LOVE Troya. We typically go to visit the Inner Richmond location, but thanks to a Groupon, we decided to venture over to the Fillmore location for a try. The decor and ambiance are modern and warm. The menu at the Fillmore location was different than the other location so we tried out some new dishes that we really loved. I highly recommend ordering the manti. Each dumpling is delicately constructed and tastes delicious with the light yogurt sauce. The skin isn't too thick so you really are able to taste the flavor of the meat with the dumpling skin. The grilled calamari was also delicious and tender. I really enjoyed the tomato sauce with the calamari.
author: Alice H.

description: Food is alright. nothing fantastic.  was disappointed after reading all the good reviews.  Portions are super small and prices are too high for what you get. i wouldnt recommend it and will not be coming back here.  a lot better options on fillmore- that are way more worth the money,  service was slow and atmosphere was dull.
author: Yasi N.

description:
I have been to Troya a few times now for lunch and dinner. I have tried the lamb kebabs, the eggplant flat bread, and a grilled haloumi cheese appetizer.

The kebabs were incredible. The lamb was tender and perfectly seasoned. The egg plant flat bread was just ok, it was very small and wasn't really enough for a meal. 

The grilled haloumi cheese appetizer was the standout. I had never had haloumi before this dish, and it made me a fan. The cheese was warm but not oozing everywhere, which is what I would think would happen to cheese when it was grilled, but it stayed solid. It was really good with the bread that was served with it. 

I would recommend getting a reservation before attempting to come here, the hostesses seems to get annoyed when you do not have one...
author: Stephanie T.

description: Great spot! Wouldn't normally consider Mediterranean food for brunch but actually worked out very nicely. My highlights: awesome service, LAMB BACON, baklava, omelette, pita, and of course the lamb. Got the table by window - fun to hang and people watch.
author: F G.

description: Though the portions were smaller than I expected, the food was delicious! Our waitress was wonderful and the atmosphere is very welcoming. Great place if you're dying for Mediterranean food.
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
Cute, simple design inside. Appropriate place for lunch with a friend.
Super friendly staff.
Great menu with plenty of options (even for me, a vegetarian)
Turkish beer!
Reasonable prices.
The red lentil soup was delicious, the brussels sprouts were great and plentiful, and the grilled avocado was surprisingly good (sounds plain, but it was quite tasty).  My friend ordered the olives and she didn't think much of them, but we were extremely happy with everything else.  I'll def go back!
author: Elena I.

description:
Ate here with the sig-o and a couple of friends I hadn't seen in months. My friend made the reservation online but was only able to get it at 8:30pm. We wanted to dine earlier so he called in and was able to get it moved to 7:00pm without any worries, so that was nice. I'm not sure why the 7pm slot was not available online originally, though.

On reaching the restaurant, it was fairly busy but not packed. Walk-ins were getting seated immediately. Our server was a bit hit-and-miss. He spoke very softly and forgot things like getting our drink and appetizer orders.

We got the Warm Hummus with House Smoked Lamb Bacon as an appetizer. It was okay but not phenomenal. We got only 1 piece of pita bread, sliced into 4 pieces. The lamb bacon was dripping with oil and was not crunchy but more like jerky. I've never had lamb bacon before--maybe that's how it's supposed to be? Who knows.

For dinner I got a flatbread with mushrooms and vegetables. It was quite tasty but also fairly oily. The wooden platter that the dish was served in was soaked in oil. I had no problems with the taste, however. My wife got Lamb Kebab in Smoked Eggplant Puree. I enjoyed it though she was not a fan. We did not partake in dessert.

Between the two of us, our check came out to nearly $70. I felt like that was a little overpriced for food that was okay. I would have been okay paying about 50-60% of that amount for the quality of food and service.

We might return here for lunch since their selection is a bit different.
author: Sohum M.

description:
The food and service were quite good. Tasty dishes included feta cheese cigars, lentil salad, lamb meatball wrap, and pumpkin dessert with yogurt, honey and nuts. 
Our one complaint was the overly loud volume of the music.
author: Michael B.

description:
I tried Troya for dinner and brunch and both times have been good experiences.

Just recently, I went for brunch, which I was surprised to know that Troya was serving on the weekend. I ordered the blueberry pancakes with pomegranate whipped cream, hazelnuts & carmelized bananas - the verdict : very sweet and rightly portioned. He ordered the baked eggs with sausage, peppers, onions & cheese which was very savory. 

I would go back to Troya for brunch but one thing that I would like to see different other than the delicious food and great ambience is probably more attentive customer service but other than that I wouldn't complain too much.
author: C M.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Feta Cheese cigars = It was alright nothing special
2.) Lentil Soup - it was fine
* Food  came with instead of bread, these crisps, kinda like crackers

SERVICE:
Good


ATMOSPHERE:
Cute atmosphere. I wouldn't mind coming here for wine & snack. Not sure if any of the entrees would be any better. But I like the Troya in Richmond District so maybe.


9.8.13
author: Angela L.

description:
Gross, inedible!!! 

The incredible arrogance of this place is unbelievable.  They knowingly sent to my table an inedible meal.  Complete disrespect for their customers. At lunch today I was served an ice cold chicken wrap. It was supposed to be warm. The chicken was thrown in straight from the refrigerator.  It was ice cold, mushy and tasted as though it were going bad.  I  informed my waiter that it was cold and he offered to return it to the kitchen to be warmed.  Gee, shouldn't it have come to the table that way in the first place. And, if it were warmed in a microwave, the lettuce and other vegetables inside would have wilted.. I asked for my check after two bites of this cold, bland garbage, served inside a tortilla.  No attempt at authenticity at this place.  Yes, I paid but I'll never return.  

I've been living in the neighborhood for 30 years and wonder what is it about Pacific Heights that attracts these pretentious, low quality restaurants. The neighborhood is filled with them.  With the exception of Ten Ichi, Bun Mee and Tullys, I no longer frequent the establishments in my own neighborhood.  Funny thing, I rarely see my neighbors in any of the Fillmore restaurants or shops.  Just wondering who are these people flocking to these places to eat sub par food and pay good money to be disrespected. People, you deserve better.
author: Donna P.

description:
The "manti" is on the 7x7 Big Eats list for 2013.  For those that don't know (and that included me), a "manti" is a Turkish dumpling.  This is listed under the Larger Plates section of the menu.  $16.  Delicious.  These were tiny beef balls, that tasted a bit like lamb actually, and they were wrapped in a firm "al dente" dough wrap.  They were sitting in a delicious sauce of yogurt with spices and paprika butter.  I loved everything about this.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/troya-fillmore-san-francisco?select=N1w4Th8kXy3RcW_mvdDlXw#IbGoYimiJUdvZlgsqergGw

The flatbreads are also delicious.  I tried the "feta & arugula", and the "lahmacun with minced beef".  The dough had a decent amount of thickness to them, so they weren't quite cracker-thin like I expected, and they did have some softness to them.  There was a nice portion of feta cheese in the former.  And in the latter, the beef was very finely minced and it had a light taste to it.

I've enjoyed the other food as well: the feta cheese cigars, calamari, grilled turkish meatballs, etc.

I've gone here twice for dinner (on a weekday, and on a Friday night), and there never has been a wait. The restaurant wasn't even quite full, but then again, I've only gone before 7pm.  (What can I say.... I'm geriatric.)

Last word of advice... watch out for the bill! Prices will sneak up on you especially after a little wine.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
We had a really good meal at Troya.  Seated promptly, friendly server and the food was very good.  The service was just the right amount of giving us attention when we needed something.  

The ONLY complaint I have is about how the place added the health care tax. It looks like the city requires so much per hour to be paid into the health insurance fund.  I have no problem with that and even if I did, it doesn't matter.  The issue I have is that Troya adds on the tax at the end instead of adding it into the cost on the menu, like most other restaurants have done. 

I would go back for sure because the food and service was enjoyable, but hopefully Troya will read this review and just add the extra charge in their menu prices.
author: Robert G.

description:
Moussaka, truly a delight to eat. My Turkish coworker informed me that an eggplant casserole is mainly what moussaka is. Yummy braised beef, potatoes, tomatoes, bechamel and eggplant. Mouth watering in my opinion, and such a huge portion too. I was thinking about moussaka, and I knew I had to go to Troya to get my moussaka fix. 

Other suggested foods to eat there is the kabobs, all are definitely tender and delicious. I had sampled all of the kabobs the first time I went to Troya with my coworkers. All in all Troya has great Mediterranean food. Next dish to try the Manti.
author: Evelyn B.

description:
The food is nice. The Brussel sprouts are great. 
The server I had, Veronica, was an excellent customer service provider. I train F&B establishments as part of my role at work and Veronica was top notch.
author: S L.

description:
I've walked by this place a million times and kept saying I would try it.

This past weekend I went in on a whim with my girlfriend and we were blown away.
I don't cook so I eat out breakfast, lunch, and dinner everyday - not at cheap eats most of the time... This place was above and beyond.

Excellent food.  Wonderful and friendly service. A bargain for the combination.
author: David K.

description:
When my boyfriend and I first started dating, he gave me three options: a teriyaki place, burgers, or Mediterranean. This was actually not the Mediterranean place he wanted to take me to back on that first date. He specifically said that, "The place I wanted to take you to was first date quality Mediterranean food. Now that we've been dating for a year, you get good Mediterranean food." Well then!

They had some yummy Turkish bread, which I enjoyed immensely. We had the appetizer with three dips and I would have been okay just eating that, but we also ordered lamb. Now, I don't usually eat lamb, so I don't know how to compare it with other places. But the meat was sooo tender and delicious. And it went really well with the Turkish tea, of course!

Soon, I'll ask my Turkish coworkers if they've ever eaten here. I personally enjoyed it, but I was basically there for the bread and the tea. I can live on that stuff if it's good, and boy, was it good. Is it okay to just make bread, dip, and tea a meal? Because I will do it.

I'd go again, but since it's pricey, it'll be saved for those special occasions.
author: Robbin A.

description: This restaurant is wonderful! I love the atmosphere, the space is open and warm, and the tasteful music a perfect volume. The host is welcoming, as any Turk would be! And the food is fantastic! Wonderful Californian appetizers or traditional Turkish dishes, paired with a simple yet comprehensive beer and wine list. Everyone wins here...and you will be stuffed! Enjoy.
author: Hez B.

description:
On a whim, came up to Troya and decided to try it out. They have an unassuming but comfortable decor. Service was nice and prompt. We started with a glass of wine, an order of the small plate of sardines, flatbread and kebabs.

Very good: The lamb kebabs were fragrant, tender and full of flavor. Very delicious.

Average: The lahmajun was ok, nothing outstanding. It felt like it was too saucy and not enough minced meat. Definitely have had better elsewhere. The average portion size is also on the low side - both for small plates and for the entrees.

Poor: The wine pour in the glass was definitely on the low end of 5oz if not even lower. (The wine glass was standard size, not the oversized one). With most establishments pouring 6oz pours, this definitely felt less. In hindsight, we should've ordered a bottle.

Overall, not bad, but given that there are so many great mediterranean/turkish restaurants in SF, it's unlikely we'll go back there.
author: Mo S.

description:
Undercooked (raw) chicken in kebabs.
Cockroach on bar.
Credit card mischarged.
No apology, no manager visit, no items refunded.
Appetizers outrageously priced.
Not coming back.
author: Boner J.

description:
Everyone raves about the moussaka -- just wanted to clarify that is is a very heavy, cheesy dish. It's basically eggplant and braised beef topped with sauce and cheese, baked in a dish. It has pretty much around the same flavor the whole way through. 


Now that that's out of the way, I thought the appetizers were the best part of the meal: 
~ Zucchini Fritters: just as good as everyone says it is! the mint sauce went great with the zucchini and really rounded out the appetizer. 
~ Borek: so flaky and delicious! Probably my favorite dish out of the meal, but I really like flaky dough and spinach and pine nuts.
~ Calamari salad: probably the most ordinary out of the three appetizers; it had a refreshing salad and not too many or too fried calamari. 

As for the restaurant, it just took the place of Citizen Cake, and redecorated it to be a trendy, dimly lit mediterranean place. Great for a casual date or an outing with some friends.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Primarily Turkish, although as is common of that region of the world, there's a lot of overlap in the culinary delights. Expect lamb, dolmas, hummus, olives, flatbread etc. What would otherwise be known as "Middle Eastern" fare.

Nice service, and an interesting ambiance. A little dark, with wood accents. Kind of modern decor. They have several beers on tap, and offer some Turkish beer in bottles, too. I thought that was fun, and worked as a nice compliment to my lamb burger.
author: Wes T.

description: I reallllly like this place, and that must mean some special vibes, because I'm usually allergic to bougie! It might have been the incredible CAULIFLOWER dish, which I felt I could eat every day for at least a week. We also had the lamb bacon small plate, which ended up being a bunch of chopped bacon with some hummus and bread (not what we expected, and I would skip, but no complaints in taste), and the pork chops, which we both felt was okay, but not great. (Note: two small plates and one large plate is definitely enough food for two people. Also, our large plate was not very large, and perhaps we would have gone with just another small instead.) However, something about here intrigues me. I'm considering purchasing a Groupon for round 2. :P
author: Shendi X.

description:
We had reservations at 5:30pm and no one acknowledged us for 15 minutes. They walked by setting up the tables and cleaning but not a single word to us standing by the door. We actually had to stop one of them and ask if they were open yet since our reservation was at 5:30 and at this point it was almost 5:50. 

Secondly the waiter was rude. He comes by and says to us, let me give you a few minutes to look over the menu so that you will have your drink and food order ready so I can take it down at once. I'm sorry are you that busy with no one in the restaurant that you felt the need to say that?!

Thirdly, the food was below average. I've been to many Mediterranean restaurants and this food was mediocre at best. 

If it wasn't for the groupon I had to use, I would have left. Will never be coming here again!
author: Suzanna W.

description:
My friends and I went here to celebrate a birthday.  The venue is small, so they could only accommodate us by having separate tables.  But we weren't far away from each other.

The food was amazing!  I really liked the cheese cigars and the bacon-wrapped figs.  There was a cake cutting fee, but that's usually standard.  I'd like to come back to this place in the spring to see what they put on their seasonal menu.
author: Vira P.

description:
OUTSTANDING TAKE ON TURKISH FARE

Thoroughly enjoyed the brussel  sprouts and, separately, grilled calamari to start; followed by mounds of ribs and, separately, a subtle and extravagantly good beef dumpling dish that, to me, was best of show. All topped off by baclava with homemade vanilla ice cream.

Familiar food on a delightful tilt, fresh and light and good. 

Service was attentive and quick. Was too late in evening for Turkish coffee, but as good a reason as any to return.
author: Kirk K.

description: Tons of open seats for brunch on a Sunday gets a good vote in my book, and the food was good, too! I got the blueberry pancakes, which were a delicious twist on traditional pancakes. I also had the side of hashbrowns which were little potato patties. Quite good!
author: Marcella D.

description: I love this restaurant -- one of my favorites in the city! The lamb shoulder bowl is delicious and the 3 dip appetizer with pita is yummy and perfect for sharing. Fantastic spot for a relaxing dinner with a few friends and great food!
author: Mairead M.

description: Pleased. Ordered to-go as I was staying at a vacation rental down the street. I had the dumplings which is on 7x7's list of 100 things must eat in SF. And yah, I agree.
author: Amy O.

description: The worst falafel in history! Took soooo long to arrive & then it was CRUNCHY (eurgh) & overcooked. It frankly shouldn't have been served & no kitchen with integrity would've. We were here for lunch during the Jazz festival were they offered a limited menu. In this case we decided to share two plates. The falafel came with a dry, dark colored, ungenerous portion of hummus smeared on the bottom of the plate, all covered by a mountain of leaves sprinkled with feta. It was a real mess & you could practically see the owner working out how to make the best margins on the dish. The second dish was a chicken skewer with rice, which tasted pretty good but three small chunks of chicken on the skewer was another very visible cost saving. The service was awful (long wait & we weren't asked whether we wanted a drink so we just drank the table water - their loss). I have wanted to come here for so long - we nearly took an apartment on this street & I mentally clocked it as somewhere to go as I LOVE middle eastern/Mediterranean food, but the search goes on for somewhere in SF that does it well. It certainly isn't here. True disappointment.
author: Fi M.

description: Perhaps they were just off tonight, but I just hades Moussakah delivered that looks and tastes like a ratatouille. My friends chicken is dry and the hummus ... I've just never had hummus this bad. No seasoning whatsoever.
author: MJ T.

description:
Blueberry-less.

This was classic. We went to Troya for Brunch last week and ordered the blueberry pancakes. There were no blueberries. So we flagged the waitress, Melis. We tore the pancakes apart in front of her - still no blueberries. She went back to the kitchen, when she came back she told us that the blueberries were pureed into the batter. I said "Wouldn't the batter be blue-ish in color rather than yellow, and have some remnant of blueberry flavor?" She said "I don't know." I said "And why would you puree blueberries into pancakes anyway? People like blueberry pancakes because they have the little bursts of sweetness." She said "Yeah, I don't know. Do you want some blueberries on the side?" I said "sure". She left, and came back minutes later and said "I'm sorry we have no blueberries in the back." I said "Well then what are they pureeing into the pancake batter?" She said "the chef assures me that there are blueberries blended into the batter." She was trying hard to handle the situation, you could tell she was lost. But we all know, there were no blueberries in the pancakes. We still got charged full price for the pancakes. 

A restaurant that has that little integrity and tries to insult my intelligence gets 1 star. I recommend you go to Elite Cafe or Sweet Maple.
author: Chaucer H.

description:
HELL YES! AMAZING FIND!

I love mediterranean food, but sometimes It can be bland or same old same old. NOT THIS PLACE. 

The food was fantastic! the salad was an entirely new flavor for me and super healthy, the goat cheese sticks were so sweet and savory, and the quince desert was soft and soothing.

The atmosphere was very professional and clean cut. This is a good date spot or for a business lunch. Lots of yuppies and very attractive people. Not a wild and rowdy crowd. 

Overall: great find! must go!
author: Gavin P.

description:
Came here for dinner the other night for the first time and overall, I liked it, but didn't love it.  The atmosphere is cool and modern-ish.  The service was limited, but the food was good.  Overall, this place would get 3.5 stars - and an improvement of the service would probably bump it up to 4 stars.  


FOOD:
   We decided to order a few mezes for the two of us, instead of ordering large plates.  Four mezes for the two of us was plenty of food.  We ordered:

- the cucumber salad with olives and dill vinaigrette:    3.5 stars, decent but nothing special
- the hummus (y'all know what this is), muhummara (roasted pepper and walnut spread), and haydari (turkish yogurt dip) plate which comes with turkish bread:   3 stars, all of the dips were okay, but the bread was not very good
- the feta cheese cigars with honey and pistachios:  4 stars, the combination of salty feta and sweet honey was great
- the grilled calamari with turkish salsa and garlic aioli: 4.5 stars, this dish was really good, definitely a must-try if you like calamari



Overall, this place has pretty good "Turkish-Middle-Eastern fusion" food and it's pretty easy to get a reservation which is a plus.  Even though I wasn't crazy about Troya as a whole, I would give it another try if I'm in the area and La Med is too busy.
author: Juliana K.

description:
Very Tasty: Marinated Olives; Summer Bean Salad; Roasted Brussel Sprouts

Tasty: Lamb Meatballs although a tad bit dry; Pinot Gris wine

Not-so-tasty: Hummus.  Hummus should be a slam dunk but the other evening it was not a slam dunk at Troya Fillmore.
author: Jay D.

description:
Loved this Turkish restaurant! Came here with Vivek A. on a slow Tuesday night. Vegetarians can finally enjoy a Mediterranean restaurant as we made an entire meal of just veg. appetizers!

Food:
+Feta Cheese Cigars- interesting dish bc i've never had anything like it. the feta was salty and the honey and pistachios almost could let it pass as desert; worth a try
+Zucchini Fritters- they were smaller than expected but still pretty tasty!
+Roasted Cauliflower- full of zesty, lemony flavor where you could actually taste the vegetable. def. recommend
+Chanterelle & Leech Flatbread- took a few bites to appreciate the flavor but overall a win
+Erdinger- a fresh and zingy non-alcoholic beer that actually tastes like regular beer but only has 82 calories

Service:
Friendly staff that check in on us multiple times.

Ambience:
Love the modern decor, lighting and high ceilings of this restaurant. It looks super classy but also casual at the same time.

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description:
The food tastes so good! I just wish there was more of it. It's more like a 3.5 for me.

I walked into this restaurant in July with 3 of my friends. We were extremely hungry and the place looked nice. 

We were seated immediately and offered refreshments by the waiter. Service was quick and attentive.

I ordered the muhammara and haydari, which were like bread and hummus. The haydari was a delicious dip for the muhammara. 

Afterwards, I started on my main dish which was lamb kebabs. This dish was also delicious. However, there were only 2 kebabs, which I thought was small for $22. 

When my friends and I finished, we were still a bit hungry but decided to get more food elsewhere. Both the muhammara and the kebabs were small portions. Troya is a nice restaurant with good food, but with the portions they have, you probably will not be full with one order.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Excellent food!  One of the best menus I have tasted on Fillmore Street in 10 years!  Great ambiance and aesthetics.  Try this place!
author: D L.

description: Really delicious food and good service. I wish it were slightly cheaper, but so it goes. It's a nice mid-range option on Fillmore (I.e., somewhere between Tacolicious and SPQR on the fanciness scale) and I LOVE that tables aren't difficult to come by. Especially great service if you sit at the bar.
author: Caroline B.

description:
Mediterranean is by far my favorite food! I find it healthy, normally very light and delicious if made correctly. And I can assure you that Troya does it just right.

I find Troya to be just as yummy as el Mediterranean down the street, however Troya generally is way less crowded and not nearly as noisy. I also believe there menu is a little more creative, which offers some rich tastes.

The had an excellent selection of wine, I was very satisfied with the bottle I choose.

xoxo
author: Noelle L.

description:
Had eaten dinner at the Inner Richmond location, and my review was basically *shrug*

Brunch at the Fillmore location, however, was far better...

My gf and I shared the Troya jams appetizer, a delicious plate of Turkish bread topped with soft cheese, spices, and eggplant and raspberry jams. Both were fantastic. 

My entree was the salmon kebabs, also very tasty. Chunks of fresh salmon and veggies grilled perfectly, all on a bed of spiced chickpeas. Gf got the lentil soup, which she liked but wished our server had mentioned was pureed lentils rather than whole. 

Too full this time for sweets, but will return for the dessert menu for sure!
author: David Z.

description:
Perhaps it's because I had dined at Kokkari in the same week but the food at Troya was very disappointing. Since one of my coworkers recommended this spot to me, I went in expecting to be more than satiated but left feeling completely confused. 

Yes, the restaurant is located in Pac Heights on the bustling Fillmore St and yes, the decor is modern and yes, the service is great, but the food is just completely bland and lackluster. We ordered several apps and entrees and weren't pleased with any of them except the lamb kebab. I will admit that the lamb kebab is tender and juicy and I can even overlook its lack of a solid flavor. However, the sheer miss on all of the other apps and entrees deems this place 3 stars. The only reason it's 2 and not 1 is because of the kebab save. 

The lentil soup is grainy and flavorless and I felt like I was chewing on cardboard while eating the minced beef flatbread - a completely underwhelming experience. 

If you're looking for good Mediterranean food, try another restaurant instead or only come here for the lamb kebabs.
author: Priya S.

description:
Troya was great. All three of us had the salmon kebab dish with chickpeas and cleaned our plates it was so yummy. The dips and housemade Turkish bread were a solid starter, perfect for sharing.

Staff was very friendly. They graciously accomodated an extra person to our reservation and glasses stayed full throughout the meal.

Atmosphere is nice but not stuffy. The place was full on the Friday night we ate there, but we were seated right away at the time of our reservation.
author: Jenny V.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Friday night with the hubby. We have been to Troya for brunch but never dinner until now. 

Grilled calamari - surprisingly tender and tasty, on a bed of tomatoes and small croutons. We only wished the portion wasn't so small! This was an excellent appetizer.

Flatbread with beef - ok but a bit bland tasting 

Lamb kebabs - good but the hubby preferred the side dishes that come with the lunchtime kebab option. 

Overall we like Troya but I think we like their lunch options better than their dinner options.
author: Stella L.

description: Dinner overall was nice. Service was extremely friendly. I give Troya 3 stars for two reasons: 1) the food was bland (was not bad, but not good enough to return), 2) with the food mediocre, I was disappointed to see the menu prices so high. This restaurant has a deal currently on Groupon; if you want to try this place out I recommend buying one to offset the high prices.
author: Samuel R.

description:
Another delicious meal at Troya!  Last night was our 2nd time at the Fillmore location (we've been to the Richmond location 2x as well).  The food never disappoints! 

This time we had 4 small plates (we weren't super hungry) which was just right for 2 for dinner.  The zucchini fritters were amazing!  Super delish and creamy and garlic-y on the inside - stuffed full of tender zucchini, surprisingly light and crispy on the outside.  Everything was great, but these were my faves of the evening.  We also had the grilled calamari - very different from the little fried rings, this was tender-firm little calamari steaks, with a yummy charred/grilled flavor in a tomato salsa with a generous drizzle of super yummy garlic aoli.  The bulgar and lentil salad with almonds, cherries and mint - also wonderfully light and flavorful. A perfect summer salad.  The roasted cauliflower was very nice - with a lemony, green-oniony topping.  

Also great - low noise levels mean you can actually have a conversation with your tablemate.  Service was friendly and fine.  

The bill for 4 small plates (no drinks or wine) was $39 - perfectly reasonable for the quality of the food. We used a $20 Groupon - so on top of it all we got a bargain.  We'll definitely be back!
author: Liz S.

description: Today has been the second time me and my wife had lunch at Troya. This time we sat inside of the restaurant, since there were no tables outside. Even though the place wasn't crowded, we had to wait almost 20 minutes for my tea and 30 for our dishes (I ordered a chicken kebab, my wife falafel). Food was good, but the portions too small for what we spent ($40). Anyway, the young waitress was very helpful, kind and funny. Since the restaurant is not too far from where we live, we will probably come back someday.
author: Laura B.

description: I ordered the chicken wrap off the lunch menu and it was extremely filling. I was surprised by how full I was after lunch but it was worth the ~12 bucks. The inside of this place is spacious and airy which was nice for a rather warm and muggy day in SF. I would encourage people to give this place a try if in the area as they offer tasty Mediterranean food at a decent price point.
author: Manosai E.

description: FOOD was aMAZING! I mean like really really good. Service was good and you just have to save up some money and go here at least once or twice.
author: Ramin A.

description: I am not sure why this place doesn't have 5 stars. My husband and I thought it was spectacular. The food was delightful- the three dips, the lamb meatballs and the mizuna salad- delicious. The lamb kebabs - wow. We had the baclava - it is the best I have ever had! Last but not least- the service was attentive and was excellent!
author: Emmy L.

description: The three stars is for the sweet servers. Really the food and actual level of service was a two. We had to request utensils and they were sort of thrown out willy nilly. I felt everything was overpoweringly spiced and they had no whole milk or half and half for coffee which is odd for a place with an espresso machine. The lamb kebab was charred. We ordered the troika. It didn't come with enough bread so we asked for more. The bread was charged at $3.50 and was not toasty or anything special, just sliced pita. The herbed bread that did come with the troika was greasy and limp. Unfortunately with tip the two of us spent $85.00. I don't mind that price in the Bay Area for quality but we definitely were underwhelmed with the experience.
author: Maria M.

description: Good clean eating!  Nice vegetarian protein options prepared well.  I like the various ancient grain dishes, the cauliflower and the kebabs.  The menu at this location is much better than their other location.
author: Neal M.

description: Troya truly is amazing!! I think my favorite dishes of the night were the brussel sprouts, the cauliflower, and the chicken skewers.  Fried brussel sprouts are always a winner in my book.  The cauliflower was served with a delicious spicy, creamy sauce which was amazing.  Lastly, the chicken skewers were so juicy and flavorful that I hardly could eat any more after all the wonderful appetizers!
author: Meagan T.

description:
So good! I love it here. HIGHLY recommend the lamb meatballs - we have sat with V a handful of times (I think every time we've been there!) and she's great. Super nice, helpful with the menu, and fun to chat with it :) 

Love this place!
author: Whitney K.

description: Have only come here for brunch. Menu changes all the time. I love their brunch dishes. So good, with a slight mediterranean flair. Had omelette and breakfast burrito, with a side salad. Salad is yummy and light. Food here good.
author: Chris C.

description:
We live just a few blocks away and the BF and I walked down Filmore one night to try the new place on the street.  Net - we like this place and will be back :-)  

The space is intimate and cozy - the staff, very welcoming and helpful.  It's the place to be with friends, enjoy a meal and stay awhile.  

We started off with the steamed mussels and split a lentil soup. Yum!  The moussaka was decent but I've enjoyed tastier in the city.  I liked that they had tourkish wines on the menu to try along with the food.  

Next time, I am looking forward to trying their kababs, flatbreads and the milk pudding!
author: Aileen C.

description:
I recommand this place for the delicious food they serve.Fresh, tasteful and lots of flavors.The postachio baklava dessert was marvelous, a nice balance between the sweetness oh honey but not too sweet and the postachio flavor.
I felt the price was right.
author: Agnes F.

description: I've dined at the Clement street location and the food was fantastic there, glad to see another location in the city. We were originally going to go to another restaurant, but the wait was too long and came over here after walking by, and I'm glad we did. The service was top notch, I could not ask for better service. I called the restaurant asking if they had a wait and the host informed me over the phone that she will take my name and possibly have a table when we arrived. 30 seconds later we walk in the host knew that I was the one who called and told us a table was leaving and once they clean it up they can seat us.
