Once we sat down the server gave us some ideas on what to order since we wanted to try them all. Loved the hummus plate and the lamb; it made us wanting more. Troya you are #1 go to place for Turkish food.
author: Matthew L.

description:
This place had a better menu than the one on Clement.  Food was good may just try all the appetizers next visit.  

Service was excellent atmosphere was great.  Spend the afternoon shopping and try this place.  Make a reservation.

Enjoy !!
author: Jennifer T.

description: The atmosphere is nice and service great. The actual taste of the food was okay. I wanted to like it more but something was missing. We ordered the meatball in yogurt sauce and something was missing in terms of flavor. There wasn't the delight/surprise factor to it.
author: J M.

description:
With all the varied food options on Fillmore, I won't be returning by choice.  It wasn't horrible but it really didn't feed my hunger or soul, which is something I expect from Mediterranean food.  My roommate and I shared the beef dumplings and the lamb kabob plate and were still really hungry 2 plates and $40 later.  The kabob plate was far from worthy of its $19 price tag and the beef dumplings seemed bland to me.  Maybe we were just grumpy because our wine glasses seemed  lacking in quantity for the price as well.

It was really empty the weeknight that we ate there so it was pretty quiet and a bit chilly but it's a pleasing space with a woody-modern feel and the service was fine.  Maybe Troya would be more tolerable if I approached it like a quiet wine bar and stuck to a bottle of wine and an app or two.  I definitely wouldn't bring anyone here that I wanted to impress though.
author: Krystle S.

description: I've been here 3 times and each time, the food and service has consistently delivered. Their hummus combo is always worth getting. They usually have some sort of voucher promo going on, so definitely scout for that. Great spot for date night or a casual catch-up with a friend... and the best part: it's in the shopping district of Pac Heights, my favorite neighborhood!
author: Diana K.

description:
I probably will never go back here again. While the service was good, the food and the price were not. We all felt acid reflux after eating the food. The portions were really small (main entries) and the food was not tasty at all. Totally a medium ranking for flavor. 

Without any alcohol the check came to $120 (for 5 people). We ordered 3 main dishes and 3 appetizers.
author: T I.

description: I think I found my benchmark for 3 stars. Nothing wrong with the place yet nothing memorable. So utterly average that without this rating being recorded I will forget about the food in a few days. There are other places on Fillmore try before ending up here
author: David B.

description:
Came here excited for Turkish food and was served a heaping plate of disappointment. 

Haydari was a tiny serving with two pieces of bread. 

Manti was undercooked and understuffed. 

Lahmacun was average and overpriced. 

Service was good and the setting was nice...but it couldn't make up for the bland food.
author: Jake B.

description:
Oh man, I think I prefer this Troya to the one in Richmond.  Thankfully the amazon deal steered us here after last week's mistake at the aforementioned location.  The neighborhood, energy and feel to this place was just so much more up our alley.  The menu is a bit different than the other...Kabobs come dressed and sided differently as well as the knafeh (dessert).  
I LOVED the roasted cauliflower, soooo delicious!  The lentil soup was also very tasty and I was totally into the little cracker sticks served in the beginning.  
For dessert we got the pistachio baklava and knafeh, both DELICIOUS!  HIGHLY recommend both of them.
Price aligns with other similar cuisine and style.  About $60 for apps, entree and dessert (no drinks).
author: Amber E.

description:
We had dinner here once and enjoyed it a lot. 
Being of greek heritage, the food resonates with me and reminds me my grandmother's cooking.

We came in the other day for brunch, carting along our 14 month old and the staff was courteous, thoughtful and didn't mind her at all.
The food was excellent (I had baked eggs, hubby had the omelet) and the kid enjoyed the pita with the smears. The tea was great and the coffee was lovely.

I take the food being great as granted, which is a little bit unfair, so I will speak highly about the fact that this was a Saturday brunch time on Fillmore and we were able to sit somewhere stress-free with our toddler (the thought of going to Grove at that time already had me stressing out). 

I think we found our favourite new brunch spot for the foreseeable future :)
author: Mirto H.

description:
Decent food and nice waiter but ...overpriced for what you get. 

Started with hummus. A little funny tasting and served with a bread roll rather than pita. 
Had the beef dumplings. This is a small dish with quite a bit of yogurt sauce. Would be better as a side dish. 

Wife had lamb kabob. It was tasty, but far from outstanding. Again, small portion.
author: M R.

description: Mediocre is a good word to describe the food..and the service. I am not particularly impressed by anything on the menu after going here 3 times.
author: Kate M.

description: I found this through Amazon coupon.  I love breakfast food and service was nice.  Recommend this restaurant!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
I will be back again!! I came here with the manfriend on a belated valentines. Love the atmosphere. The staff is incredible, very attentive and friendly. 

Feta cheese 'cigars' to dip in hot honey and crushed pistachio. Need I say more? Deep fried awesomeness. 

Fried calamari over an arugula salad. The calamari went really well with the fresh citrus taste and bite from arugula. 

Lamb kebab. I'm not a lamb person. But it came highly recommended. And I was so glad I tried it. The smoky eggplant purée complements the kebab and the lamb was so juicy.  

Chocolate pot de cream. The deep chocolate marries well with the tartness from the yogurt whipped topping. I'm a chocolate fiend. 

The pistachio baklava with homemade ice cream. All the food was incredible. But I could have dreams about this baklava. It is very sweet but I find that part of its appeal. And it was watery but in a good way not too heavy in an overwhelming syrup way. 

I can't wait to come back with my brother and his wife. And get everything we had already and try others as well. :)
author: Glessie C.

description: Food is bland and their prices are not worth my wallet. Thought it'd be good to try them, but would rather go to Tuba instead. Portions and flavor combined are 10x better than.
author: Lola M.

description:
My favorites were the mushrooms and yogurt and the lentil soup. 

The Turkish meatballs and muhammara dip were also good. 

The feta cheese "cigars" with honey and pistachios were unique, and their fish was good, but what gets this place 4 stars in particular is the ambiance--they do a great job with it, and it's a nice addition to Fillmore Street.
author: Mike G.

description:
I have never had a more perfectly timed meal in my life! Literally each dish came out as soon as we finished the other. Every dish was spectacular! I appreciated that our waitress was Turkish, she made the recommendation of sharing the Turkish Beef Dumplings, they were tiny, but so delicious and actually quite filling with the yogurt sauce. Here's what you should get:

- feta cigars
- chanterelle and leek flatbread
- turkish beef dumplings


They serve this awesome flatbread with zaatar to start and some olive tapendae. Great place for a birthday, a date or parents in town!
author: Sonya S.

description: Came here with a Groupon, and I'm glad I did because now I will be a patron! I think many of the people who reviewed this restaurant are on point: the small plates outshine the larger ones, and the simplest plates are the most surprising. We got the hummus with lamb bacon - which was our absolute favorite. But the flatbread, which we were looking forward to the most, was our least favorite. I also highly recommend the pots de creme if you have room for dessert - it's made with Turkish coffee and you can really taste the flavors. Probably the best pots de creme I've ever had. Can't wait to come back and to try some more of the menu!
author: Convict T.

description: Amazing wild salmon entree plus warm olives made for a lovely meal tonight. Wonderful service seated at the bar as well. Great neighborhood gem. On the pricier side, but believe it's worth it. Lastly, got the pistachio baclava for takeaway but a half hour later, it tasted well past its expiration date and neglected. So only one issue with meal but otherwise, pretty good meal.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Ate here on Sunday night with my two adult children and wife.  It was wonderful.  Warm, cozy room; not fancy, just well designed and nice.  I had the pork shoulder, which was moist and and flavorful.  Everyone loved their dinner.  Great wine list and terrific selection by the glass.  Service was attentive but not fawning.  Just friendly and helpful.  Prices were reasonable.  Not cheap, but the value was there.
author: Mike R.

description:
Love this place! Great food and service.
Good spot for a date or group dinner. Definitely get the feta fritters- so good!
author: Erin G.

description:
I went to this restaurant (Fillmore location) with my family last weekend and we loved the food! It was so flavorful and tasty! We had the hummus appetizer; the homemade pita bread that came with it was divine, and the combo of hummus, fruits and nuts was just perfect! Our entrees, the lamb meatball Mediterranean wrap and the lamb kebab, were also really good! The flavors in their food is just right, the only thing that was just ok was the rice that came with the lamb; it tasted a little plain. Service was attentive (although at the time there were not many patrons in the restaurant so there was no excuse not to be, but still) and friendly, the interior of the restaurant was very urban chic, and there was enough room even for a high chair for our daughter without feeling squeezed (not guaranteed in SF restaurants). The only complaint I might add and the reason I gave this place four instead of five stars is that there were two bathrooms, but neither had a changing station for babies even though one of them was big enough to have one. As a mom, this is a new pet peeve of mine (something I never paid attention to prior to becoming a parent, but now it's very important... nothing worse than having to put a moving baby on a bathroom floor to change her diaper, hoping she will not roll off the changing mat onto the dirty floor!)

We would definitely eat here again, we would just make sure our daughter has on a fresh diaper before we go in (or better, management could install a diaper changing station in one of the bathrooms!!) :)

Delete review
author: Elisabeth M.

description:
I came here for my birthday dinner with a group of 7. We decided to get an assortment of small plates and a few large plates and share as a group, which was a great idea since all the food was amazing (NOTE: the portions are not big, so if you are with a larger group and don't know everyone well, it might be awkward to cut a meatball in half...ya know?). Anyway, the food was amazing. The lamb kebabs were the best I've ever had. Everyone loved the meatballs, too. But seriously, everything was incredibly delicious. If you save room for dessert, go for the baklava. Served warm with vanilla ice cream. Nothin' better than that.

Also, our server was super sweet - we accidentally added tip even though it was included, and she chased us down the street after to correct the error.
author: Margot Z.

description:
Much better experience this time. Everything we had was great: the sigara böreği (feta cigar borek), dolma, cucumber salad, meze plate, mücver (fritters) mantı (beef dumplings) and lamb kebab. Everything cooked to perfection and very tasty. I love their Californian-Turkish approach to their menu. Eating the cigar börek of my childhood with honey and pistachios sounded weird at first but worked perfectly. 
Only complain the prices are a bit high but if you're willing to spend some and eat some great Turkish food this is the place to go.
author: Cihan G.

description:
I think it's one of the best mediterranean restaurant in the bay area.  
They use organically grown products and offer a creative menu that has a lot of gluten free, vegetarian and paleo diet choices. I taste everything on the menu that they were all delicious. my favorites are roasted asparagus, cauliflower, meatball, lamb bacon, red lentil soup, turkish spreads, all flatbreads, lamb kebab and hanger steak. 
as a dessert, kunefe's taste amazing and pot de creme is the best in the city. 
you can also enjoy selective wine list and decent ambience. 
Should try lunch which is totally different than dinner. very reasonable price for healthy food. love falafal plate and beef brisket wrap!
author: nagme u.

description: What a great find!  Turkish food on Fillmore...it was delicious.  Had the meze platter (not sure if that was what it was called on the menu but it had an assortment of hummus and dips) and the fried haloumi cheese.  Bliss in the mouth!
author: Priya R.

description:
A modern looking restaurant with nice ambiance and service.

Thumbs up for the Brussel Sprouts and Calamari as starters.

The Grouper special as well as the Lamb Kebabs were delicious.
author: Francis M.

description: The worst eating experience in san francisco.. Chicken wrap and chicken dish is too bad.. They dont have kids menu.. We ordered french fries for the kids and they bring us a plate of trash.. We ordered bread and they bring pita with full of olive oil on it.. Never go again never..
author: Melo K.

description: Love this place, especially for lunch.  The wraps are really good, as is the red lentil soup and salads.  I am usually here for weekday lunch so can't really speak to the wine selection....but the food is always excellent and service is great.
author: Coco L.

description:
HAPPY MEAL:
1 zucchini fritters
1 anatolian eggplant (flatbread pizetta type thing)
1 braised chicken
1 chocolate pot due creme
-----
total: $43.40 (w/out tip)

Get the above and you will not leave disappointed, I promise you.

Our server was trying to sell us the chicken kebabs but I'm glad we opted for the braised chicken stew as it was SO much more flavorful, and really not that hard to share despite it being bone-in.

The chocolate pot due creme had this orange oil flavor going on and I'm salivating just remembering it . . . yeah, that good!

Haven't been to the other location, but this one was a little hipster-y, clean lines, nice lighting -- helpful and nice servers, and I can't wait to come back to try more stuff!
author: Anjali V.

description:
This restaurant has gone south since opening a couple of years ago. I had not been in a few months and won't return. Rancid oil on the salad dressing. Stale seasonings on flatbread. Red lentil soup tasted and looked like navy bean. Hummus app nothing great, and cauliflower saute heavy and greasy.

Tasteless Pinot, and a poor pour at that.

Waitress didn't want to answer our questions and rushed us until I asked her if we were bothering her...

SO many other options in The City...why waste money and taste buds here.
author: Banthehoodie A.

description: Certainly a good restaurant, but I am not sure if it is as good as the price level sugests. I am very sad that the old Troya disappeared...
author: Axel B.

description:
Muhammara... I love you. 

Troya has two of my favorite things in the world: olives and muhammara. I learned about muhammara after getting tired of hummus and grabbing a 1/2 pint of it at Molly Stones one day and Troya has some. It's pretty good, I don't have a great knowledge of muhammara yet. I will travel to its home town at some point in the near future. 

The service here is great. They've very observant and are on top of everything from a client prospective. Cheers to great management.

I'd recommend this place for dates or parties of 4. It's got a great first date type ambience. 

I don't think the food is over the top amazing but it's 3.5 stars (I rounded up) and a welcome addition to Pac Heights - Fillmore street and 1 block from my house.
author: Michael S.

description:
Second time eating here was even better than the first.  Everything I have tried on the menu on the menu is very good and the service is friendly and attentive.  A nice selection of wines by the glass...I enjoyed my meals here both times.  
Slightly on the expensive side for the amount of food but if you are dining with skinny female friends you will be ok. 
A welcome addition to the neighborhood.
author: Nilu r.

description: food was great, wait staff deserve 7 stars. Went on a first date here and the staff helped me out to no end. Highly approved!
author: Nic K.

description:
This place opened in the neighborhood for quite a while now, I was resistant to try it out because it is where my dear citizen cake used to be.

It is great! We had the humus, pasturma, marinated lamb kebab and the lavash wrap.

The marinated lamb kebab was delicious but to be honest the wrap was something else. The dough was so crispy that didn't even get soggy after dipping it.

Will go back.
author: Bea L.

description:
Walked in on a Tuesday evening and was seated instantly at 5:30pm .  The place was empty except for 2 solo diners seated at the bar.  They had the nerve to ask if I had reservations...who cares!  

My gf & I ordered all to share - 
Zucchini Fritters with Mint & Yogurt - it was kinda weird.  Almost had the texture of sprouts.  Grilled Turkish Meatballs with haydari & pickles - these were just ok, very lamby.  Hummus, Haydari & Muhammara with House Made Turkish Bread - bland.  Roasted  Cauliflower with spring onion &  urfa - our fave dish of the evening.  Fried Calamari with Garbanzo Beans, Arugula & Fennel - weird flavor.  Lahmacun Flatbread, Minced beef, Chilies, Onions, Garlic & Paprika - super weird!  My gf had to add salt too.  

I don't know maybe I don't have the taste buds to appreciate and like the dishes but I definitely don't need to come back & wasn't a meal to note in the books.  It was pricey too - $101 without tip.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Good not great. The food was tasty but not stupendous. The wait staff was very authentic which was great, however there were a few mixups that were lost in translation.

At first pass the interior seems very posh, however they need to ditch the white-bracket mirror holders along the brick wall - it looks a bit tacky. I would also go for paper towels in the basket move instead of the old hand dryer. Fix those two things, throw some art on the walls and this place will be rockin.
author: Jason M.

description:
Yum!

The roasted cauliflower is fresh and delish with Mediterranean spices. The feta cheese cigars were so-so. The lamb kebab was pretty good too.

But the most special and memorable dish is the turkish beef dumplings with yogurt and spices. Imagine raviolis in a cream sauce ---- only lighter and more delicious.  I'm glad they're in the neighborhood. I've been back at least twice...
author: Sarah T.

description: wow what a great new neighborhood gem in Fillmore! we enjoyed all of our dishes especially the turkish meatballs and the zucchini cakes. our server was super friendly and helpful (he recommended his favorite dish - the turkish meatballs - and they were delicious!). thanks for a great meal! we can't wait to come back.
author: Helen Y.

description: Great food. Everything with cheese is good! And the best: they actually have real coca cola in a bottle and not that dispenser thing. Def coming back.
author: Hanna A.

description: So the food is actually really good..the service sucked.  I went there this past Sunday for brunch to celebrate my husband's birthday.  The menu offers "freshly squeezed OJ"...so we ordered two.  The waiter was hesitant and said it wasn't made yet--so we said no problem--we'll wait.  Five mins later, he said it was coming.  Cool!  Then we see another employee walk in with 2 jugs of OJ from elsewhere.   uhhh that's no freshly squeezed.  Then they proceeded to serve this store-bought OJ (and have the nerve to charge as if it's fresh).  When it was served, we asked again if it was freshly squeezed and the waiter said yes.  LIAR.  It was disgusting.  It was carbonated...how is that fresh?!  We sent it back.  The original waiter came back and said sorry you didnt like the OJ.  We told him it wasnt fresh and tasted like it was old.  So he apologized and said he'd bring us so more bread.  THEN HE CHARGED us for the apology bread!!!!  WHAT THE HECK!   I'm pissed that they lied and tried to dupe us on the OJ and then charge us for something he offered and we didn't order. He never asked about the bread, just said "i'm so sorry, let me bring you some more bread"  Second service issue was that the check was put on our table before we were even done.  SUCKS
author: Nisha K.

description:
Classic jams.

Classic Troydan jam: http://open.spotify.com/track/4EB5OK4cY1TwDRUTQrGzUG

Classic Troya jam: Grilled bread layered with creamy cheese and then topped with eggplant jam and citrus marmalade.

Knew citrus could be a jam, no idea eggplant could as well. It is and it's amazing.

After marveling at the first round we moved on to a baked egg with peppers and cheese second round. Great, gooey and gigantic for two people. We gave it our all.

Last but not least was a roasted chicken wrap with pesto swapped out for hummus. Each half was almost full size. More splitting. More loving.

Sipped and savored a simply sweet Turkish coffee throughout.

Be sure to add Troya to your brunch playlist.
author: Jason B.

description: Consistently excellent food and a cool modern space . Very fresh food, creative and great attentive service. We are thrilled that they now serve brunch on Saturday and Sunday starting to 10 am. So great for our neighborhood as other places like Jane are booked solid with a line out the door in the mornings. It is easy to get a spot at the bar or a table. In my opinion this is one of the best kept secrets in our neighborhood. I also recommend this for those looking to keep healthy.
author: Amanda J.

description:
I just finished a divine dinner at Troya. I knew it was a new restaurant (I had read about it on sf-eater) but I didn't realize that tonight was only its 3rd night open!

I was especially surprised because the service was attentive and impeccable. The staff already had great rhythm and timing which was amazing considering that it's such a new place. Our server Caitlin was spot-on, took great care of us and guided us through the menu skillfully.

Starter:
Spinach Borek -- Savory and light -- perfect thing to whet our appetite

Entrees:
Manti (Turkish dumplings with a yoghurt sauce) - Turkish comfort food heaven!
Lamb Kabobs with Eggplant puree - Perfectly cooked lamb with tender, tasty veggies

Dessert:
Nightingale Nest Style Baklava with homemade vanilla ice cream - My first time having this denser style of baklava.  Hints of cardamon, pistachio with complemented by the vanilla ice cream.

It was a complete pleasure to dine there and I look forward to coming back!
author: Freida N.

description:
Delicious and creative food made with fresh ingredients.
Great value.
author: Theo F.

description:
Troya Fillmore shows how much food depends on predilections and taste.  The place is nicely refurbished, the service is good, with a more mediterranean than Turkish slant.  So I prefer the food at Troya Clement where Turkey reigns supreme. For you it may be otherwise.    

I started with lentil soup.  It was good.  Livened by the lemon wedge on the plate.  I could have used another wedge to wake the soup still further.

Fried calamari with beans, fennal and arugula was nice enough, although I felt the seasoning to be an acquired taste.

Braised lamb dolmas with pine nuts, currents and tahini were just OK.  The lamb being overwhelmed by their wrap.

The star of my meal was roasted cauliflower with spring onions and urfa.  Perfectly roasted and a very ample portion well suited to sharing.  The cauliflower was to come at the same time as the dolmas but there was a miscue either on the part of my server or the kitchen.  There was an appropriate apology.  

So, there you have it: if one Troya is not your special thing, then the sister restaurant will likely become a favorite.  For me, Troya Clement is it.
author: David D.

description: Really good Mediterranean food! We got the chicken kebabs, mushroom flatbread, and hummus and it was more than enough for two people! Great service too!
author: Jillian C.

description: Yum! Best Turkish food I've found yet. Fresh and tasty. Mix in a couple bottles of wine and you're all set for a quality experience. Request Lisandro. He's the man. Very charming and a pleasure to be served by! Check it out. Thumbs up!
author: Jimmy L.

description: Great breakfast at this place this morning Veronica was very nice and helpful , as a local in pac heights I will definitely be back to try there great looking dinner menu
author: Paul O.

description:
Good ambience and food isn't ridiculously over priced. 

It took about 15 minutes to get a take out meal. I did order lamb so that dish might require more preparation. 

As far as the quality of the food goes,its very very very BADDDD... they don't serve any rice with the entrees... either that or they just forget to give it to me in my take away order...
author: Abhi M.

description: Great customer service.. Had hummus plate, chicken kababs, falafel and Brussel sprouts - everything was great. A bit pricey but overall yummy!
author: Harleen P.

description: I wanted to like this place but was disapointed. Food was presented well but everything lacked flavor. The lamb kebobs had no lamb flavor and needed salt, the grilled calamari were underwhelming and seemed old, my manti beef dumplings also lacked flavor. Even the tzaziki was uninspiring. Too bad. Skipped desert.
author: Matt A.

description: I had lamb kebab. The food was correct, not breathtaking, but by all means tasty. I liked that the kebab came with green salad and was well balanced in the amount of meat, salad and roasted vegetables. The accompanying eggplant paste did not have a flavour definite enough to really add a substantial accent to the taste of the kebab. When the dish arrived, it occurred that there is no staple included, so I had to hold on and wait for bread; it would have positively contributed to the experience if the waiter suggested the side of lavash bread upfront. The ambiance is nice and classy. My overall opinion is that this is an OK American restaurant serving Mediterranean food, but there are better options if you are looking for something not that classy but more authentic.
author: Grzegorz J.

description:
If you're familiar with Troya on Clement street, the new Troya is slightly upscale of that.  Plates are smaller, service is posh (they have a Cultery Boy), and it'll cost you $45 a person before you're done.

The food, however, will be worth it.  Highlights from dinner: Turkish bread, spinach boreks, manti ("Turkish beef dumplings"), "flatbread", and the baklava.  I think this may be the only restaurant in San Francisco where you can get authentic, hand-made manti.  And I generally don't like baklava and don't eat it anywhere but Troya.  It's that good.

Note that the meze plates are small. If you choose to make a meal entirely from meze, you'll need 2-3 plates per person.  This is a good thing, it keeps you from option paralysis on the menu.  Just order one of everything!

Everything is made in-house from scratch.  While waiting for the bathroom, I watched one of the Turkish owner's female relatives supervising the kitchen staff.

They've kept the decor and furnishings from the former Citizen Cake, so it's all hard surfaces; Troya will be very noisy once it's full.  Wine selection is modest but affordable, and includes some Greek and Turkish wines.

Should definitely be on your list of options for dining on the Fillmore next time you go.
author: Josh B.

description:
Really enjoyed our meal here last night. We walked in on a whim and were pleasantly surprised by this spot. The decor is modern and rustic. The service was efficient and professional.
We ordered several small plates for sharing, all of which were terrific. The flavors were seasonal and fresh. The dolmas alone are worth the trip. They are rich and tender, a bit spicy too. SO good.
Portions are somewhat small but it's reasonably priced so you can order several items to try. Dinner for 3 with wine was just about $100.
Their brunch menu also looks delicious. I look forward to trying that next time.
author: Heather H.

description:
Turkish Bread:  At $2 a pop, its nothing special and kind of dry.  We had to ask for olive oil and butter.   We got olive oil.   I guess 1 out of 2 isn't bad

Beef Dumplings:   Looked good but didn't taste all that great.  It was underseasoned so we had to ask for some salt.   Not sure that I'd order this dish again. 

Brussels Sprouts:   Was the tastiest dish we had;  Sprouts were seasoned with a Turkish spice and an eggplant dip.

The biggest reason for the 2 stars-  The service.  Its the kind of staff that gives off an annoyed vibe because they're being asked for something.    We hightailed it out of there and got dessert elsewhere.
author: Fred X.

description:
My friend and I happened upon this place randomly for dinner. Overall we were thrilled. The food was GREAT. The cauliflower is TO DIE FORRRRRR. I highly recommend it. We also got the beets salad which was also amazballs. I really like the bread too and the hummus like dips were great (forget the names). 

Overall - had an amazing time here. Super simple and cute place.
author: Lillian S.

description:
Organic meat for my kabobs? 
Stylish environs for the fancy-full?
A 5 min walk from my doorstep and no wait on a Sat eve to dinner with the hubster?

Things came fresh off the grill, and didn't disappoint. Welcome to the neighborhood!
author: Rachel S.

description:
Solidly delicious Mediterranean food.

Plusses:
1.) central location on Fillmore street, 
2.) fact that there is usually not a wait, 
3.) friendly, professional service
4.) YUMMY food.
5.) Moderate prices - great value for money

No minuses to speak of.  I loved everything I had here.
author: Tina T.

description:
I think this place is great! food was tasty and yummy they had a variety on the menu. I would definitely come back.

customer service was very friendly and welcoming.
author: Veronica V.

description:
A little underwhelming.

We went in last night and was pretty excited to try the new entrant to the Fillmore neighborhood. I had already had dinner so was just going to pick at food while my companion chowed down. First off, loved the look of this place. Red brick, wood panels at the bar, and wonderful unique lighting really enhance the space and totally match my decor style.

We ended up ordering:
Hummus, Haydari & Muhammara with House Made Turkish Bread -- The walnut pesto spread was tasty but the other two were a little disappointing. The hummus was not the creamy homemade goodness I was expecting, and the strained yogurt was pretty bland except for some dill mixed in. Probably would not get again, especially since they have a spicy side sauce that was tastier than all of them that you can get for free.
Marinated Lamb Kebab with Onions, Peppers & Eggplant Puree -- Apparently very very good lamb. The kebabs themselves were very tasty (according to my dining buddy) though two things that were offputting: 1. they wouldn't accomodate one chicken skewer and one lamb so that he could try more of the menu and 2. while the eggplant puree was excellent to pick at, the skewers don't come with any rice or anything to really turn the kebab into a meal.

They have a pretty limited menu which isn't a big deal if you have some heavy hitting golden dishes but I just didn't see those here. Limited veggie entrees (just a veggie kebab) so would recommend adding some there. 

Had good drinks. Their New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc was excellent and they have a red Turkish beer (forgetting the name) which was very tasty as well.

I'm sure they'll enhance the menu and get better in time. Will probably try back in a few months.
author: Raina B.

description:
"Yay! I'm a fan!"

Troya Fillmore was great for our lunch today. the decor, food, service.. all of them was just superb. I am not the biggest fan of mediterranean cuisine.. but I really enjoyed their food today.

we started with the lentil soup:
delicious; not too heavy, bland.. just perfect amount of richness and flavor. 

followed by chicken lavash wrap and lamb kebab.

they were nicely portioned and really tasty.. i don't know that much of the cuisine, but it was really tasty. 

I would go there anytime for lunch.. I can't quite remember how it was at Troya Clement for dinner.. but i know i enjoyed there. This place seems a bit low'er' key and hip.. and I dig it. It's also very reasonably priced as well.
author: Sung C.

description: Had a nice Groupon dinner here last night, attentive friendly service +wine talk from Veronica, my bro and I sat at the bar which was pleasant.  Two-top tables are too small and too close together for my taste --- as my bro said, "I don't really want to listen to someone's weak conversation on their first date" and it looked like a lot of first dates going on :  )  Crowd is a bit older, like 40s-50s? but dishes we ordered were tasty --- grilled calamari with red beans was spicy and good, lamb kebabs also good but kinda small, make sure you get PITA flatbread b/c the Turkish bread looked like an onion roll from Costco but I kinda liked it.  Good Turkish caffe
author: Michael G.

description:
Went here last night with the bf and it was delicious!!! Its more of a Turkish cuisine but similar to Mediterranean and Persian food. 

We started with the trio of dips, hummus, takizi and red one (not sure what it was). The turkish bread came with it that everyone raves about and yes it was good. The yogurt one was a little thicker and super tangy which I just loved.

Then we split the beef dumplings-- this was soooooooo flipping good!!!!!!!! Get this get this get this. It was a yogurt sauce over it, and it reminds me of raviolis.  Super garlicy which I enjoyed though it was in my mouth the entire night.

The bf got a Turkish beer which he enjoyed too, nice and light.
author: Jess O.

description:
In the city for GGT Bridge celebrations, we decided to stop by Fillmore for a bite.I knew that one of my favorite restaurants had opened a second location there.
What a lovely job they did with the interior.
Zuccini Fritters,Borek w.Spinach, Eggplant Flatbread, grilled meatballs and Moussaka all were outstanding. Bakklava w. ice cream yummy.
Wine menu was well designed also with interesting wines by the glass.
It was crowded but service kept moving along. Our whole party was very happy by the time we left and we will definitely be  back.
author: Maria C.

description:
I had the lamb dolmas , olives, bread and hummus. It was great. 
They figured out how to give not enough of their awesome bread to dip in the humus . Then you order more and they give you too much and you run out of hummus, so you have order more of that... And so on and so on and more of the same and etc etc.
author: Porch G.

description:
We were searching for a vegetarian friendly dinner place to enjoy with friends and jumped at the chance to try Troya.  We started with the hummus plate which we inhaled within minutes of it arriving at the table.  After we ate all the provided bread, they brought out more crispy crackers for dipping too.  The lentil soup soon followed.  Our friends enjoyed the hummus and soup so much they didn't have room for their vegetable kebabs! 

We split several apps including the fried zucchini, feta cigars with honey dipping sauce, and the cauliflower (which was the most popular dish of the evening).  It's a shame we were almost too stuffed with all the other delicious dishes to enjoy it!

In addition to the excellent meal, we appreciated the quiet ambiance and helpful staff.  Great job Troya!
author: Kim K.

description: This place is a little pricey, but the food is tasty. The service is standard, but the space is nice and usually wide open on weekends around brunch time. I wanted to try Manti since they're on the 7x7 Big Eats list for 2013, but they didn't have them on the menu for lunch. The waitress asked if they'd make them anyway for me, and they did, so that was nice. (They tasted ok. The yogurt to manti ratio was a little bit high for my tastes, but that's a personal thing.)
author: Maya G.

description: So bad. I ordered the chicken wrap and paid 12$ for a burnt wrap with charcoal tasting pita and chicken. The grill obviously hadn't been cleaned in a long while. I told the waitress I only took 3 bites but still paid. Lovely interior and music, but unfortunately I will not be returning.
author: Bonnie N.

description:
I was definitely impressed walking into Troya.  They did a great job decorating the place, and it looks immaculate inside.  Surrounded by so many great restaurants on Fillmore st, Troya is a fine selection for semi-upscale Mediterranean cuisine.

I ordered the lamb kabob which came with an eggplant puree that complimented the meat and roasted veges very well.  The lamb was tender, flavorful and cooked just right.  At $19 for 2 skewers I felt like I could have used a bit more on the plate, but I'll settle for what I had.

Although this is labeled as a Turkish restaurant, it's not a great depiction of Turkish food.  I enjoyed what I ate, but it's more general Mediterranean/American fusion cuisine than traditional Turkish.

With all that said, I'd recommend Troya to spend some fine time with a date, friend or by yourself.
author: Natan O.

description:
Troya has become one of my favorite spots on Fillmore.  Unique Mediterranean food with a great variety of menu.  The atmosphere can vary based on day (mid week vs weekends) but overall it's become one of my go-to spots. 

Turkish Dumplings are a must.  Feta Cigars are unique and tangy.  No need to order the starter bread (not much too it). Salmon special is delicious. Babaganoush is pretty good. And I would recommend the Chicken Skewers.

Not every dish is a home-run, but I appreciate the concept and enjoy my go-to dishes. 

Check it out!
author: Renae K.

description: The kunefe dessert at Troya is definitely a must try! I wasn't sure what to expect when the server told me that it had cheese, but the combination of flavors works surprisingly well. The dessert was delicious! I will definitely be going back soon for more.
author: Natasha J.

description: good food, European serving sizes and moderate to high pricing. the servers were attentive and helpful which is always nice. would go back with another groupon and try to get better parking. the parking is outrageous! $4.50 an hour at the meters and if you use a credit card they charge you more!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
SO impressed by the food and service.

Muhammara was refreshing, light and absolutely delicious! Please get it!
Lamb kebab: 4 stars
Chicken kebab: 5+ stars. I'm getting takeout of this dish right NOW cuz it's so damn good!
author: Emily T.

description:
Fun place with 4 different sections allowing for various dining experiences: The bar is unique with attractive downward lights, the back row of tables has one long  bench sitting against a brick wall (artistically matching an attractive painting), the front row of table has a bit of a modern look, and the communal high table. Oh, and a secluded single window side table. 

I went with friends who, like me, were interested in sampling. First of all, the wine list seems to have been set by a professional tasteful sommelier. The Pinot Noir from NZ is excellent. There were at least 3 French wines that were all good. Apparently, the delicious fresh bread is by an authentic baker. The chef added items that are different from the menu at the original Troya (on Clement) such as mussels, Calif cod fish, and a selection of flat bread items (similar to pizza but folded along the sides to a boat-like shape). Zucchini fritters were light and tasty. The fish was perfectly cooked (the only item on the menu above $20 which is reasonable for high quality fish). Moussaka (eggplant-based dish) was very good but I wish they have it also as vegetarian. 

We chose the communal table which allowed for an overview of the entire restaurant. It also allowed us to socialize with a nice group of people who chose to sit there as well. Great for a single diner if you want to carry on conversation with strangers over dinner. And I would say the same about the bar where I sat waiting for my friends and was nicely welcomed by the owner (real cool person!) and staff. Although we were so full but we didn't want to pass on the desserts. Glad we didn't: we ended up sharing a floating flan-like cultured served in a cute little jar and a large kanafeh (shreded wheat with sweet light cheese). Both were delicious. 

Over all,  we had a great experience and would definitely go back and probably soon.
author: amy k.

description: My roommate and I decided to go here and though this place is a bit expensive the food here is really good!! We went all out and ordered appetizers and dessert and came back with full stomachs and happy faces
author: Meher S.

description: We were there for lunch and had no idea what to expect. I can tell you: it was sooo good! We had to wait a bit, but it was all fresh and absolutely yammi!
author: Cornelia I.

description: Billed as Turkish, not sure what is Turkish about this place. It is "Mediterranean" and the food is OK, if not spectacular. Interior is nice and the service is good. Good for meat eaters or vegetarians. Worth trying if you are in this neighborhood, but not really a destination. Not as good as La Méditerranée, but not bad either.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I found Troya on Yelp but had never heard of it before.  A special thanks to my fellow Yelpers because Troya was amazing! 

I went with a group of friends and we just ordered a bunch of dishes and shared them all. 

The humus platter was great (although we needed to order another side of bread), the feta "cigars" were perfect with the honey dip and the calamari was like nothing I've ever tried before. The calamari came more like a salad - which was a surprise but it was done so perfectly - I couldn't have asked for anything better. The fried calamari was mixed in the arugula and fava beans and had a light sauce - to die for! 

And for entrees we had the chicken and lamb kabobs - which were also amazing. If you have to choose one - I'd go with the lamb. The eggplant puree it comes with is out of this world!

All-in-all it was a great experience and I can't wait to go back!
author: Roya P.

description:
Had an evening of the specials....

Walked in with no reservations on a friday night  and was promptly seated !  gold star.  The place filled up quickly after that .

All the specials looked great  so we ordered:

 the Cod  entree was served over a  bed of stewed chard and tomatoes
 arugula salad oyster mushroom leek feta flatbread  and
 sardines over a bed of veggies and dressing.
The sardines were excellent.  Meaty not too salty.  For those who are afriad of sardines, this will would convert and non sardine lovers out there.

The flatbread rocked. can't wait to try this at home.
The salad was simple and very fresh. Yum!

The cod fell very flat.  The cod was a bit mushy and  flavorless in contrast to the quite spicy veggies.  The veggies were good, but totally overpowered the fish.  Do not recommend.

The service was friendly if a bit timid.  

It made a great date night.
author: maia j.

description: The lamb meatball sandwich was so flavorful. Came with a dainty side salad but the overall food portion was enough, and not too much. The space needed some color, perhaps some decor from the homeland? The coffee service was a little weak, and the table was super wobbly.  Regardless of the negatives, the taste of the food was enough to want to return and try new items.
author: Nora M.

description:
Only had the 3-spread appetizer (hummus, garlicky yogurt, and a walnut spread).  The yogurt was delicious, the hummus smokey and rich, and the walnut spread a little bland.  The turkish bread that it comes with is divine!  But there's not enough of it, so get an extra order.

Wine selection is so-so.
author: Sona P.

description: Simple food, but seasoned very well! Really enjoyed: watermelon salad, chicken kebabs, lamb meatballs, moussaka, and roasted cauliflower. They were out of the Manti so was a bit disappointed. Service is pretty fast. Portions on the smaller side for the appetizers so for a group of six adults, got a bit pricey.  It gets busy very fast so definitely make reservations.
author: Kat T.

description:
We had lentil soup, cucumber salad, fried zucchini dish and flat Turkish bread (pide) with cheese and eggplants. 
Lentil soup : pretty good
Cucumber salad : pretty good
Zucchini dish ; good
Pide : good but not entirely  is authentic..
Interior design ; very very good
Service : very good

Overall highly recommended...
author: Ali E.

description: Delicious food and good ambience. When I visit San Francisco a lot of the places with good food often are cafeteria style seating, so I was happy to find this place that was cozy, inviting, and had good lighting. I always love Turkish tea. The trio of yogurt sauces were delicious as were the lamb and chicken kabobs. The olives were warm and yummy. Can't wait to come back!
author: Melisa W.

description: Delish! My boyfriend and I split the hummus plate and lamb kebab. It was all amazing, highly recommend the hummus plate.
author: Emily B.

description: The food, the service, the ambience, all 5 stars. I haven't been to Turkey but if Troya is half as good as the food in Turkey I can't wait to visit. Plus, the people that work there are very nice and always help my wife and I find a table without reservations.
author: Luis C.

description: Ate here today and my chicken kebab came with three quarter-sized pieces of chickens...was very very small. 3 or 4 bites of chicken total.
author: Yin L.

description: Really solid food. Vegetarians will love the options. We stuck to the small plates - lentil and bulgar salad, humus dip, roasted cauliflower, and buklawa for dessert. Well made simple food no masquerading here. We will be back!
author: riddhi g.

description: My wife and I stopped in here for a quick bite to eat on our last day vacationing in San Francisco. We were attracted by the possibility of gluten free options and we were delighted by the most delicious Mediterranean food we've had to date. I intend to try to recreate the salmon and halloum skewers we had that night.
author: John M.

description: I came with a couple friends and we ordered a number of mezes to try different dishes and get a sense of the food.  The ones that stood out were the feta cheese cigars with pistachio and honey (nice balance of flavors, loved the crispiness of the cigars, fun and tasty eat), grilled calamari with turkish salsa and garlic aioli (I love calamari, fresh and had just the right saltiness), zucchini fritters with mint and yogurt (this was my fave, wish I had it all to myself, ha).  For our shared entree we had the California yellow tail with organic grape tomatoes and warm chickpea salad (this was perfect to share as you should pull off what you want, fish was fresh, tasty and tender).  We capped off our meal with Turkish coffee which comes in a little cup, strong and don't drink the bitter grounds that collect at the bottom - loved it though overall.  Service was nice and attentive.  I just wish I did not forget to pick up our leftovers - darn!  Oh well, I will just have to go back!  ;D
author: Maile N.

description:
My husband and I went to Troya on Fillmore on Saturday night.  We were delighted with the food and dining experience. We had the Brussels sprouts, sardines, fried zucchini, and yellow tail kebabs. All were excellent. We also had the pumpkin desert.
The menu was different from the original one on Clement. I would say the choices were more contemporary and lighter, but still Turkish. There seemed to be a very good wine and beer menu. The service with attentive but not in your face. There seems to be a real positive vibe among the staff. 

We will definitely go back.
author: Shelley B.

description: Most underrated restaurant on Fillmore.  Troya has a proven track record of serving good food (been operating on Clement Street for 10+ years), their restaurant on Fillmore is clean and service is good.  While many of the smaller restaurants often have lines, Troya is larger than most along the street and rarely ever has a wait.  For lunch I highly recommend the albacore tuna wrap.
author: Andrew R.

description: Great food and service! Always a favorite, elevated place in the fillmore.
author: Agnes P.

description: feta in lahmacun is not a great idea! We paid 20 dollars for a spoon of manti. It is over priced and not even a real turkish food. I dont recommend this place.
author: Ceren B.

description: Enjoyed the food and interior design.  The communal table top was a bit too high and uncomfortable, but enjoyed the beautiful lighting and materials.  Loved the lamb kebab, black lentil salad, and feta cigars!  Great atmosphere for a date
author: Ryan N.

description: Excellent food and service! Tried the lamb meatballs which were delicious and also the cigar cheese rolls and zucchini fritters and hummus plate. Everything was fantastic!
author: Yas G.

description: Yum! Came her for lunch and had the brussel sprouts and chicken wrap. Delicious! Expensive ($12 for a lunch wrap!) but relatively comparable with other Fillmore restaurants. Would give it a 5 if the prices were a bit more reasonable.
author: Michaela S.

description: Thoroughly enjoyable first time experience. Soooo glad we got several dishes to share including an outstanding cauliflower as a side to share. Sounded boring but definitely had zing. Short, but tasty wine list, many more options for beer lovers.do not miss the lamb meet balls and don't hesitate to order more than less- you'll be glad of the take home leftovers the next day. Oh, and it is all very reasonable for the quality. If I lived closer I'd become a regular.
author: Joan P.

description:
Dear Troya,
Your food, service and atmosphere are all lovely. Your sign sucks. I've walk right by your restaurant every time I've tried to go there. And I even live in the neighborhood. I can never find it unless I look up the address. I can't imagine you get many walk ins with that sign! It needs some light! Give it light!!!
author: Khloe M.

description: Delicious Turkish/fusion, highly recommended. Not the best in Fillmore St but well worth a visit. The marinated chicken kebabs were tender and beautifully flavourful, well paired with a delicious piquant paprika sauce. The lentil and burghul salad was a nice fusion riff on the traditional tabbouleh. Calamari was amazing. Even simple mezze like bread and warm olives were nicely presented and tasty.
author: Greg B.

description: Delightful meal in this fantastic restaurant.  The young man who waited on our table was very kind when my meal wasn't what I expected (my fault).   He was gracious wanting to make it better.  This is what great restaurants are made of...great food and waiters who are looking after their customers.   Well done.
author: K C.

description: We enjoyed the roasted cauliflower most and would definitely order that dish again if we returned to Troya. The duck confit pizza had nice overall flavor, although we didn't really pick up on the fennel, and the duck was pretty dry for a confit. The lamb kabobs were good but I would probably try a different main dish if I went back. Troya is a nice little restaurant in a neighborhood full of nice little restaurants. While I generally enjoyed the meal I'd probably be more likely to find somewhere else next time.
author: m t.

description: I have found it rare to have that balance of excellent service and amazing food. This place has unique Turkish style food that doesn't compare to any other Turkish place I have been. It has a very friendly vibe-no snooty people here at all! Yet you do feel it is perfectly upscale but casual at the same time. I could easily eat here several times a week. My goal is to try everything on the menu. Also, they do not make you feel rushed at all!
author: Sara S.

description:
My third time there thinking that it would get better but it didn't. 

First and foremost - the waiter was horrible, couldn't be bothered to make eye contact and didn't seem interested in taking our order or serving our party. We were not three young professionals and therefore he seemed to give attention to everyone else but us. One of the guest needed assistance to get to the table and his judgmental attitude was visible from the moment he came to the table. 

The host / waiter's assistant who sat us was very kind and nice. 

The person that ran the food was good.

The person that cleared the plate was great. 

We didn't see the waiter after ordering our food until it came time for the check. 

I am saddened that someone could have been so judgmental and disinterested in 2014 in San Francisco. 

This is my last attempt at going to this restaurant. 

Manager - please some of the staff that all customers deserve customer service.
author: first l.

description: Ok, my husband and I came here last week sometime on a Saturday night. It seemed interesting to try though I know theres a couple more places in Fillmore that's Mediterranean as well. Compared to La Mediterranian this place's portions suck. the quality of food was great, tasted delicious. I really expected more satisfying portions for the prices they charge.
author: Eugenia L.

description: I love going here regularly. Although the menu isn't huge, it changes monthly, and there is enough variety. The dishes are interesting, wine is good, it can get a little loud but it is always a fun night out.
author: Peaches P.

description:
We were really excited to try this neighborhood spot, but unfortunately, the experience left us disappointed. We ordered a trio of yogurts w bread, feta sticks w honey, brussel sprouts, grilled calamari, cauliflower, and the meatballs. Each dish came out separately in that order and they waited til it was done before bringing the next. It would have been nice to have it timed better (together) - this isn't exactly fine dining where each dish should be savored individually. Really the yogurt would have been nice w everything else. The cauliflower was a particular disappointment. Neither of us ate any of it and the server said he'd take it off the bill (but he forgot to). 
On a positive note the meatballs were delicious! Maybe a little heavy on the dried fruit but overall it's a good dish to try. 
I'm not sure we'll return any time soon, which is too bad bc it seems like such a nice spot (nice active ambience). Maybe it was just an off night.
author: Natasha T.

description: Yes, disappointed.  Unfortunately, the brunch menu wasn't as exciting as their dinner menu (no dumplings!).  Ever since a grand tour of Turkey a few years back, I've been eager to find a great Turkish restaurant in the Bay Area.  While I could appreciate all the bold flavors and generous portion sizes, I found the flavors and the meal overpowering.  The roasted cauliflower meze was overly salty, although the lamb kebab was tasty and filling enough.  We enjoyed the flatbread, but it was not outstanding.  When we asked if they had baklava, the server said they did and asked if we wanted one or two orders.  When we asked him his recommendation given that we couldn't finish all the food, he said two.  It turned out to be too much - we ended up with two servings of baklava and a scoop of ice cream each.  Normally too much dessert is just fine with me, but their baklava was filler dense rather than delicately and refinely sweet.
author: Peg S.

description: If you are looking for down and dirty home style Turkish food, this isn't your place.  IF you are looking for delicious, fancy, tapas style, small portioned food, then this is your place.  great service.  nice date place
author: Shay D.

description: Came to have dinner with my boyfriend here, a couple weeks ago, because where we originally picked was way too long of a wait. I really liked the atmosphere inside, it was just welcoming and smelled amazing like the food! I really really enjoyed my food! I had the Manti. Our server, Veronica, was AWESOME!  She was too funny about warning me if I liked yogurt or not because of the nature of Manti and she was right but like I said it was great!!!
author: Ashton S.

description:
Tried this place tonight and, sadly, won't be back. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't horrible by any means but I wasn't impressed by most of what we had:

Special of the day: little gem lettuce. Kumquats- delicious, interesting, different, but too much dressing
Dolmas- good, not great, a little overcooked- did not like the sweet sauce on this dish
Eggplant flatbread- pretty good, but not amazing
Dips- yogurt was great, red pepper was ok, eggplant was unedible

Overall, it reminded that I'm not the biggest fan of Turkish food. I'm Lebanese and love Mediterranean / middle eastern dishes, but just not crazy about Turkish cuisine and, sadly, troya did not change my mind. I will say though that service was great.
author: brett d.

description: The best, most unique and delicious Mediterranean/Turkish food I have ever had. We had the asparagus and calamari appetizers (both amazing), and for main courses we had the short ribs and lamb kebab (huge portions and delicious). 10/10 would eat here again many times.
author: Isaac T.

description: Nice clean restaurant, good service. Food is tasty and the wine selection is extensive for a layman like myself. The kabobs are good and actually fill me up:) I need to try the Clement Troya next.
author: Keyser S.

description:
don't be deceived- prices seemed a bit high but this place is AMAZING!

humus: 3 different types- i loved the yogurt one and my friends loved the other ones. bread was amazing!! nice and fluffy
sardines: decent/good. i would probably try something else next time since many of the appetizers looked really good
lamb kebab: super delish!! the meat was made to perfection!
yellowtail kebab: a bit dry, tasted like chicken. worth the try but would probably go for something else next time
manti: i visited turkey recently and the manti here definitely brought back some good memories. 

didn't have the flatbread but it looked good. 
overall, i loved this place and definitely looking to come back. my friends are also from the mediterranean area and also loved the place. 

also, great decor! extra roomy, high ceilings, love the feel. 
great date spot but also great to grab dinner with some friends.
author: Janet Y.

description: Great spot. Exceeded expectations. Good wine, great light small plates, friendly service I'll definitely come back. Crispy Brussels sprouts, Turkish dumplings, and baklava for dessert were our faves.
author: Matt W.

description: Really delicious food. The cheese cigars were amazing. The flavors in all the dishes were great, nothing was too heavy. As two people, we split 6 small plates, a dessert, and two glasses of wine which came to $100 including tip. I also really liked the service -- not too pushy and in your face, but there when needed.
author: Just R.

description: I'm sorry to write a bad review, but the one time that I went here my food was not good.  I'm not a big meat eater and that could have been part of the reason. Sadly, I would discourage vegetarians from coming here (even though this style of food normally works well with a vegetarian diet).
author: Amy L.

description: Ok atmosphere; not sure if I'd come back even though there wasn't much to complain about besides smaller portions and limited options for vegans. The hand dryer in the bathroom is very low for some reason; maybe it's a Turkish thing lol. But it's not a bad choice for a quick lunch.
author: V L.

description: I was not impressed. I read previous reviews, and was hopeful. I went with a friend and we had the watermelon salad and roasted cauliflower for appetizers, and split the stuffed eggplant entree. There was nothing special about any of the dishes, and we both agreed we could have done better cooking them ourselves. There was nothing special about the watermelon salad. The roasted cauliflower was good, though I thought it was overseasoned. The stuffed eggplant came out so fast, and looked like it had been sitting under a heating lamp for hours. It looked so sad. I am not rushing to return.
author: Pam F.

description: Mediocre experience, tiny portions for the price. Short ribs were good. We ordered the chicken guvec -- it was on the menu posted outside, but not on the menu that they give you when you are seated. We ordered the chicken kebab instead. Ok chicken, a bit on the dry side. Several servers waited on us. Instead of making us feel special, we felt like orphans, not belonging to anyone. Who does this tip go to at the end? Servers were ok, not too friendly, not inattentive -- just distant and disinterested -- maybe it's what other reviewers call the "hipster attitude". Loud inside. Can barely hear the person in front of you. Meh experience and food for this snooty neighborhood. Not going back.
author: C Anne D.

description: Troya is a more ordinary version of Kokari. Menus are very similar but the food is not as impressive for the price you pay. Greek food is usually pretty flavorful and aromatic but I did not get that Mediterranean punch form Troya. The lamb skewers were grilled nicely but lacked marination or seasoning. The beef dumplings in yogurt, like gnocchi with beef, were  unique but mainly tangy and definitely overpriced. Menu selection is quite simple as well. I prefer La Mediterranean across the street for similar food, though slightly different.
author: Ed L.

description: Great-tasting chicken kabobs on top of a rice and vegetables was quite good.  Nice decor and good service, too.  Reasonable pricing for what you get.  Will be back.
author: Jeff W.

description: This restaurant is marvelous.  The roasted eggplant and tomato salad is superb as are the lamb meat balls, the roasted cauliflower and the sardines.  Excellent Turkish food but not greasy as in other Turkish restaurants. The tastes are subtle, the presentation beautiful and the service is excellent.  We'll be back again and again.
author: Annette O.

description: The service was great, however for the amount that was spent nothing was fresh. All their standouts (lamb meatballs and Brussels sprouts) were overcooked. Based on the reviews, seems like it's a hit or miss.
author: Brianna L.

description: This is hands-down my fave turkish restaurant in the city plus the location is amazing as well.
author: Beril Y.

description: over-priced.. dry... flavor-less.. great service.
author: Denise M.

description: Really enjoyed this small plates Turkish restaurant while at a conference in San Francisco in May.  Very nice setting, good service and tasty food.  When we enjoyed a dip, they gave us some extra.
author: David N.

description: Had a satisfactory Sunday brunch here.  Highlights included big portions (the chicken lavash wrap likely measured longer than a foot in total and a half portion would have been more than sufficient), house-made marmalade that came as part of the breakfast sampler, and Turkish coffee.  Service was good and the food came out super quick, though the restaurant was pretty empty.  The interior hasn't changed much since Citizen Cake and felt too dark for a day-time meal.
author: Clara H.

description: This review is for Troya Clement.  Delicious dinner!  The 3 dip appetizer was great!  Moussaka and bayti were two thumbs up. Advise against the red Turkish wine.  Sit near a window that opens - it got uncomfortably hot towards the end of the meal.  We would have loved to have tried the Baklava for dessert but it was so stiflingly hot, we opted for the ice cream across the street at Toy Boat.
author: M W.

description: Too expensive for what it is. I've never ordered lentil soup ($7 and tiny), and not received pide or bread. Here they try and charge you. As common etiquette, bread should be served w soup. Half the reason we order soup is so we can dip the delicious turkish bread in it. Server stand off'ish too which I didn't like.
author: Ceyda G.

description: The food here is just horrible. Chicken and tuna kabob were both dry. Flatbreads are tasteless. The service is not much better. Tables are also too close together.
author: Max M.

description: Stopped in for lunch and shared the cauliflower and chicken kebob- everything was great and had a lot of flavor, I especially loved the spices they put on the cauliflower. I also enjoyed the modern interior of the restaurant and I'd like to visit again at night because of the lighting features.
author: Natalie M.

description:
food: yay i'm a fan!  everything on the troya menu is very good.  i really recommend their turkish meatballs, babaganoush, grilled halloumi, cucumber salad, dolmas, all their flatbreads, braised chicken....everything!  their wine list includes very afforadable and tasty wines.  

service: very nice and helpful...with a sense of humor :)

final thoughts: can't wait to try it again.  the only reason for the 4 stars is the slow service (food) and super super hot temperature in the restaurant...we were sweating :(
author: Kara P.

description: My girlfriend and I came here and both got hit with a stomach bug from the poorly cooked food. I can guarantee that Troya caused this. Not happy.
author: Sean B.

description: Troya never disappoints.  Their food is wonderful, and the atmosphere is comfy and laid back.  My husband and I came to Troya as one of our first dates in San Francisco and have enjoyed it many times with friends and family since.  Try the goat cheese cigars with honey.  Yum.
author: Jaimie C.

description: Went here recently for lunch. Waited 50 minutes for food to arrive. Asked waiter when food would arrive as we had been picking at an appetizer for 45 minutes. Food finally came to the table and there was a big black hair embedded in my salad. Waiter quickly took away the salad and brought another, but it was hard to enjoy anything after that!  I can't take restaurants without proper hygiene - my last visit for sure. Between the service and the hair in food - no can do
author: Ann W.

description: I was at Troya recently for lunch----which was good.  The food was not the problem.  My bill came to $13.47 and when I handed the waitress a $20 bill, she said "Do you want change?"  "Yes", I replied with a smile.  I was owed $6.53.  The waitress came back with $6, saying "We don't give change, we just round up".  !!!!  I'm sure this is illegal--- I know it is theft.  It may only be 53 cents, but it's MY 53 cents, not theirs.
author: Evaa B.

description: What a fantastic new neighborhood spot. Troya nails it on the head. It's casual enough to just go with friends, but nice enough that you could go for a special date or take your parents.  The food was perfectly cooked -- the meat tender and juicy, the dips were flavorful and fresh -- all in all, just delicious. Great wine, great noise level, great interior design -- sleek and simple yet elegant. I loved it.
author: Michelle T.

description: Got take out tonight and was very impressed. The bar is a great place to grab a drink while waiting for your food.
author: Justin O.

description: Small portions. Some staples of Turkish cuisine missing here... If you are craving Iskandar or Döner kebabs this is not the place. Too fancy and rather pretentious for the food offered.
author: Ramoun M.

description: Very friendly service coupled with amazingly flavorful food.  The moussaka is outstanding, along with the meat ball appetizer.  Just a great experience overall.
author: Mark G.

description: Really great food. Stumbled across this place and loved it! Try the baba ghannouj!
author: Glen T.

description: Excellente! My wife and I had a scrumptious dinner here on a LivingSocial deal. Even though we tried to call 5 times to make a reservation with no success (something to improve !), the maître d' was able to get us a table at 7 pm on a Saturday night. The food was just right. Very tasty, nice presentation, just the right amount. We had a lamb kebab and a stuffed eggplant, glass of wine and baklava for dessert. All were 5 stars, thumbs up. Highly recommend it, but be sure to make a reservation on weekend nights.
author: Miklos P.

description:
We came for a Saturday brunch (group of 4) and it was delightful. The food was outstandingly delicious and serving sizes were great (not outrageously large); the staff were super nice and helpful. 

The lentil and burghur salad was a highlight for me - light and full of texture and flavour. But it's hard to pick a favourite, everything was so good! 

It's great for brunch - get a spot in the front window to watch everyone enjoying a sunny day on Fillmore!
author: Erin O.

description:
really good mediterranean food and a really nice atmosphere to dine out.  three of us shared the feta and arugula flatbread, the grilled halloumi cheese, the turkish meatball lavash wrap, and the lamb kebab.  everything was super delicious, though I think it was sort of overpriced.

service was excellent and speedy.
author: Lisa C.

description: Went there for dinner with friends. My chicken kebab was very tasty. The hummus sampler was a bit bland I thought. The space is nice with a nice atmosphere and the wait staff was very friendly. Nice location on Fillmore Street close to stores, etc. Will go back to try some other dishes.
author: Manuela P.

description: We went there on Sunday and tried lahmacun, hamburger, borek, manti, dolma and there were excellent. It has been a while i didn't eat this much. Prices are very reasonable too. Place very nicely designed even if it is crowded you can talk and enjoy your meal without your elbows touching to the next table guest :) We will definitely go there again.
author: onder e.

description:
Great addition to the Upper Fillmore.  Tried it the first week, and happily returned several times.

The food is very good.  Subtle spicing, good ingredients and the kitchen is clearly paying attention to what they do.  Best bet - go with friends, and share 3 or 4 of the mezes and a big plate or 2 (the moussaka .is outstanding).  I haven;t been disappointed - zucchini fritters are a treat; the lamb dolmas a nice change from the usual tired rice-inflated grape leave I find most other places. The baklava is the best I have had - Not overly sweet, delicate flavors.  Finish the meal with the Turkish coffee.

The wine list is very nice - a number of unusual selections, reasonably priced. though not cheap.  I've enjoyed the Turkish wines, great  rapport qualité prix.  

The staff is attentive, knowledgeable and friendly.

Troya does very good food with very good service.  (But, having read other reviews, please note this warning: This is not the cheap middle-eastern feedbag that some reviewers seem to expect).
author: Paul W.

description: I enjoy having Troya in my neighborhood. Their dishes are tasty and unusual and satisfying..you can eat as much or as little as you wish...and the service is very professional
author: Kay H.

description: 5 stars for the feta cigars, those were awesome.  4 stars for the beef dumplings - very good but a tad spicy for my taste.  Not abnormally spicy, however. It was a little Loud. Good wine selection. Friendly service. Definitely will return.
author: Larry E.

description: The food was ok, but nothing To die for. went there to try manti (on the 7by7 list) but they were out of it, for the second time.. my bad review goes specially to the service, which was veery slow. We had to remind them to bring us the entrees, and same thing for the extra bread we ordered.  Just disappointed, not coming back!
author: Maria G.

description: Wasn't bad but wasn't particularly good either. I tried a bunch of stuff and everything was just ok - a bit too greasy and flat from a flavor perspective. Space is lovely and service is good. I'm very surprised about complaints on size, as I thought the $7-$8 apps I had were very large for the price. Wine needs to be better.  I doubt I'll return - you can do so much better within a few blocks.
author: Ellen H.

description:
Excellent place with scrumptious turkish inspired small plates, great wine finds at affordable rates and some decadent desserts

Staff are cordial and attentive and will return here often
author: Arjunan R.

description: This has become our favorite Mediterranean restaurant!  We are thoroughly satisfied every time we dine here. It's always busy, but never too busy where we have to wait hours to eat- usually get seated pretty quickly.  All of the entries are excellent with such complex flavor.  The staff is always welcoming and provide such great, attentive and seamless service.  It keeps us coming back for more!!
author: Gaby G.

description: I came here for a quick lunch and got the eggplant wrap. The vibe was relaxed and trendy, surrounded by other quirky bourgeoisie restaurants and shops that line Fillmore. The lavash and the salad that came with it was delicious - the salad was a very nice touch. Overall a good place to stop for lunch and the waiter was funny and friendly!
author: Megan L.

description: Very yummy spot on Fillmore.  Don't be thrown off by the $2 turkish bread, it's really good but you need to spend the extra 3 bucks and get the sauces.  Lamb kabobs are amazing.  Wasn't impressed by the beef dumplings though, everyone on yelp is raving about them for some reason.  it's also a little pricey, but that's expected on Fillmore.
author: Ryan H.

description: Wonderful exotic (to me) menu and friendly staff make this a perfect brunch spot with friends.
author: Rob K.

description: My husband and I shared zucchini fritters with mint and yoghurt sauce, roasted cauliflower with spicy oil, vegetable kebabs (he's vegetarian). I also ordered the meatballs.  Each dish was perfectly prepared and visually pleasing. Tasty crackers (complimentary). Service was a little slow but friendly. Our plates were changed several times. Dessert of kenefe was very tasty. We will definitely return. One drawback is noise that bounces off all the hard surfaces; at times we nearly had to shout. They could benefit from acoustics consultant. Also, they don't use Opentable even though their other location does.
author: Liana T.

description: Very good food in a nice, classy setting.  My faves so far have been the halloumi appetizer, the lamb kebab, and the coffee/chocolate pot de creme dessert.  I was underwhelmed by the chicken kebab & the cauliflour appetizer, but the other things have been good enough to keep me going back.  Friendly service.  A good addition to Fillmore!
author: Molly P.

description: Good food, but the napkins leave white crumblies all over your clothes.
author: Mike O.

description: My afternoon at Troya was one of the best lunches I had in recent memory.  Troya definitely exceed my expectations, especially with their mouth-watering grilled pita wraps that was bursting with unique flavors.  I also recommend the chicken kabobs that were cooked perfectly.  The service is also accomedating and is the perfect place to grab a bite after traveling around Filmore.  I highly recommend Troya if you are in the area!
author: Shannon W.

description: Amazing....the Feta and Arugula Flat Bread is to die for, so are the Turkish Mushrooms!!
author: Ben N.

description: Soooooo delicious! I went here with a few friends the other night and we were blown away by the food. Everything tasted so fresh and the flavors were bursting. We got the dips, kebabs, turkish meatballs, beet salad and some other things - all of which were fabulous. The ambience is great too - exposed brick and pretty bar. A couple of us are gluten-free and it was no problem for them to accommodate us. I can't wait to go back!
author: H M.

description:
I was really excited to try Troya, but came back with an "a-ok" feeling.  With this restaurant, it's hit-or-miss with the menu.  We didn't order much:  
-Beef dumplings: very good!  
-Zucchini fritters: not very warm, seemed pre-made and not fresh.  Would not order this again.
-Mussels: Good until my friend pointed out that they tasted very "fishy" and Briney.  I think I was really distracted by dipping my bread into the broth so I didn't notice as much.  

The staff was very nice, the restaurant had a great ambiance (and no one was snotty even though we were dressed down), and there was no wait at around 7:30 or 8, but this was on a Tuesday night.    

I feel like I might go back to Troya to try other dishes on the menu.  We were not that impressed with what we ordered and left feeling like we had ordered the wrong things.  Better luck next time?
author: Alison K.

description: Great new spot, I am not typically a big fan of Mediterranean food but really enjoyed everything we tried here. Highlights were the cucumber salad and lamb kabobs.
author: Corey L.

description:
This place is awesome. Excellent Turkish food, nice decor, and great service. 
The waiter chased me 3 blocks to return my credit card, which I had forgotten at my table...very nice guy, I appreciated his effort.
author: Ron A.

description: Finally gave it a try, we live around the corner.  Hostess had a major problem in estimating wait time:  had to be delayed three or four times, although I don't believe it was totally her fault.  The wine was good and table service was excellent.  The "spread" combo was good.  We tried three different kabobs - food was OK, but very salty.
author: Glenn S.

description: What a TREAT! After being up at Alta Plaza park with our dog, we were hungry for lunch so decided to try Troya. We knew they had one table outside. Anyway, we noticed they had haloumi cheese on the menu as a filling for the brunch omelet, but asked them if they'd grill it instead and serve it to us as an app - since that's the way we are used to eating haloumi cheese. The server was so nice about it and they fulfilled our request. It was so delicious. We have had a really hard time finding haloumi cheese in SF so we were pleasantly surprised. We enjoyed the cheese and hummus app with the Turkish iced tea. Loved the fact they bring you a whole pitcher of tea. My husband drinks iced tea so fast, the poor server is usually going back and fourth to refill his glass. Smart thinking on their part. For entrees we had the chicken pesto wrap and yellowtail kabobs. We loved them both and finished off the meal with Turkish Coffee. We are SO glad we discovered Troya and will undoubtedly return regularly.
author: Kelsey K.

description: The second we walked through the door, my husband and I received exceptional customer service. We waited only about 30 minutes (had a glass of wine while we waited).
