Once we sat, we ordered the Hummus, Haydari & Muhammara with House Made Turkish Bread and the Marinated Lamb Kebab with Onions, Peppers & Eggplant Puree to split. The eggplant puree was to DIE for and the turkish bread was heavenly. I'm writing this review because it's the first restaurant in SF where we've waited less than hour to recieve great customer service AND excellent food. I'm definitely going back here.
author: Lexi H.

description: Mixed experience:  The good---- Vege moussaka had some nice, interesting flavors as did the small meza lamb meatballs.  The bad---- $14 for 2 smallish meatballs with garnish ?  More than a little overpriced.      The moussaka, while good, was similar to a boiling pot of water when it arrived-- we had to wait about 10 minutes for it to cool sufficiently to eat.   Service was slow due to understaffing.
author: David R.

description: Really enjoyed this place! Cozy, a good buzz, friendly service. We ordered a number of plates to share, and they were all delcious.
author: Heather K.

description: Excellent food and service. We arrived early for our reservation and they were very helpful and accommodating even though the restaurant was quite busy. We had the chicken and lamb kebabs, the sides served with the kebabs were delicious (garbanzo bean salad, eggplant puree. etc). Everything was very flavorful and the ambiance is very nice.
author: Mj C.

description:
A good addition to the Pac Heights area. The food was tasty and a reasonable price. I went shortly after it opened and it wasn't hard to get a table- though enough people in the restaurant to make it feel lively. Sat at the bar which was fun and had good service.

Lots of good tapas plates to share. They have a few full entrees which were less impressive but still good.
author: Katie S.

description: I am not sure why this restaurant gets so many high ratings.  I went there for dinner recently and found the food to be heavy.  The grilled calamari dish was smothered in this creamy sauce and the mushroom dish had a super strong butter flavor.  I thought I ordered healthier options and that Mediterranean cuisine tends to be lighter but this was not the case in my experience.  We ordered a chocolate cake for dessert after the waitress said it was "light."  After one bite, my friend and I universally thought it was  pretty heavy.  I am not a health freak, but after the meal, I just wanted to go home do some push ups and stomach exercises. I would have rather have eaten prime rib or burger if I was going to intake all the fat/calories.  Just not my cup of tea.
author: C T.

description: Great ambience and good food - nice and casual place with excellent greek / middle eastern type food.  The bar is good place to sit and eat with a glass of wine.  Have been there 3 times so far and the experience has been quite consistent. Highly recommend this place.
author: S S.

description: I love Troya on Fillmore. The food is delicious and the service friendly! The grilled calamari is tender and beautifully spiced, the roasted cauliflower with urfa is tasty, the salmon kebab and chicken kebab each with chick peas is delicious and the pistachio filled baklava a great ending to a healthy and excellent meal. This is a neighborhood gem!
author: Liv D.

description: Let me start with the positives - it has a nice ambiance and service is pretty decent too. I really wanted to like this place and was pretty excited about trying out their food. I have to say Meh, I've experienced better Mediterranean food. The portion sizes are tiny and the mezzes don't even come with bread...you have to order separately. The bread is a bit dry and flavorless too. My first experience wasn't that great, so I went back there yesterday to give it another shot. I got the moussaka as an entree and was not that impressed either - for $18, it is a pretty small size entree and nothing on the side.  Overall average overpriced turkish mediterranean food.
author: Anitha I.

description: While the branch on clement was great this one was a true disappointment. Very small servings with high price tags! The service was inadequate and we had to wait a while for someone to take our order. We ordered an appetizer and two main dishes. The chicken kabob was burnt. A lot of hype but no quality.
author: O N.

description: What a great evening at Troya on Fillmore. Our server was excellent and knew the dishes well and took time with us appropriately. The cheese cigars, lamb meatballs and brussel sprouts were really the faves. One of those with me doens't eat brussel sprouts but unknowingly ate some and wanted more...until I told her what they were!! In any case, this is such a step up from other places of Mediterranean style that might be considered comparable. So much more for the price overall...very pleased with my first experience here.
author: Dr F.

description: Troya's mediterranean cuisine is spectacular.  They change a few dishes to keep up with locals, but the spicy string beans and chicken kabob are epic staples.  My wife and I are regulars.
author: Gregg W.

description: Troya has a nice ambiance and that's about it. Maybe my expectations were too high. I thought the food was very bland. The turkish meatballs were good and that's about it. Tried most of the appetizers, everything was "okay." I've had much better for much cheaper.
author: Kamalpreet K.

description: My friend suggested we try Troya for dinner.  We go out to a new place every month to catch up now that we no longer work together.   Looks like this place just opened on Fillmore in the former Citizen Cake location.  We loved everything!  I'm vegetarian (I eat eggs and dairy products) and my friend eats everything.  There were so many good options from which to choose!!  We were both very, very happy with the entire meal and with our drinks.  We split the zucchini cakes with mint and yogurt sauces on the side and "cigars" (full of feta and other yummy things) with honey and pistachio on the side.  For dinner, I had the eggplant and feta Anatolian flat bread (amazing!) and my friend had a lamb dish with stewed tomatoes, onions and a yogurt sauce.  The portions are generous.  Nonetheless, we each had a dessert (that was our only mistake) - we should have shared ONE dessert - they are huge!! My friend enjoyed the Turkish coffee a lot.  We will be back.  I also have to note that the service was *excellent*, the decor was very inviting and the tables are set at a good distance (unlike at other places where you feel like you're sitting right on the people seated next to you.)   I highly recommend Troya on Fillmore.
author: V B.

description: Came here a few months ago with my boyfriend and had fantastic service with amazing food. I couldn't wait to come back. So I took my mom here on Mother's Day excited to show her the place and it ended up being a terrible experience. We had TERRIBLE service. All the employees looked miserable and didn't smile once. It took about 20 minutes to even get our drinks. The food came out about 30 minutes later and it tastes horrible and not authentic at all. We tried using a groupon and they claimed they weren't taking groupons on Mother's Day (WHAT F**** BULLSHIT). I couldn't believe the service and on top of that the food was disgusting. Never coming back here again because of that experience. What a shame because I had a great experience the first time. Don't go here the fat lady will be rude to you and the Turkish workers won't smile and will throw menus at your face. Teach your employees some good customer service please
author: Ceren T.

description: Very disappointing. I really liked Troya on Clement so I decided to try Troya on Fillmore. HUGE difference. I really was displeased with Troya Fillmore for a number of reasons. First, I couldn't hear a word my date was saying across the long table. We were squished between other tables and under a hot light like an interrogation. The calamari was very strange. I couldn't understand the waitresses accent. They didn't take away our empty plates and made it hard to eat. However, they did ask about 20 times if we wanted more wine. The bill was expensive and we didn't even order two entrees. This was a much worse experience than visiting Troya on Clement. The biggest problem was that it was exceptionally LOUD. I felt like I was at a concert. People were standing right behind me the entire time, and it just wasn't a pleasant experience. My date didn't like the place at all. I won't be returning, but will go back to Troya on Clement.
author: Steve D.

description: I really liked the ambiance of Troya. The service was excellent too. But I cannot say the same for the food. We tried zucchini frittata, meatballs, babaghannus and lahmacun. Frittatas were overcooked and lahmacun was not tasty. Only thing I liked was babaghannus, and you probably can't go wrong with that. Also the portions were really small.
author: Elcin E.

description: We ordered the dolmas which were good except for the chili flakes sprinkled on top (who puts chili flakes on dolmas?) which made them inedible for my dining partner who does not eat any spicy foods.  The artichoke flatbread sounded promising, but was in fact just a bunch of veggies thrown on the flatbread without any sauce - and again, sprinkled with chili flakes making the entire dish too spicy for my partner to eat.  (Nowhere on the menu did the description of this flatbread include chili flakes.)  The crackers served before the meal were boring and should have been accompanied by some type of dipping sauce.  And... the bill for one appetizer, one flatbread and one glass of wine was $34.00 not including tip.  We won't be back.
author: Joseph S.

description: Lovely service but the place is LOUD.  It was only half full when we arrived for a late dinner and the noise was overwhelming.  Food was fine but not really special (had the moussaka and some sides) but definitely didn't make up for the noise.
author: Lainie M.

description: My favorite Turkish place (there are not many!).  Exquisite.  Reminds me of my Sephardic childhood.  And of my trips to Turkey.  Very good food, great service, good atmosphere.  Like the decor, minimalist. Come expecially to SF to eat at Troya.
author: yvette c.

description: We went to Troya on a Sunday night with a reservation and used a groupon. The ambiance is casual and the décor was nice. We are vegetarians and appreciated the number of selections we had to choose from. We ordered the grilled haloumi salad as an appetizer which was average -- the haloumi slices were left in slabs (may have been better if cut smaller) and the persimmons felt out of place in the dish. We tried the roasted broccolini flatbread which was excellent -- the smoked shishoto-like peppers with the roasted broccolini and kalamatas was the perfect balance of smoky, spicy, and salty with a cooling kasselini cheese. We got the cauliflower beyti as the main dish and this was stellar -- arguably one of the best vegetarian dishes available in the city. The cauliflower was roasted and spiced perfectly and the yogurt and red sauce was a perfect balance. We considered going back a few weeks later but were disappointed to see that the cauliflower beyti was off the menu (and not available to order based on a phone conversation we had with the restaurant). PLEASE BRING IT BACK for all of the vegetarians in the city.
author: T K.

description: Food was very good as was the atmosphere and service. Easily a 4-5 star except for the small portions and high prices-not a good value. We had the Lentil Soup, Grilled Halloumi Cheese with Roasted Apricot &  Almonds, Zucchini Fritters with Mint & Yogurt, Marys Chicken Skewers with Peppers & Herbs, Marinated Lamb Kebab with Onions, Peppers & Eggplant Puree, Eggplant & Braised Beef Moussaka, and the Turkish Coffee Chocolate Pot de Creme. All were quite tasty-the Lamb especially good. I might go back for a special occasion--too pricey for regular dining.
author: H D.

description: The other Troya location is MUCH better. I'm not sure why they changed their menu, but the offerings at the Clement Street location were much better and more reasonably priced. Granted the food was ok. I definitely didn't like the dumplings though. It seems they sold out a little bit to come into this neighborhood. I know parking is difficult on Clement, but it's a trip that is much more worth the hassle.
author: Maria Y.

description: One of the best restaurants in the area. The Turkish bread isn't that great, but really enjoy the other options on the menu. Lots of vegetarian options as well.
author: arielle r.

description: Really great food and very nice staff. We had the moussaka and grilled vegatables which were dilcious. Great wine selection as well. Only minor complaint is that the menu really isn't that extensive.
author: Natasha W.

description: Consistently good food that is slightly overpriced. I highly recommend the dip platter with turkish bread, chicken kabob, and baklava. Service is always great.
author: Joanna B.

description: The Turkish meatball wraps are beyond delicious! I'm tempted to get it every time I go instead of trying something new. Great ambiance, beautiful design, and wonderful service!
author: Amy F.

description: Pretty good food.  A tad pricey.   But Fillmore needs new places like this.
author: chris b.

description: Love their lentil soup, borek, and bread and spreads (hummus, yogurt and muhammara). Also ordered their roasted cauliflower which was just wonderful. Great spot for vegetarians. Lunch can get a bit pricey (ordering soup plus an appetizer will set you back $14 easily) but the $8/$9 wraps looked nice and big and my coworkers reported that they were delicious.
author: Katherine F.

description: I love Mediterraean food!! Couldn't wait to try this restaurant! I was pleasantly surprised by the chic casual atmosphere.  If you don't feel like hassling crowds and have a relaxing lunch or dinner, this would be a great place to go. Make sure you make reservations. They have bar seats as well as tables. I sat  at the bar with a great glass of wine watching what others were ordering, so I could choose wisely.  I started with  the lamb kebab appetizer.  YUM! Spicy tender lamb with a yogurt sauce didn't disappoint!  Along with the kebab, I had the  Arugula Salad which was light and fresh with lots of flavor.  For my main course I tried the grilled tuna! Very good! I eat a lot of fresh fish so I had something to compare it to. Fish was cooked just right and not over done.   Being someone who is conscience of what I eat, I tend to be a little picky.  Trying to get good quality food in a restaurant isn't always easy.  They use lots of fresh ingredients which is something I am always looking for when I go out. Troya had some great options. If you still have room, have an expresso with their incredible Baklava!  The service was attentive and food came out in good time. This restaurant made for a great evening in a quiet ambiance.
author: Tami R.

description: Ate here on Sunday - wonderful addition to Fillmore St.  Reasonable prices, nice counter seating if you are dining alone, service good, food delicious.  We ordered the spicey green beans with apricots & yogurt suggested by the waiter; the Persian cucumber, radish, black olive salad and the salmon special - each of the yummy - all very flavorable yet simple & light.  I will be back soon.
author: Sheri W.

description: Funny -- I really disliked Troya on Clement, and I thought the food couldn't be too much different. But now I don't know! Is the food at the Fillmore Troya better? Or is it just that the peaceful, airy interior is so much nicer?
author: L.D. K.

description: My husband and I had an awesome dinner at Troya last night after happening to walk by. We had the dips plate (hummus, tzatziki, muhamarra), arugula & fig salad, zucchini cakes, and Turkish meatballs, with baklava for dessert. It was one of the best meals I've had in SF in a long time and the service was great. Our waitress apologized (and comped our dessert) because of a somewhat long pause between the delivery of the second and third plates. I actually welcomed the slower pacing -- I feel like so many small plates restaurants rush you through your orders in hopes you'll order more before you're full. This was an outstanding meal, we'll definitely be back. I'm guessing that Troya will give neighboring LaMediterranee -- another one of my favorite places in the city -- a run for its money!
author: Jen C.
